Title: Introduced by Guereca, 7, Chairman Enrollment and Review

Section 1:
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
E AND R AMENDMENTS TO LB 317
1 1. Strike the original sections and all amendments thereto and
2 insert the following new sections:
3 Section 1. (1) On and after July 1, 2025, the Department of Natural
4 Resources shall be merged into the Department of Environment and Energy,
5 which shall be renamed as the Department of Water, Energy, and
6 Environment, and the Director of Environment and Energy shall be renamed
7 as the Director of Water, Energy, and Environment. The Director of
8 Natural Resources shall be renamed the Chief Water Officer and retain
9 authorities previously prescribed for the administration of duties of the
10 Department of Natural Resources, except as otherwise provided by law.
11 (2) On and after July 1, 2025, positions of employment in the
12 Department of Natural Resources related to the powers, duties, and
13 functions transferred to the Department of Water, Energy, and Environment
14 pursuant to this legislative bill are transferred to the Department of
15 Water, Energy, and Environment. For purposes of the transition, employees
16 of the Department of Natural Resources shall be considered employees of
17 the Department of Water, Energy, and Environment and shall retain their
18 rights under the state personnel system or pertinent bargaining
19 agreement, and their service shall be deemed continuous. This section
20 does not grant employees any new rights or benefits not otherwise
21 provided by law or bargaining agreement or preclude the department or the
22 director from exercising any of the prerogatives of management set forth
23 in section 81-1311 or as otherwise provided by law. This section is not
24 an amendment to or substitute for the provisions of any existing
25 bargaining agreements.
26 Sec. 2. Any appropriation and salary limit provided in any
27 legislative bill enacted by the One Hundred Ninth Legislature, First
-1-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 Session, to Agency No. 29, Department of Natural Resources, shall be null
2 and void, and any such amounts are hereby appropriated to Agency No. 84,
3 Department of Water, Energy, and Environment. Any financial obligations
4 of the Department of Natural Resources that remain unpaid as of June 30,
5 2025, and that are subsequently certified as valid encumbrances to the
6 accounting division of the Department of Administrative Services pursuant
7 to sections 81-138.01 to 81-138.04, shall be paid by the Department of
8 Water, Energy, and Environment from the unexpended balance of
9 appropriations existing in such program classifications on June 30, 2025.
10 Sec. 3. On and after July 1, 2025, whenever the Department of
11 Natural Resources or the Department of Environment and Energy is referred
12 to or designated by any contract or other document in connection with the
13 duties and functions of the Department of Natural Resources or the
14 Department of Environment and Energy as such departments existed prior to
15 July 1, 2025, such reference or designation shall apply to the Department
16 of Water, Energy, and Environment or the Chief Water Officer, as
17 determined by the duties and functions assigned to each in statute. All
18 contracts entered into by the Department of Natural Resources or the
19 Department of Environment and Energy prior to July 1, 2025, in connection
20 with the duties and functions of the Department of Natural Resources or
21 the Department of Environment and Energy as such departments existed
22 prior to July 1, 2025, are hereby recognized, with the Department of
23 Water, Energy, and Environment or the Chief Water Officer, as determined
24 by the duties and functions assigned to each in statute, succeeding to
25 all rights and obligations under such contracts. Any cash funds,
26 custodial funds, gifts, trusts, grants, and appropriations of funds from
27 prior fiscal years available to satisfy obligations incurred under such
28 contracts shall be transferred and appropriated to such department or the
29 Chief Water Officer for the payment of such obligations. All documents
30 and records transferred, or copies of the same, may be authenticated or
31 certified by such department or the Chief Water Officer for all legal
-2-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 purposes.
2 Sec. 4. No suit, action, or other proceeding, judicial or
3 administrative, lawfully commenced prior to July 1, 2025, or which could
4 have been commenced prior to that date, by or against the Department of
5 Natural Resources or the Department of Environment and Energy, or any
6 director or any employee thereof in such director's or employee's
7 official capacity or in relation to the discharge of his or her official
8 duties, shall abate by reason of the transfer of duties and functions
9 from the Department of Natural Resources to the Department of Water,
10 Energy, and Environment or the Chief Water Officer or the renaming of the
11 Department of Environment and Energy as the Department of Water, Energy,
12 and Environment.
13 Sec. 5. On and after July 1, 2025, unless otherwise specified,
14 whenever any provision of law refers to the Department of Natural
15 Resources or the Department of Environment and Energy in connection with
16 duties and functions of the Department of Water, Energy, and Environment,
17 such law shall be construed as referring to the Department of Water,
18 Energy, and Environment or the Chief Water Officer, as determined by the
19 duties and functions assigned to each in statute.
20 Sec. 6. On July 1, 2025, all items of property, real and personal,
21 including office furniture and fixtures, books, documents, and records of
22 the Department of Natural Resources pertaining to the duties and
23 functions transferred to the Department of Water, Energy, and Environment
24 pursuant to this legislative bill shall become the property of such
25 department.
26 Sec. 7. Section 2-408, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
27 amended to read:
28 2-408 For purposes of the Resilient Soils and Water Quality Act:
29 (1) Demonstration and research farms means large-scale field and
30 pasture settings located across the state that provide a demonstration of
31 healthy soil practices in support of the educational and research
-3-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 programs of the producer learning community;
2 (2) Department means the Department of Water, Energy, and
3 Environment Natural Resources; and
4 (3) Producer learning community means an agricultural producer-led,
5 nonprofit, voluntary membership organization dedicated to fostering
6 learning, skills, and abilities and the gathering and sharing of
7 knowledge for the purpose of carrying out the Resilient Soils and Water
8 Quality Act.
9 Sec. 8. Section 2-414, Revised Statutes Cumulative Supplement, 2024,
10 is amended to read:
11 2-414 (1) The nitrogen reduction incentive program is created and
12 shall be administered by the Department of Water, Energy, and Environment
13 Natural Resources. The department may collaborate with natural resources
14 districts to administer the program.
15 (2) The purposes of the program are to:
16 (a) Provide incentive payments to farmers; and
17 (b) Encourage farmers to (i) reduce the use of commercial fertilizer
18 and (ii) incorporate innovative technology into farming practices,
19 including the proper use of biological nitrogen products.
20 (3) The program shall provide an annual per-acre incentive for any
21 farmer who verifies through documentation that commercial fertilizer
22 rates were reduced by the lesser of forty pounds per acre for nitrogen or
23 fifteen percent by incorporating a qualifying product in the farmer's
24 nutrient plans.
25 (4) A commercial fertilizer rate reduction from historic baseline
26 use shall be completed to qualify for the program.
27 (5) The department shall review the required commercial fertilizer
28 rate of reduction for the program on a biennial basis to determine if
29 higher reduction targets are necessary.
30 (6) The department shall:
31 (a) Collaborate with natural resources districts to add any new
-4-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 technology to the program as it becomes available. Such technology shall
2 replace nitrogen fertilizer use and maintain farm productivity;
3 (b) Identify geographically beneficial target areas while keeping
4 the program open to all farmers in the state;
5 (c) Consult with farmers and commercial entities in the agriculture
6 industry to determine a per-acre payment rate tied to the commercial
7 fertilizer rate reduction but not less than ten dollars per acre; and
8 (d) Review the per-acre payment rate based on inflation or emerging
9 technology in subsequent years.
10 (7)(a) The department shall not award an amount of incentive
11 payments in total per year under the nitrogen reduction incentive program
12 that is greater than the lesser of:
13 (i) Five million dollars; or
14 (ii) The amount appropriated for such purpose by the Legislature.
15 (b) It is the intent of the Legislature that any appropriation from
16 the General Fund to carry out the Nitrogen Reduction Incentive Act be
17 used only for operating expenses.
18 Sec. 9. Section 2-415, Revised Statutes Cumulative Supplement, 2024,
19 is amended to read:
20 2-415 The Department of Water, Energy, and Environment Natural
21 Resources may adopt and promulgate rules and regulations that adopt a
22 standard for labeled commercial fertilizer products to qualify for the
23 nitrogen reduction incentive program and may adopt and promulgate rules
24 and regulations to carry out the Nitrogen Reduction Incentive Act.
25 Sec. 10. Section 2-416, Revised Statutes Cumulative Supplement,
26 2024, is amended to read:
27 2-416 (1) The Nitrogen Reduction Incentive Cash Fund is created and
28 shall be administered by the Department of Water, Energy, and Environment
29 Natural Resources for purposes of the Nitrogen Reduction Incentive Act.
30 The Nitrogen Reduction Incentive Cash Fund may consist of transfers as
31 directed by the Legislature and gifts, grants, bequests, and money from
-5-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 any public or private source.
2 (2) The Department of Water, Energy, and Environment Natural
3 Resources may apply for all grants from state, federal, and private
4 sources that are applicable to the purposes of the Nitrogen Reduction
5 Incentive Act.
6 (3) Any such grant applied for by the Department of Water, Energy,
7 and Environment Natural Resources that is awarded to the Department of
8 Water, Energy, and Environment Natural Resources or the State of Nebraska
9 shall be credited to the Nitrogen Reduction Incentive Cash Fund.
10 (4) Any money in the fund available for investment shall be invested
11 by the state investment officer pursuant to the Nebraska Capital
12 Expansion Act and the Nebraska State Funds Investment Act.
13 Sec. 11. Section 2-969, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
14 amended to read:
15 2-969 The Riparian Vegetation Management Task Force is created. The
16 Governor shall appoint the members of the task force. The members shall
17 include one surface water project representative from each river basin
18 that has ever been determined to be fully appropriated pursuant to
19 section 46-714 or 46-720 or is designated as overappropriated pursuant to
20 section 46-713 by the Chief Water Officer Department of Natural
21 Resources; one surface water project representative from a river basin
22 that has not been determined to be fully appropriated pursuant to section
23 46-714 or 46-720 or is not designated as overappropriated pursuant to
24 section 46-713 by the Chief Water Officer Department of Natural
25 Resources; one representative from the Department of Agriculture, the
26 Department of Water, Energy, and Environment Environment and Energy, the
27 Department of Natural Resources, the office of the State Forester, the
28 Game and Parks Commission, and the University of Nebraska; three
29 representatives selected from a list of at least ten individuals
30 nominated by the Nebraska Association of Resources Districts; two
31 representatives selected from a list of at least five individuals
-6-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 nominated by the Nebraska Weed Control Association; one riparian
2 landowner from each of the state's congressional districts; and one
3 representative from the Nebraska Environmental Trust. In addition to such
4 members, any member of the Legislature may serve as a nonvoting, ex
5 officio member of the task force at his or her option. For administrative
6 and budgetary purposes only, the task force shall be housed within the
7 Department of Agriculture.
8 Sec. 12. Section 2-1501, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
9 amended to read:
10 2-1501 As used in sections 2-1501 to 2-15,123, unless the context
11 otherwise requires:
12 (1) Commission means the Nebraska Natural Resources Commission;
13 (2) State means the State of Nebraska;
14 (3) Agency of this state means the government of this state and any
15 subdivision, agency, or instrumentality, corporate or otherwise, of the
16 government of this state;
17 (4) United States or agencies of the United States means the United
18 States of America, the Natural Resources Conservation Service of the
19 United States Department of Agriculture, and any other agency or
20 instrumentality, corporate or otherwise, of the United States of America;
21 (5) Government or governmental means the government of this state,
22 the government of the United States, and any subdivision, agency, or
23 instrumentality, corporate or otherwise, of either of them;
24 (6) Lands, easements, and rights-of-way means lands and rights or
25 interests in lands whereon channel improvements, channel rectifications,
26 or water-retarding or gully-stabilization structures are located,
27 including those areas for flooding and flowage purposes, spoil areas,
28 borrow pits, access roads, and similar purposes;
29 (7) Local organization means any natural resources district,
30 drainage district, irrigation district, or other public district, county,
31 city, or state agency;
-7-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (8) Subwatershed means a portion of a watershed project as divided
2 by the department on a complete hydrologic unit;
3 (9) Rechanneling means the channeling of water from one watercourse
4 to another watercourse by means of open ditches;
5 (10) Watercourse means any depression two feet or more below the
6 surrounding land serving to give direction to a current of water at least
7 nine months of the year, having a bed and well-defined banks and, upon
8 order of the commission, also includes any particular depression which
9 would not otherwise be within the definition of watercourse;
10 (11) Chief Water Officer means the Chief Water Officer of the
11 Department of Water, Energy, and Environment Director means the Director
12 of Natural Resources;
13 (12) Department means the Department of Water, Energy, and
14 Environment Natural Resources; and
15 (13) Combined sewer overflow project means a municipal project to
16 reduce overflows from a combined sewer system pursuant to a long-term
17 control plan approved by the department Department of Environment and
18 Energy.
19 Sec. 13. Section 2-1504, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
20 amended to read:
21 2-1504 (1) The Nebraska Natural Resources Commission is established.
22 The commission shall advise the department as requested by the Chief
23 Water Officer director and shall perform such other functions as are
24 specifically conferred on the commission by law. The commission shall
25 have no jurisdiction over matters pertaining to water rights.
26 (2) Each member of the commission shall be a resident of the State
27 of Nebraska and shall have attained the age of majority. The voting
28 members of the commission shall be:
29 (a) One resident of each of the following river basins, with
30 delineations being those on the Nebraska river basin map officially
31 adopted by the commission and on file with the department: (i) The
-8-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 Niobrara River, White River, and Hat Creek basin, (ii) the North Platte
2 River basin, (iii) the South Platte River basin, (iv) the middle Platte
3 River basin, (v) the lower Platte River basin, (vi) the Loup River basin,
4 (vii) the Elkhorn River basin, (viii) the Missouri tributaries basin,
5 (ix) the Republican River basin, (x) the Little Blue River basin, (xi)
6 the Big Blue River basin, and (xii) the Nemaha River basin;
7 (b) One additional resident of each river basin which encompasses
8 one or more cities of the metropolitan class; and
9 (c) Fourteen members appointed by the Governor, subject to
10 confirmation by the Legislature. Of the members appointed by the
11 Governor, one shall represent each of the following categories:
12 Agribusiness interests; agricultural interests; ground water irrigators;
13 irrigation districts; manufacturing interests; metropolitan utilities
14 districts; municipal users of water from a city of the primary class;
15 municipal users of water from a city of the first or second class or a
16 village; outdoor recreation users; public power districts; public power
17 and irrigation districts; range livestock owners; surface water
18 irrigators; and wildlife conservation interests.
19 (3) Members of the commission described in subdivision (2)(a) of
20 this section shall be selected for four-year terms at individual caucuses
21 of the natural resources district directors residing in the river basin
22 from which the member is selected. Such caucuses shall be held for each
23 basin within ten days following the first Thursday after the first
24 Tuesday of the year the term of office of the member from that basin
25 expires. The dates and locations for such caucuses shall be established
26 by the commission, and the commission shall provide notice to the public
27 by issuing press releases for publication in a newspaper of general
28 circulation in each county that comprises the river basin for which a
29 caucus election will be held. Terms of office of such members shall
30 follow the sequence originally determined by the river basin
31 representatives to the commission at their first meeting on the third
-9-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 Thursday after the first Tuesday in January 1975. All river basin members
2 shall take office on the third Thursday after the first Tuesday in
3 January following their selection and any vacancy shall be filled for the
4 unexpired term by a caucus held within thirty days following the date
5 such vacancy is created. Each member of the commission representing a
6 river basin shall qualify by filing with the other members of the
7 commission an acceptance in writing of his or her selection.
8 (4) Members of the commission described in subdivision (2)(b) of
9 this section shall be residents of natural resources districts which
10 encompass one or more cities of the metropolitan class and shall be
11 selected in the same manner, at the same time, and for a four-year term
12 having the same term sequence as provided for the other members from such
13 basin under subsection (3) of this section.
14 (5) For members of the commission described in subdivision (2)(c) of
15 this section:
16 (a) The Governor shall appoint the eleven additional members added
17 by Laws 2014, LB1098, within thirty days after April 17, 2014. The eleven
18 additional appointments shall be for staggered four-year terms, as
19 determined by the Governor. The Governor shall also set the terms of the
20 current members of the commission appointed under such subdivision and
21 serving on April 17, 2014, to staggered four-year terms. Future
22 appointments shall be for four-year terms. Members whose terms have
23 expired shall continue to serve until their successors have been
24 appointed. In the case of a vacancy, the Governor shall appoint a
25 successor for the unexpired term. Members may be removed for cause.
26 Initial appointees shall begin serving immediately following notice of
27 appointment, except that the member appointed representing municipal
28 users of water from the class of city or a village that is being
29 represented by the current member representing municipal users of water
30 and the members representing surface water irrigators and ground water
31 irrigators shall not begin serving until the term of the current member
-10-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 representative of the category expires or such member resigns or is
2 otherwise removed; and
3 (b) In appointing such members, the Governor shall:
4 (i) Create a broad-based commission which has knowledge of, has
5 experience with, and is representative of Nebraska's water use and
6 economy;
7 (ii) Give recognition to the importance of both water quantity and
8 water quality; and
9 (iii) Appoint members who represent diverse geographic regions of
10 the state, including urban and rural areas, and represent, to the extent
11 possible, the racial and ethnic diversity of the state.
12 (6) After the members have been appointed as required under this
13 section, the commission shall revise or adopt and promulgate rules and
14 regulations as necessary to administer the Water Sustainability Fund
15 pursuant to sections 2-1506 to 2-1513.
16 Sec. 14. Section 2-1507, Revised Statutes Cumulative Supplement,
17 2024, is amended to read:
18 2-1507 (1) It is the intent of the Legislature that the Water
19 Sustainability Fund be equitably distributed statewide to the greatest
20 extent possible for the long term and give priority funding status to
21 projects which are the result of federal mandates.
22 (2) Distributions to assist municipalities with the cost of
23 constructing, upgrading, developing, and replacing sewer infrastructure
24 facilities as part of a combined sewer overflow project shall be based on
25 a demonstration of need and shall equal ten percent of the total annual
26 appropriation to the Water Sustainability Fund if (a) applicants have
27 applied for such funding as required under section 2-1509 and (b) any
28 such application has been recommended for further consideration by the
29 Chief Water Officer director and is subsequently approved for allocation
30 by the commission pursuant to subsection (1) of section 2-1511. If more
31 than one municipality demonstrates a need for funds pursuant to this
-11-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 subsection, funds shall be distributed proportionally based on
2 population.
3 (3) Any money in the Water Sustainability Fund may be allocated by
4 the commission to applicants in accordance with sections 2-1506 to
5 2-1513. Such money may be allocated in the form of grants or loans for
6 water sustainability programs, projects, or activities undertaken within
7 the state. The allocation of funds to a program, project, or activity in
8 one form shall not of itself preclude additional allocations in the same
9 or any other form to the same program, project, or activity. The
10 commission shall, when ranking and scoring applications for funding,
11 prioritize projects for drinking water improvements for any federally
12 recognized Indian tribe whose drinking water is under a no-drink order
13 from the United States Environmental Protection Agency.
14 (4) When the commission has approved an allocation of funds to a
15 program, project, or activity, the department Department of Natural
16 Resources shall establish a subaccount in the Water Sustainability Fund
17 and credit the entire amount of the allocation to the subaccount.
18 Individual subaccounts shall be established for each program, project, or
19 activity approved by the commission. The commission may approve a partial
20 allocation to a program, project, or activity based upon available
21 unallocated funds in the Water Sustainability Fund, but the amount of
22 unfunded allocations shall not exceed eleven million dollars. Additional
23 allocations to a program, project, or activity shall be credited to the
24 same subaccount as the original allocation. Subaccounts shall not be
25 subject to transfer out of the Water Sustainability Fund, except that the
26 commission may authorize the transfer of excess or unused funds from a
27 subaccount and into the unreserved balance of the fund.
28 (5) A natural resources district is eligible for funding from the
29 Water Sustainability Fund only if the district has adopted or is
30 currently participating in the development of an integrated management
31 plan pursuant to subdivision (1)(a) or (b) of section 46-715.
-12-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (6) The commission shall utilize the resources and expertise of and
2 collaborate with the department Department of Natural Resources, the
3 University of Nebraska, the Department of Environment and Energy, the
4 Nebraska Environmental Trust Board, and the Game and Parks Commission on
5 funding and planning for water programs, projects, or activities.
6 (7) A biennial report shall be made to the Clerk of the Legislature
7 describing the work accomplished by the use of funds towards the goals of
8 the Water Sustainability Fund beginning on December 31, 2015. The report
9 submitted to the Clerk of the Legislature shall be submitted
10 electronically.
11 Sec. 15. Section 2-1508, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
12 amended to read:
13 2-1508 The commission shall rank and score applications for funding
14 based on criteria that demonstrate the extent to which a program,
15 project, or activity:
16 (1) Remediates or mitigates threats to drinking water;
17 (2) Meets the goals and objectives of an approved integrated
18 management plan or ground water management plan;
19 (3) Contributes to water sustainability goals by increasing aquifer
20 recharge, reducing aquifer depletion, or increasing streamflow;
21 (4) Contributes to multiple water supply management goals,
22 including, but not limited to, flood control, agricultural use, municipal
23 and industrial uses, recreational benefits, wildlife habitat,
24 conservation of water resources, and preservation of water resources;
25 (5) Maximizes the beneficial use of Nebraska's water resources for
26 the benefit of the state's residents;
27 (6) Is cost-effective;
28 (7) Helps the state meet its obligations under interstate compacts,
29 decrees, or other state contracts or agreements or federal law;
30 (8) Reduces threats to property damage or protects critical
31 infrastructure that consists of the physical assets, systems, and
-13-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 networks vital to the state or the United States such that their
2 incapacitation would have a debilitating effect on public security or
3 public health and safety;
4 (9) Improves water quality;
5 (10) Has utilized all available funding resources of the local
6 jurisdiction to support the program, project, or activity;
7 (11) Has a local jurisdiction with plans in place that support
8 sustainable water use;
9 (12) Addresses a statewide problem or issue;
10 (13) Contributes to the state's ability to leverage state dollars
11 with local or federal government partners or other partners to maximize
12 the use of its resources; and
13 (14) Contributes to watershed health and function. ; and
14 (15) Uses objectives described in the annual report and plan of work
15 for the state water planning and review process issued by the department.
16 Sec. 16. Section 2-1509, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
17 amended to read:
18 2-1509 (1) Applicants for funds may file an application with the
19 department for a grant or loan from the Water Sustainability Fund.
20 Applications for grants to the department itself shall be filed by the
21 department. Each application shall be filed in such manner and form and
22 be accompanied by such information as may be prescribed by the Chief
23 Water Officer director and the commission.
24 (2) Any such application shall:
25 (a) Describe the nature and purpose of the proposed program,
26 project, or activity;
27 (b) Set forth or be accompanied by a plan for development of the
28 proposed program, project, or activity, together with engineering,
29 economic, and financial feasibility data and information, and such
30 estimated costs of construction or implementation as may be required by
31 the Chief Water Officer director and the commission;
-14-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (c) State whether money other than that for which the application is
2 made will be used to help in meeting program, project, or activity costs
3 and whether such money is available or has been sought for this purpose;
4 (d) When appropriate, state that the applicant holds or can acquire
5 title to all lands or has the necessary easements and rights-of-way for
6 the program, project, or activity and related lands and has or may
7 acquire all water rights necessary for the proposed program, project, or
8 activity;
9 (e) Show that the applicant possesses all necessary authority to
10 undertake or participate in the proposed program, project, or activity;
11 and
12 (f) Demonstrate the probable environmental and ecological
13 consequences that may result from such proposed program, project, or
14 activity.
15 (3) Upon receipt of an application, the Chief Water Officer director
16 shall evaluate and investigate all aspects of the proposed program,
17 project, or activity and the proposed schedule for development and
18 completion of such program, project, or activity, determine eligibility
19 for funding, and make appropriate recommendations to the commission
20 pursuant to sections 2-1506 to 2-1513. As a part of his or her
21 investigation, the Chief Water Officer director shall consider whether
22 the plan for development of the program, project, or activity is
23 satisfactory. If the Chief Water Officer director determines that the
24 plan is unsatisfactory or that the application does not contain adequate
25 information upon which to make determinations, the Chief Water Officer
26 director shall return the application to the applicant and may make such
27 recommendations to the applicant as are considered necessary to make the
28 plan or the application satisfactory.
29 (4) Requests for utilization of the Water Sustainability Fund for
30 state participation in any water and related land-water resources
31 projects shall also be filed with the department for the Chief Water
-15-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 Officer's director's evaluation, investigation, and recommendations. Such
2 requests shall be filed in the manner and form and be accompanied by such
3 information as shall be prescribed by the department and the commission.
4 Sec. 17. Section 2-1510, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
5 amended to read:
6 2-1510 (1) Each program, project, or activity for which funding is
7 requested, whether such request has as its origin an application or the
8 action of the department itself, shall be reviewed as provided in
9 sections 2-1506 to 2-1513 by the Chief Water Officer director prior to
10 the approval of any allocation for such program, project, or activity by
11 the commission.
12 (2) The Chief Water Officer director may recommend approval of and
13 the commission may approve grants or loans, including the appropriate
14 repayment period and the rate of interest, for program, project, or
15 activity costs or acquisition of interests in programs, projects, or
16 activities if after investigation and evaluation the Chief Water Officer
17 director finds that:
18 (a) The plan does not conflict with any existing Nebraska state land
19 plan;
20 (b) The proposed program, project, or activity is economically and
21 financially feasible based upon standards adopted by the commission
22 pursuant to sections 2-1506 to 2-1513;
23 (c) The plan for development of the proposed program, project, or
24 activity is satisfactory;
25 (d) The plan of development minimizes any adverse impacts on the
26 natural environment;
27 (e) The applicant is qualified, responsible, and legally capable of
28 carrying out the program, project, or activity;
29 (f) In the case of a loan, the borrower has demonstrated the ability
30 to repay the loan and there is assurance of adequate operation,
31 maintenance, and replacement during the repayment life of the program,
-16-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 project, or activity;
2 (g) The plan considers other plans and programs of the state and
3 resources development plans of the political subdivisions of the state;
4 and
5 (h) The money required from the Water Sustainability Fund is
6 available.
7 (3) The Chief Water Officer director and staff of the department
8 shall carry out their powers and duties under sections 2-1506 to 2-1513
9 independently of and without prejudice to their powers and duties under
10 other provisions of law.
11 (4) No member of the commission shall be eligible to participate in
12 the action of the commission concerning an application for funding to any
13 entity in which such commission member has any interest. The Chief Water
14 Officer director may be delegated additional responsibilities consistent
15 with the purposes of sections 2-1506 to 2-1513. It shall be the sole
16 responsibility of the commission to determine the priority in which funds
17 are allocated for eligible programs, projects, or activities under
18 section 2-1508.

1 (4) With the express approval of the commission, an applicant may

14 file a statement of the lien, its amount, terms, and a description of the
15 program, project, or activity with the register of deeds of each county

18 indexed as other liens are required by law to be indexed. The lien shall
19 be valid until paid in full or otherwise discharged. The lien shall be
20 foreclosed in accordance with applicable state law governing foreclosure
21 of mortgages and liens. Any lien provided for by this section may be
22 subordinate to that which secures federal assistance or other secured
23 assistance received on the same program, project, or activity.

10 Sec. 24. Section 2-2626, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
11 amended to read:
12 2-2626 The department shall have the following powers, functions,
13 and duties:
14 (1) To administer, implement, and enforce the Pesticide Act and
15 serve as the lead state agency for the regulation of pesticides. The
16 department shall involve the natural resources districts and other state
17 agencies, including the Department of Water, Energy, and Environment
18 Environment and Energy or the Department of Natural Resources, in matters
19 relating to water quality. Nothing in the act shall be interpreted in any
20 way to affect the powers of any other state agency or of any natural
21 resources district to regulate for ground water quality or surface water
22 quality as otherwise provided by law;
23 (2) To be responsible for the development and implementation of a
24 state management plan and pesticide management plans. The Department of
25 Water, Energy, and Environment Environment and Energy shall be
26 responsible for the adoption of standards for pesticides in surface
27 water, ground water, and drinking water. These standards shall be
28 established as action levels in the state management plan and pesticide
29 management plans at which prevention and mitigation measures are
30 implemented. Such action levels may be set at or below the maximum
31 contaminant level set for any product as set by the federal agency under
-26-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 the federal Safe Drinking Water Act, 42 U.S.C. 300f et seq., as the act
2 existed on January 1, 2021. The Department of Agriculture shall cooperate
3 with and use existing expertise in other state agencies when developing
4 the state management plan and pesticide management plans and shall not
5 hire a hydrologist within the department for such purpose;
6 (3) After notice and public hearing, to adopt and promulgate rules
7 and regulations providing lists of state-limited-use pesticides for the
8 entire state or for a designated area within the state, subject to the
9 following:
10 (a) A pesticide shall be included on a list of state-limited-use
11 pesticides if:
12 (i) The Department of Agriculture determines that the pesticide,
13 when used in accordance with its directions for use, warnings, and
14 cautions and for uses for which it is registered, may without additional
15 regulatory restrictions cause unreasonable adverse effects on humans or
16 the environment, including injury to the applicator or other persons
17 because of acute dermal or inhalation toxicity of the pesticides;
18 (ii) The water quality standards set by the Department of Water,
19 Energy, and Environment Environment and Energy pursuant to this section
20 are exceeded; or
21 (iii) The Department of Agriculture determines that the pesticide
22 requires additional restrictions to meet the requirements of the
23 Pesticide Act, the federal act, or any plan adopted under the Pesticide
24 Act or the federal act;
25 (b) The Department of Agriculture may regulate the specific time,
26 locations, and conditions restricting the use of a state-limited-use
27 pesticide, including allowable quantities or concentrations, and may
28 require that it be purchased or possessed only with permission or under
29 the direct supervision of the department or its designee;
30 (c) The Department of Agriculture may require a person authorized to
31 distribute or use a state-limited-use pesticide to maintain records of
-27-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 the person's distribution or use and may require that the records be kept

5 plans and with other state agencies and with natural resources districts;
6 (e) The state management plan and pesticide management plans may
7 impose progressively more rigorous pesticide management practices as
8 pesticides are detected in ground water or surface water at increasing
9 fractions of the standards adopted by the Department of Water, Energy,
10 and Environment Environment and Energy; and
11 (f) A pesticide management plan may impose progressively more
12 rigorous pesticide management practices to address any unreasonable
13 adverse effect of pesticides on humans or the environment. When
14 appropriate, a pesticide management plan may establish action levels for
15 imposition of such progressively more rigorous management practices based
16 upon measurable indicators of the adverse effect on humans or the
17 environment;
18 (4) To adopt and promulgate such rules and regulations as are

22 (a) The collection of samples, examination of records, and reporting

25 distribution, use, and disposal of pesticides and their containers;

31 (e) Reporting and record-keeping requirements for persons
-28-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 distributing or using pesticide products made available under 7 U.S.C.

3 the Pesticide Act;
4 (f) Methods to be used in the application of pesticides when the
5 Department of Agriculture finds that such regulations are necessary to
6 carry out the purpose and intent of the Pesticide Act. Such regulations
7 may include methods to be used in the application of a restricted-use
8 pesticide or state-limited-use pesticide, may relate to the time, place,
9 manner, methods, materials, amounts, and concentrations in connection
10 with the use of the pesticide, may restrict or prohibit use of the
11 pesticides in designated areas during specified periods of time, and may
12 provide specific examples and technical interpretations of subdivision
13 (4) of section 2-2646. The regulations shall encompass all reasonable
14 factors which the department deems necessary to prevent damage or injury
15 by drift or misapplication to (i) plants, including forage plants, or
16 adjacent or nearby property, (ii) wildlife in the adjoining or nearby
17 areas, (iii) fish and other aquatic life in waters in reasonable
18 proximity to the area to be treated, (iv) surface water or ground water,
19 and (v) humans, animals, or beneficial insects. In adopting and
20 promulgating such regulations, the department shall give consideration to
21 pertinent research findings and recommendations of other agencies of the
22 state, the federal government, or other reliable sources. The department
23 may, by regulation, require that notice of a proposed use of a pesticide

27 (g) State-limited-use pesticides for the state or for designated

-29-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 pesticide management plan;

4 regulations existed on January 1, 2019; and
5 (k) Establishment of a process for the issuance of permits for

7 federal act;
8 (5) To enter any public or private premises at any reasonable time
9 to:
10 (a) Inspect and sample any equipment authorized or required to be

15 (c) Inspect and sample any area where a pesticide is disposed of or
16 stored;
17 (d) Observe the use and application of and sample any pesticide;
18 (e) Inspect and copy any records relating to the distribution or use
19 of any pesticide or the issuance of any license, permit, or registration
20 under the act; or

23 person engaging in an activity regulated by the act if, from probable

-30-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 order to the owner or custodian of the pesticide. The person who receives

4 the act. This subdivision shall not limit the right of the department to
5 proceed as authorized by any other provision of the act;
6 (8)(a) To sue in the name of the director to enjoin any violation of
7 the act. Venue for such action shall be in the county in which the
8 alleged violation occurred, is occurring, or is threatening to occur; and
9 (b) To request the county attorney or the Attorney General to bring
10 suit to enjoin a violation or threatened violation of the act;

16 provision, requirement, condition, limitation, or duty imposed by the act

18 (10) To cause a violation warning letter to be served upon the

3 Sec. 25. Section 2-3202, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
4 amended to read:
5 2-3202 For purposes of Chapter 2, article 32, unless the context
6 otherwise requires:
7 (1) Commission means the Nebraska Natural Resources Commission;
8 (2) Natural resources district or district means a natural resources
9 district operating pursuant to Chapter 2, article 32;
10 (3) Board means the board of directors of a district;
11 (4) Director means a member of the board;
12 (5) Other special-purpose districts means rural water districts,
13 drainage districts, reclamation districts, and irrigation districts;
14 (6) Manager means the chief executive hired by a majority vote of
15 the board to be the supervising officer of the district; and
16 (7) Department means the Department of Water, Energy, and
17 Environment Natural Resources.

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 assessed upon real estate, shall become a lien upon such real estate

4 taxes are levied.
5 (3) When the special project would not result in the provision of
6 revenue-producing continuing services, the board shall apportion the
7 benefits thereof accruing to the several tracts of land within the
8 district which will be benefited thereby, on a system of units. The land
9 least benefited shall be apportioned one unit of assessment, and each
10 tract receiving a greater benefit shall be apportioned a greater number
11 of units or fraction thereof, according to the benefits received. Nothing
12 contained in this section shall prevent the district from establishing
13 separate areas within the improvement project area so as to permit future
14 allocation of costs for particular portions of the work to specific
15 subareas. This subarea method of allocation shall not be used in any
16 improvement project area which has heretofore made a final apportionment
17 of units of benefits and shall not thereafter be changed except by
18 compliance with the procedure prescribed in this section.

1 cost per benefit unit thereof. Thereupon the board of directors shall

LB317 LB317

1 the original apportionment of benefits as a basis to ascertain the

10 estate taxes, and such assessments shall be and remain a perpetual lien
11 against such real estate until paid. All provisions of law for the sale,
12 redemption, and foreclosure in ordinary tax matters shall apply to such
13 special assessments.

4 Sec. 31. Section 2-4602, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
5 amended to read:
6 2-4602 The Legislature recognizes that erosion and sedimentation are
7 serious problems throughout the state. Changes in farm and ranch
8 enterprises, operations, and ownership, demands made upon farm and ranch
9 enterprises which do not encourage sound resource utilization, rapid
10 shifts in land use from agricultural and rural to nonagricultural and
11 urban uses, construction of streets, highways, pipelines, recreation
12 areas, schools and universities, public utilities and facilities,
13 conversion of grasslands to croplands, and other land-disturbing
14 activities have caused excessive wind erosion and water runoff and
15 accelerated the process of soil erosion and sediment deposition. This has
16 resulted in the pollution of the waters of the state and damage to
17 domestic, agricultural, industrial, recreational, fish and wildlife, and
18 other resources. It is declared to be the policy of the state to
19 strengthen and extend the present erosion and sediment control activities
20 and programs of the state for both rural and urban lands, to improve
21 water quality, and to establish and implement, through the Director of
22 Water, Energy, and Environment Natural Resources and the Nebraska Natural
23 Resources Commission, a statewide, comprehensive, and coordinated erosion
24 and sediment control program to reduce damage from wind erosion and storm
25 water runoff, to retard nonpoint pollution from sediment and related
26 pollutants, and to conserve and protect land, air, and other resources of
27 the state. This program shall be carried out by the natural resources
28 districts in cooperation with the counties, municipalities, and other
29 local governments and political subdivisions of the state and other
30 public and private entities.
31 Sec. 32. Section 2-4603, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
-41-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 amended to read:
2 2-4603 For purposes of the Erosion and Sediment Control Act, unless
3 the context otherwise requires:
4 (1) Commission means the Nebraska Natural Resources Commission;
5 (2) Conservation agreement means an agreement between the owner or
6 operator of a farm unit and the district in which the owner or operator
7 agrees to implement a farm unit conservation plan or, with the approval
8 of the district within which the farm unit is located, a portion of a
9 farm unit conservation plan. The agreement shall include a schedule for
10 implementation and may be conditioned on the district or other public
11 entity furnishing technical, planning, or financial assistance in the
12 establishment of the soil and water conservation practices necessary to
13 implement the plan or a portion of the plan;
14 (3) Director means the Director of Water, Energy, and Environment
15 Natural Resources;
16 (4) District means a natural resources district;
17 (5) Erosion or sediment control practice means:
18 (a) The construction or installation and maintenance of permanent
19 structures or devices necessary to carry, to a suitable outlet away from
20 any building site, any commercial or industrial development, or any
21 publicly or privately owned recreational or service facility not served
22 by a central storm sewer system, any water which would otherwise cause
23 erosion in excess of the applicable soil-loss tolerance level and which
24 does not carry or constitute sewage or industrial or other waste;
25 (b) The employment of temporary devices or structures, temporary
26 seeding, fiber mats, plastic, straw, diversions, silt fences, sediment
27 traps, or other measures adequate either to prevent erosion in excess of
28 the applicable soil-loss tolerance level or to prevent excessive
29 downstream sedimentation from land which is the site of or is directly
30 affected by any nonagricultural land-disturbing activity; or
31 (c) The establishment and maintenance of vegetation upon the right-
-42-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 of-way of any completed portion of any public street, road, or highway or
2 the construction or installation thereon of permanent structures or
3 devices or other measures adequate to prevent erosion of the right-of-way
4 in excess of the applicable soil-loss tolerance level;
5 (6) Excess erosion means the occurrence of erosion in excess of the
6 applicable soil-loss tolerance level which causes or contributes to an
7 accumulation of sediment upon the lands of any other person to the
8 detriment or damage of such other person;
9 (7) Farm unit conservation plan means a plan jointly developed by
10 the owner and, if appropriate, the operator of a farm unit and the
11 district within which the farm unit is located based upon the determined
12 conservation needs for the farm unit and identifying the soil and water
13 conservation practices which may be expected to prevent soil loss by
14 erosion from that farm unit in excess of the applicable soil-loss
15 tolerance level. The plan may also, if practicable, identify alternative
16 practices by which such objective may be attained;
17 (8) Nonagricultural land-disturbing activity means a land change,
18 including, but not limited to, tilling, clearing, grading, excavating,
19 transporting, or filling land, which may result in soil erosion from wind
20 or water and the movement of sediment and sediment-related pollutants
21 into the waters of the state or onto lands in the state but does not
22 include the following:
23 (a) Activities related directly to the production of agricultural,
24 horticultural, or silvicultural crops, including, but not limited to,
25 tilling, planting, or harvesting of such crops;
26 (b) Installation of aboveground public utility lines and
27 connections, fenceposts, sign posts, telephone poles, electric poles, and
28 other kinds of posts or poles;
29 (c) Emergency work to protect life or property;
30 (d) Activities related to the construction of housing, industrial,
31 and commercial developments on sites under two acres in size; and
-43-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (e) Activities related to the operation, construction, or
2 maintenance of industrial or commercial public power district or public
3 power and irrigation district facilities or sites when such activity is
4 conducted pursuant to state or federal law or is part of the operational
5 plan for such facility or site;
6 (9) Person means any individual, partnership, limited liability
7 company, firm, association, joint venture, public or private corporation,
8 trust, estate, commission, board, institution, utility, cooperative,
9 municipality or other political subdivision of this state, interstate
10 body, or other legal entity;
11 (10) Soil and water conservation practice means a practice which
12 serves to prevent erosion of soil by wind or water in excess of the
13 applicable soil-loss tolerance level from land used only for
14 agricultural, horticultural, or silvicultural purposes. Soil and water
15 conservation practice includes, but is not limited to:
16 (a) Permanent soil and water conservation practice, including the
17 planting of perennial grasses, legumes, shrubs, or trees, the
18 establishment of grassed waterways, the construction of terraces, and
19 other permanent soil and water practices approved by the district; and
20 (b) Temporary soil and water conservation practice, including the
21 planting of annual or biennial crops, use of strip-cropping, contour
22 planting, minimum or mulch tillage, and other cultural practices approved
23 by the district; and
24 (11) Soil-loss tolerance level means the maximum amount of soil loss
25 due to erosion by wind or water, expressed in terms of tons per acre per
26 year, which is determined to be acceptable in accordance with the Erosion
27 and Sediment Control Act. Soil loss may be impacted by water erosion
28 which may include (a) sheet and rill erosion which includes relatively
29 uniform soil loss across the entire field slope which may leave small
30 channels located at regular intervals across the slope and (b) ephemeral
31 gully erosion which occurs in well-defined depressions or natural
-44-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 drainageways where concentrated overland flow results in the convergence
2 of rills forming deeper and wider channels.
3 Sec. 33. Section 2-4604, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
4 amended to read:
5 2-4604 (1) The director shall, in cooperation with the commission,
6 the Department of Environment and Energy, the Natural Resources
7 Conservation Service of the United States Department of Agriculture, and
8 other appropriate state and federal agencies, develop and coordinate a
9 comprehensive state erosion and sediment control program designed to
10 reduce soil erosion in this state to tolerable levels. The program, which
11 shall be reasonable and attainable, shall include:
12 (a) The soil-loss tolerance level for the various types of soils in
13 the state;
14 (b) State goals and a state strategy for reducing soil losses on all
15 lands in the state to an amount no more than the applicable soil-loss
16 tolerance level;
17 (c) Guidelines for establishing priorities for implementation of the
18 program at the state and local levels;
19 (d) Types of assistance to be provided by the state to districts,
20 cities, and counties in the implementation of the state and local erosion
21 and sediment control programs; and
22 (e) Such other elements as the director deems appropriate in
23 accordance with the objectives of the Erosion and Sediment Control Act,
24 including any recommendations for further legislative or administrative
25 action.
26 (2) The state erosion and sediment control program may be revised by
27 the director and the commission at any time. Before approving any such
28 changes, the director and the commission shall conduct at least four
29 public hearings or meetings to receive information from interested
30 persons in different parts of the state.

5 (3) A municipality or county shall file a report complying with the
6 rules and regulations adopted pursuant to this section with the
7 Department of Water, Energy, and Environment Department of Environment
8 and Energy before April 1 of each year documenting purchasing practices
9 for the past calendar year in order to continue receiving the rebate. The
10 report shall include, but not be limited to, quantities of products,
11 materials, or supplies purchased which were manufactured or produced from
12 recycled material. The department shall provide copies of each report to
13 the materiel division in a timely manner. If the department determines
14 that a municipality or county is not following the purchasing policy
15 presented in the approved application or that the purchasing policy
16 presented in the approved application is not effective in assuring that a
17 preference is given to products, materials, or supplies which are
18 manufactured or produced from recycled material, the department shall
19 suspend the rebate until it determines that the municipality or county is
20 giving a preference to products, materials, or supplies which are
21 manufactured or produced from recycled material pursuant to a written
22 purchasing policy approved by the department subsequent to the
23 suspension. The materiel division may make recommendations to the
24 department regarding suspensions and reinstatements of rebates. The
25 Department of Administrative Services may adopt and promulgate rules and
26 regulations establishing procedures for reviewing applications and for
27 annual reports.
28 (4) Any suspension of the rebate or denial of an application made
29 under this section may be appealed. The appeal shall be in accordance
30 with the Administrative Procedure Act.
31 (5) The council shall adopt and promulgate rules and regulations
-49-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 establishing criteria for application procedures, for accepting and
2 denying applications, for required reports, and for suspending and
3 reinstating the rebate. The materiel division shall recommend to the
4 council criteria for accepting and denying applications and for
5 suspending and reinstating the rebate. The materiel division may make
6 other recommendations to the council regarding rules and regulations
7 authorized under this section.

7 Sec. 40. Section 19-1201, Revised Statutes Cumulative Supplement,
8 2024, is amended to read:
9 19-1201 (1) There is hereby established the Revitalize Rural
10 Nebraska Grant Program. The governing body of a city of the first class,
11 a city of the second class, or a village may apply, on behalf of the city
12 or village, to the Department of Water, Energy, and Environment
13 Environment and Energy for approval of a dilapidated commercial property
14 demolition grant. The Director of Water, Energy, and Environment
15 Environment and Energy shall prescribe the form and manner of
16 application.
17 (2) The department shall award the grants annually on a competitive
18 basis beginning in fiscal year 2023-24 subject to available funds. The
19 department shall give priority to applications from cities of the second
20 class and villages. If there are funds remaining at the end of each grant
21 period, the department shall consider applications from cities of the
22 first class. A city or village may apply for more than one grant. The
23 department shall give preference to new applicants.
24 (3) There shall be no limit on the amount that can be awarded to
25 each applicant within the available funding. It is the intent of the
26 Legislature that if the department does not award all of the available
27 appropriation for grants under the program, the unobligated amount of the
28 appropriation shall be reappropriated for the next fiscal year to be
29 awarded during the next grant period.

1 the action or at any time afterward before judgment by the Court of

13 notice to the adverse party or his or her attorney only if (a) it clearly
14 appears from specific facts shown by affidavit that immediate and
15 irreparable injury, loss, or damage will result to the applicant before
16 the adverse party or his or her attorney can be heard in opposition and
17 (b) the applicant or his or her attorney certifies to the court in
18 writing the efforts, if any, which have been made to give such notice and
19 the reasons supporting the applicant's claim that such notice shall not
20 be required.
21 Every temporary restraining order granted without notice shall: (i)
22 Be endorsed with the date and hour of issuance; (ii) be filed immediately
23 in the office of the clerk of the district court and entered of record;
24 (iii) define the injury and state why the injury is irreparable and why
25 the order was granted without notice; and (iv) expire by its terms within
26 such time after entry, not to exceed ten days, as the court fixes unless
27 within such fixed time period the order, for good cause shown, is

31 order is granted without notice, the motion for a temporary injunction
-54-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 shall be heard at the earliest possible time in the district court and
2 shall take precedence over all matters except older matters of the same
3 character. When the motion for a temporary injunction comes up for
4 hearing, the party who obtained the temporary restraining order shall
5 proceed with the application for a temporary injunction, and if he or she
6 does not do so, the district court shall dissolve the temporary
7 restraining order. On two days' notice to the party who obtained the
8 temporary restraining order without notice or on such shorter notice to
9 such party as the district court may prescribe, the adverse party may
10 appear and move for the dissolution or modification of the order, and in
11 that event, the court shall proceed to hear and determine such motion as
12 expeditiously as the ends of justice require.

23 person or by their attorney or attorneys, on the question of whether the
24 restraining order should be granted and, if so, in what amount the bond
25 or undertaking is to be fixed.
26 (6) Any person, natural or artificial, injured or likely to be
27 injured by the granting of a restraining order may intervene in the
28 action at any stage of the proceedings and become a party to the
29 litigation if it involves the delivery of irrigation water and the Chief
30 Water Officer director is a party.

7 Sec. 59. Section 37-806, Revised Statutes Cumulative Supplement,
8 2024, is amended to read:
9 37-806 (1)(a) Any species of wildlife or wild plants determined to

24 by adopting and promulgating rules and regulations, determine whether any
25 species of wildlife or wild plants normally occurring within this state
26 is an endangered or threatened species as a result of any of the
27 following factors:
28 (a) The present or threatened destruction, modification, or
29 curtailment of its habitat or range;
30 (b) Overutilization for commercial, recreational, scientific,
31 educational, or other purposes;
-64-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (c) Disease or predation;
2 (d) The inadequacy of existing regulatory mechanisms; or
3 (e) Other natural or manmade factors affecting its continued
4 existence within this state.
5 (3)(a) The commission shall make determinations required by
6 subsection (2) of this section on the basis of the best scientific,
7 commercial, and other data available to the commission.
8 (b) Except with respect to species of wildlife or wild plants
9 determined to be endangered or threatened species under subsection (1) of
10 this section, the commission shall not add a species to nor remove a
11 species from any list published pursuant to subsection (5) of this
12 section unless the commission has first:
13 (i) Provided public notice of such proposed action by publication in
14 a newspaper of general circulation in each county in that portion of the
15 subject species' range in which it is endangered or threatened or, if the
16 subject species' range extends over more than five counties, in a
17 newspaper of statewide circulation distributed in the county;
18 (ii) Provided notice of such proposed action to and allowed comment
19 from the Department of Agriculture, the Department of Water, Energy, and
20 Environment Environment and Energy, the Department of Natural Resources,
21 and any other state agency that the commission determines might be
22 impacted by the proposed action;
23 (iii) Provided notice of such proposed action to and allowed comment
24 from each natural resources district and public power district located in
25 that portion of the subject species' range in which it is endangered or
26 threatened;
27 (iv) Notified the Governor of any state sharing a common border with
28 this state, in which the subject species is known to occur, that such
29 action is being proposed;
30 (v) Allowed at least sixty days following publication for comment
31 from the public and other interested parties;
-65-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (vi) Held at least one public hearing on such proposed action in
2 each game and parks commissioner district of the subject species' range
3 in which it is endangered or threatened;
4 (vii) Submitted the scientific, commercial, and other data that is
5 the basis of the proposed action to scientists or experts outside and
6 independent of the commission for peer review of the data and
7 conclusions. If the commission submits the data to a state or federal
8 fish and wildlife agency for peer review, the commission shall also
9 submit the data to scientists or experts not affiliated with such an
10 agency for review. For purposes of this section, state fish and wildlife
11 agency does not include a postsecondary educational institution; and
12 (viii) For species proposed to be added under this subsection but
13 not for species proposed to be removed under this subsection, developed
14 an outline of the potential impacts, requirements, or rules and
15 regulations that may be placed on private landowners, or on other persons
16 who hold state-recognized property rights on behalf of themselves or
17 others, as a result of the listing of the species or the development of a
18 proposed program for the conservation of the species as required in
19 subsection (1) of section 37-807.
20 (c) The inadvertent failure to provide notice as required by
21 subdivision (3)(b) of this section shall not prohibit the listing of a
22 species and shall not be deemed to be a violation of the Administrative
23 Procedure Act or the Nongame and Endangered Species Conservation Act.
24 (d) When the commission proposes to add or remove a species under
25 this subsection, public notice under subdivision (3)(b)(i) of this
26 section shall include, but not be limited to, (i) the species proposed to
27 be listed and a description of that portion of its range in which the
28 species is endangered or threatened, (ii) a declaration that the
29 commission submitted the data that is the basis for the listing for peer
30 review and developed an outline if required under subdivision (b)(viii)
31 of this subsection, and (iii) a declaration of the availability of the
-66-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 peer review, including an explanation of any changes or modifications the
2 commission has made to its proposal as a result of the peer review, and
3 the outline required under subdivision (b)(viii) of this subsection, if
4 applicable, for public examination.
5 (e) In cases when the commission determines that an emergency
6 situation exists involving the continued existence of such species as a
7 viable component of the wild fauna or flora of the state, the commission
8 may add species to such lists after first publishing public notice that
9 such an emergency situation exists together with a summary of facts that
10 support such determination.
11 (4) In determining whether any species of wildlife or wild plants is
12 an endangered or threatened species, the commission shall take into
13 consideration those actions being carried out by the federal government,
14 by other states, by other agencies of this state or its political
15 subdivisions, or by any other person which may affect the species under
16 consideration.
17 (5) The commission shall adopt and promulgate rules and regulations
18 containing a list of all species of wildlife and wild plants normally
19 occurring within this state that it determines, in accordance with
20 subsections (1) through (4) of this section, to be endangered or
21 threatened species and a list of all such species. Each list shall refer
22 to the species contained in such list by scientific and common name or
23 names, if any, and shall specify with respect to each such species over
24 what portion of its range it is endangered or threatened.
25 (6) Except with respect to species of wildlife or wild plants
26 determined to be endangered or threatened pursuant to the Endangered
27 Species Act, the commission shall, upon the petition of an interested
28 person, conduct a review of any listed or unlisted species proposed to be
29 removed from or added to the lists published pursuant to subsection (5)
30 of this section, but only if the commission publishes a public notice
31 that such person has presented substantial evidence that warrants such a
-67-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 review.
2 (7) Whenever any species of wildlife or wild plants is listed as a
3 threatened species pursuant to subsection (5) of this section, the
4 commission shall issue such rules and regulations as are necessary to
5 provide for the conservation of such species. The commission may
6 prohibit, with respect to any threatened species of wildlife or wild
7 plants, any act prohibited under subsection (8) or (9) of this section.
8 (8) With respect to any endangered species of wildlife, it shall be
9 unlawful, except as provided in subsection (7) of this section or section
10 37-807, for any person subject to the jurisdiction of this state to:
11 (a) Export any such species from this state;
12 (b) Take any such species within this state;
13 (c) Possess, process, sell or offer for sale, deliver, carry,
14 transport, or ship, by any means whatsoever except as a common or
15 contract motor carrier under the jurisdiction of the Public Service
16 Commission or the federal Surface Transportation Board, any such species;
17 or
18 (d) Violate any rule or regulation pertaining to the conservation of
19 such species or to any threatened species of wildlife listed pursuant to
20 this section and adopted and promulgated by the commission pursuant to
21 the Nongame and Endangered Species Conservation Act.
22 (9) With respect to any endangered species of wild plants, it shall
23 be unlawful, except as provided in subsection (7) of this section, for
24 any person subject to the jurisdiction of this state to:
25 (a) Export any such species from this state;
26 (b) Possess, process, sell or offer for sale, deliver, carry,
27 transport, or ship, by any means whatsoever, any such species; or
28 (c) Violate any rule or regulation pertaining to such species or to
29 any threatened species of wild plants listed pursuant to this section and
30 adopted and promulgated by the commission pursuant to the act.
31 (10) Any endangered species of wildlife or wild plants that enters
-68-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 this state from another state or from a point outside the territorial
2 limits of the United States and that is being transported to a point
3 within or beyond this state may be so entered and transported without
4 restriction in accordance with the terms of any federal permit or permit
5 issued under the laws or regulations of another state.
6 (11) The commission may permit any act otherwise prohibited by
7 subsection (8) of this section for scientific purposes or to enhance the
8 propagation or survival of the affected species.
9 (12) Any law, rule, regulation, or ordinance of any political
10 subdivision of this state that applies with respect to the taking,
11 importation, exportation, possession, sale or offer for sale, processing,
12 delivery, carrying, transportation other than under the jurisdiction of
13 the Public Service Commission, or shipment of species determined to be
14 endangered or threatened species pursuant to the Nongame and Endangered
15 Species Conservation Act shall be void to the extent that it may
16 effectively (a) permit that which is prohibited by the act or by any rule
17 or regulation that implements the act or (b) prohibit that which is
18 authorized pursuant to an exemption or permit provided for in the act or
19 in any rule or regulation that implements the act. The Nongame and
20 Endangered Species Conservation Act shall not otherwise be construed to
21 void any law, rule, regulation, or ordinance of any political subdivision
22 of this state which is intended to conserve wildlife or wild plants.

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 46-122 (1) It is hereby expressly provided that all water
2 distributed for irrigation purposes shall attach to and follow the tract
3 of land to which it is applied unless a change of location has been
4 approved by the board of directors pursuant to sections 46-2,127 to
5 46-2,129 or by the Chief Water Officer Department of Natural Resources
6 pursuant to section 46-294 or sections 46-2,122 to 46-2,126.

8 provide for the suspension of water delivery to any land in such district
9 upon which the irrigation taxes levied and assessed thereon shall remain
10 due and unpaid for two years. It shall be the duty of the directors to
11 make all necessary arrangements for right-of-way for laterals from the
12 main canal to each tract of land subject to assessment, and when
13 necessary the board shall exercise its right of eminent domain to procure
14 right-of-way for the laterals and shall make such rules in regard to the

17 not adequate to be beneficially used when equitably apportioned to all
18 landowners in the district, the board may, after providing notice to
19 landowners in a portion of the district and upon receiving no objections
20 from the majority of such landowners, elect not to deliver water to that
21 portion of the district. Such election shall not subject the district to
22 liability under section 46-160 and shall not affect the rights of
23 landowners in that portion of the district to water deliveries in the
24 future. Any election to not deliver water to a portion of the district
25 shall be made on a year-to-year basis, not to exceed ten years, and such
26 election shall not subject any landowner to adjudication of his or her
27 water right under section 46-229. The board may adjust the tolls or
28 charges made to landowners within the district to reflect the decrease in
29 supply to those landowners in the portion of the district not receiving
30 water pursuant to such election by the board.

28 if the Chief Water Officer director determines that the change is in the
29 public interest, and that any interference with the rights of senior
30 appropriators as a result of such change is unavoidable and not material;
31 (c) The priority date shall remain the same as that of the original
-80-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 appropriation; and
2 (d) When the application is for recognition of incidental
3 underground water storage, such stored water is being withdrawn or is
4 otherwise being used for beneficial purposes.
5 (2) For an application filed pursuant to section 46-226.01, the
6 burden shall be on the applicant to prove that underground water storage
7 has occurred.
8 (3) The Chief Water Officer director may grant the application in a
9 modified or reduced form, if required by the public interest, and may
10 impose such other reasonable conditions as deemed appropriate to protect
11 the public interest.
12 (4) The Chief Water Officer's director's order of approval shall
13 specify:
14 (a) The source of the water stored or to be stored underground;
15 (b) The underground water storage method; and
16 (c) A description of the area served or to be served by the water
17 stored underground.
18 Sec. 74. Section 46-226.03, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
19 amended to read:
20 46-226.03 For purposes of sections 46-226 to 46-243:
21 (1) Chief Water Officer means the Chief Water Officer of the
22 Department of Water, Energy, and Environment;

24 Environment Natural Resources;
25 (2) Director means the Director of Natural Resources;
26 (3) Incidental underground water storage has the same meaning as in
27 section 46-296;
28 (4) Induced ground water recharge means the process by which ground
29 water withdrawn from wells near a natural stream is replaced by surface
30 water flowing in the stream;
31 (5) Intentional underground water storage has the same meaning as in
-81-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 section 46-296;

4 natural resources district, irrigation district, reclamation district, or
5 sanitary and improvement district which supplies or intends to supply
6 water to inhabitants of cities, villages, or rural areas for domestic or
7 municipal purposes;
8 (7) Underground water storage has the same meaning as in section
9 46-296; and
10 (8) Well means a well, subsurface collector, or other artificial
11 opening or excavation in the ground from which ground water flows under
12 natural pressure or is artificially withdrawn.
