23 Sec. 80. Section 46-229.04, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
24 amended to read:
25 46-229.04 (1) At a hearing held pursuant to section 46-229.03, the
26 verified field investigation report of an employee of the department, or
27 such other report or information that is relied upon by the Chief Water
28 Officer department to reach the preliminary determination of nonuse,
29 shall be prima facie evidence for the forfeiture and annulment of such
30 water appropriation. If no person appears at the hearing, such water
31 appropriation or unused part thereof shall be declared forfeited and
-87-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 annulled. If an interested person appears and contests the same, the
2 Chief Water Officer department shall hear evidence, and if it appears
3 that such water has not been put to a beneficial use or has ceased to be
4 used for such purpose for more than five consecutive years, the same
5 shall be declared canceled and annulled unless the Chief Water Officer
6 department finds that (a) there has been sufficient cause for such nonuse
7 as provided for in subsection (2), (3), or (4) of this section or (b)
8 subsection (5) or (6) of this section applies.
9 (2) Sufficient cause for nonuse shall be deemed to exist for up to
10 thirty consecutive years if:
11 (a) Such nonuse was caused by the unavailability of water for that
12 use. For a river basin, subbasin, or reach that has been designated as
13 overappropriated pursuant to section 46-713 or determined by the Chief
14 Water Officer department to be fully appropriated pursuant to section
15 46-714, the period of time within which sufficient cause for nonuse
16 because of the unavailability of water may be deemed to exist may be
17 extended beyond thirty years by the Chief Water Officer department upon
18 petition therefor by the owner of the appropriation if the Chief Water
19 Officer department determines that an integrated management plan being
20 implemented in the river basin, subbasin, or reach involved is likely to
21 result in restoration of a usable water supply for the appropriation; or
22 (b) The land subject to the appropriation is under an acreage
23 reserve program or production quota or is otherwise withdrawn from use as
24 required for participation in any federal, state, or natural resources
25 district program, or such land was previously under such a program but
26 currently is not under such a program and there have been not more than
27 five consecutive years of nonuse on such land subsequent to when that
28 land was last under such program.
29 (3) Sufficient cause for nonuse shall be deemed to exist
30 indefinitely if such nonuse was the result of one or more of the
31 following:
-88-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (a) For any tract of land under separate ownership, the available
2 supply was used but on only part of the land under the appropriation
3 because of an inadequate water supply;
4 (b) The appropriation is a storage appropriation and there was an
5 inadequate water supply to provide the water for the storage
6 appropriation or less than the full amount of the storage appropriation
7 was needed to keep the reservoir full; or
8 (c) The appropriation is a storage-use appropriation and there was
9 an inadequate water supply to provide the water for the appropriation or
10 use of the storage water was unnecessary because of climatic conditions.
11 (4) Sufficient cause for nonuse shall be deemed to exist for up to
12 fifteen consecutive years if such nonuse was a result of one or more of
13 the following:
14 (a) Federal, state, or local laws, rules, or regulations temporarily
15 prevented or restricted such use;
16 (b) Use of the water was unnecessary because of climatic conditions;
17 (c) Circumstances were such that a prudent person, following the
18 principles of good husbandry, would not have been expected to use the
19 water;
20 (d) The works, diversions, or other facilities essential to use the
21 water were destroyed by a cause not within the control of the owner of
22 the appropriation and good faith efforts to repair or replace the works,
23 diversions, or facilities have been and are being made;
24 (e) The owner of the appropriation was in active involuntary service
25 in the armed forces of the United States or was in active voluntary
26 service during a time of crisis; or
27 (f) Legal proceedings prevented or restricted use of the water.
28 The Chief Water Officer department may specify by rule and
29 regulation other circumstances that shall be deemed to constitute
30 sufficient cause for nonuse for up to fifteen years.
31 (5) When an appropriation is held in the name of an irrigation
-89-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 district, a reclamation district, a public power and irrigation district,
2 a mutual irrigation company or canal company, or the United States Bureau
3 of Reclamation and the Chief Water Officer director determines that water
4 under that appropriation has not been used on a specific parcel of land
5 for more than five years and that no sufficient cause for such nonuse
6 exists, the right to use water under that appropriation on that parcel
7 shall be terminated and notice of the termination shall be posted on the
8 department's website and shall be given in the manner provided in
9 subsection (2), (3), or (4) of section 46-229.03. The district or company
10 holding such right shall have five years after the determination, or five
11 years after an order of cancellation issued by the Chief Water Officer
12 department following the filing of a voluntary relinquishment of the
13 water appropriation that has been signed by the landowner and the
14 appropriator of record, to assign the right to use that portion of the
15 appropriation to other land within the district or the area served by the
16 company, to file an application for a transfer in accordance with section
17 46-290, or to transfer the right in accordance with sections 46-2,127 to
18 46-2,129. The Chief Water Officer department shall issue the its order of
19 cancellation within sixty days after receipt of the voluntary
20 relinquishment unless the relinquishment is conditioned by the landowner
21 upon an action of a governmental agency. If the relinquishment contains
22 such a provision, the Chief Water Officer department shall issue the its
23 order of cancellation within sixty days after receipt of notification
24 that such action has been completed. The Chief Water Officer department
25 shall be notified of any such assignment within thirty days after such
26 assignment. If the district or company does not assign the right to use
27 that portion of the appropriation to other land, does not file an
28 application for a transfer within the five-year period, or does not
29 notify the Chief Water Officer department within thirty days after any
30 such assignment, that portion of the appropriation shall be canceled
31 without further proceedings by the Chief Water Officer department and the

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 district or company involved shall be so notified by the Chief Water
2 Officer department. During the time within which assignment of a portion

4 appropriation involved shall be reduced, as necessary, to avoid
5 inconsistency with the rate allowed by section 46-231 or with any greater
6 rate previously approved for such appropriation by the Chief Water
7 Officer director in accordance with section 46-229.06.
8 (6) When it is determined by the Chief Water Officer director that
9 an appropriation, for which the location of use has been temporarily
10 transferred in accordance with sections 46-290 to 46-294, has not been
11 used at the new location for more than five years and that no sufficient
12 cause for such nonuse exists, the right to use that appropriation at the
13 temporary location of use shall be terminated. Notice of that termination
14 shall be posted on the department's website and shall be given in the
15 manner provided in subsection (2), (3), or (4) of section 46-229.03. The
16 right to reinitiate use of that appropriation at the location of use
17 prior to the temporary transfer shall continue to exist for five years
18 after the Chief Water Officer's director's determination, but if such use
19 is not reinitiated at that location within such five-year period, the

22 (7) If at the time of a hearing conducted in accordance with
23 subsection (1) of this section there is an application for incidental or
24 intentional underground water storage pending before the Chief Water
25 Officer department and filed by the owner of the appropriation, the

7 would result in an authorized diversion rate less than the rate

21 Sec. 84. Section 46-231, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
22 amended to read:
23 46-231 Each appropriation shall be determined in its priority and
24 amount by the time at which it is made and the amount of water which the
25 works are constructed to carry. An appropriator shall at no time be
26 entitled to the use of more than he or she can beneficially use for the
27 purposes for which the appropriation has been made, and the amount of any
28 appropriation made by means of enlargement of the distributing works
29 shall be determined in like manner.
30 An allotment from the natural flow of streams for irrigation shall
31 not exceed one cubic foot per second of time for each seventy acres of
-93-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 land and shall not exceed three acre-feet in the aggregate during one
2 calendar year for each acre of land for which such appropriation has been
3 made, and an allotment shall not exceed the least amount of water that
4 experience may indicate is necessary, in the exercise of good husbandry,
5 for the production of crops. Such limitations do not apply to storage
6 waters or to water appropriations transferred pursuant to sections
7 46-2,122 to 46-2,125 and 46-2,127 to 46-2,129.
8 When storage water is being used in addition to the natural flow,
9 the person in charge of the ditch or canal shall, upon his or her request
10 and within twenty-four hours thereof, be notified in writing by the user
11 of such storage waters of the time of withdrawal from natural streams to
12 be distributed according to law.
13 When an appropriation is for irrigation purposes and the amount is
14 so small that a proper distribution and application is impractical, as
15 much water as the applicant can use without waste may be allotted for a
16 limited time so fixed by the Chief Water Officer department as to give
17 each appropriator his or her just share without violating other rights,
18 so long as (1) the volume of water used in a twenty-four-hour period does
19 not exceed the amount of water that would otherwise have been allowed at
20 the approved fixed continuous rate for a twenty-four-hour period or (2)
21 the volume of water used in a seven-day, Monday-through-Sunday period
22 does not exceed the amount of water that would otherwise have been
23 allowed at the approved fixed continuous rate for a seven-day period. The
24 Chief Water Officer department shall determine schedules among
25 appropriators to assure that other rights are not violated.

6 water it anticipates using in the next twenty-five-year period. Such
7 statement shall also quantify the total amount of water the public water
8 supplier presently uses from the well field as well as the total amount
9 of water it anticipates using from the well field in the next twenty-
10 five-year period.
11 (3) Upon receipt of an application containing the information set
12 forth in this section, the Chief Water Officer department shall (a) make
13 a record of the receipt of the application, (b) cause the application to
14 be recorded in its office, and (c) make a careful examination of the
15 application to ascertain whether it sets forth all the facts necessary to
16 enable the Chief Water Officer department to determine the nature and
17 amount of the proposed appropriation. If such an examination shows the
18 application in any way defective, it shall be returned to the applicant
19 for correction, with a statement of the correction required, within
20 ninety days after its receipt. Ninety days shall be allowed for the
21 refiling of the application, and in default of such refiling, the
22 application shall stand dismissed. Except as provided in subsection (4)
23 of this section, if so filed and corrected as required within such time,
24 the application shall, upon being accepted and allowed, take priority as
25 of the date of the original filing, subject to compliance with the future
26 provisions of the law and the rules and regulations thereunder. During
27 the pendency of any application or upon its approval, the Chief Water
28 Officer department, upon proper authorization and request of the
29 applicant, may assign the application a later priority date.
30 (4) For public water supplier wells in existence on September 9,
31 1993, the priority date assigned to an application for induced ground
-96-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 water recharge made by a public water supplier shall be:
2 (a) June 27, 1963, for water supply wells and facilities constructed
3 and placed in service on or before June 27, 1963;
4 (b) January 1, 1970, for water supply wells and facilities
5 constructed and placed in service on or after June 28, 1963, and on or
6 before December 31, 1969;
7 (c) January 1, 1980, for water supply wells and facilities
8 constructed and placed in service on or after January 1, 1970, and on or
9 before December 31, 1979;
10 (d) January 1, 1990, for water supply wells and facilities
11 constructed and placed in service on or after January 1, 1980, and on or
12 before December 31, 1989; and
13 (e) January 1, 1993, for water supply wells and facilities
14 constructed and placed in service on or after January 1, 1990, and on or
15 before September 9, 1993.
16 (5) Prior to taking action on an application for induced ground
17 water recharge, the Chief Water Officer director shall publish notice of
18 such application at the applicant's expense at least once each week for
19 three consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the area
20 of the stream segment and also in a newspaper of statewide circulation.
21 The notice shall state that any person having an interest may, in
22 writing, object to the application. Any such objection shall be filed
23 with the Chief Water Officer department within two weeks after the final
24 publication of the notice.
25 (6) After the Chief Water Officer director has accepted the
26 application made under subsection (2) of this section as a completed
27 application and published notice as required under subsection (5) of this
28 section, the Chief Water Officer director shall, if he or she determines
29 that a hearing is necessary, set a time and place for a public hearing on
30 the application. The hearing shall be held within reasonable proximity to
31 the area in which the wells are or would be located. At the hearing the
-97-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 applicant shall present all hydrological data and other evidence
2 supporting its application. All interested parties shall be allowed to
3 testify and present evidence relative to the application.
4 (7) An unapproved application pending on August 26, 1983, may be
5 amended to include appropriation for intentional underground water
6 storage and recovery of such water.
7 (8) Application may be made to the Chief Water Officer department
8 for a temporary permit to appropriate water. The same standards for
9 granting a permanent appropriation shall apply for granting such
10 temporary permit except when the temporary permit is for road
11 construction or other public use construction and the amount of water
12 requested is less than ten acre-feet in total volume. For temporary
13 permits for public-use construction, the applicant shall include on the
14 application the location of the diversion, the location of use, a
15 description of the project, the amount of water requested, and the person
16 to contact. Temporary permits for public-use construction and for less
17 than ten acre-feet in total volume may be granted without any
18 determination of unappropriated water and shall be considered to be in
19 the public interest. The requirement of filing a map or plans with the
20 application for a temporary permit may be waived at the discretion of the
21 Chief Water Officer director. In granting a temporary permit, the Chief
22 Water Officer director shall specify a date on which the right to
23 appropriate water under the permit shall expire. Under no circumstances
24 shall such date be longer than one calendar year after the date the
25 temporary permit was granted. Temporary permits shall be administered
26 during times of shortage based on priority. The right to appropriate
27 water shall automatically terminate on the date specified by the Chief
28 Water Officer director on the temporary permit without further action by
29 the Chief Water Officer department.
30 (9) Water may be diverted from any stream, reservoir, or canal by
31 any fire department or emergency response services for the purpose of
-98-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 extinguishing a fire in progress in an emergency without obtaining a
2 permit from the Chief Water Officer department. The installation of a dry
3 well for this purpose is allowed without the prior permission of the
4 Chief Water Officer department, but the Chief Water Officer department
5 shall be informed of any such installation, its location, and the party
6 responsible for its installation and maintenance within thirty days after
7 the installation.
8 Sec. 86. Section 46-233.01, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
9 amended to read:
10 46-233.01 (1) Application may be made to the Chief Water Officer
11 department for a permit to appropriate any of the public surface waters
12 of the State of Nebraska to be diverted or stored in Nebraska for use in
13 any other state.
14 (2) In determining whether to grant such application, the Chief
15 Water Officer director shall consider the following factors:
16 (a) Whether unappropriated water exists in the source of supply
17 named in the application;
18 (b) Whether such application and appropriation when perfected are
19 not otherwise detrimental to the public welfare;
20 (c) Whether denial of the application is demanded by the public
21 interest; and
22 (d) Whether the proposed use is a beneficial use of water.
23 (3) When determining whether denial of such application is demanded
24 by the public interest, the Chief Water Officer director shall consider
25 the following factors:
26 (a) The economic, environmental, and other benefits of the proposed
27 use;
28 (b) Any adverse economic, environmental, and other impacts of the
29 proposed use;
30 (c) Any current beneficial uses being made of the unappropriated
31 water;
-99-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (d) The economic, environmental, and other benefits of not allowing
2 the appropriation and preserving the water supply for beneficial uses
3 within the state;
4 (e) Alternative sources of water supply available to the applicant;
5 and
6 (f) Any other factors consistent with the purposes of this section
7 that the Chief Water Officer director deems relevant to protecting the
8 interests of the state and its citizens.
9 The application shall be deemed in the public interest if the
10 overall benefits to Nebraska are greater than the adverse impacts to
11 Nebraska. The Chief Water Officer's director's order granting or denying
12 an application shall specify the reasons for such action, including a
13 discussion of the required factors for consideration, and shall document
14 such decision by reference to the hearing record, if any, and to any
15 other sources used by the Chief Water Officer director in making the
16 decision.

8 (2)(a) An application for an induced ground water recharge
9 appropriation for public water supplier wells constructed and placed in
10 service before September 9, 1993, shall be approved by the Chief Water
11 Officer director if he or she finds that:
12 (i) The appropriation is necessary to maintain the well or wells for
13 the use or uses for which the appropriation has been requested;
14 (ii) The rate and timing of the flow is the amount reasonably
15 necessary to maintain the well or wells for the uses for which the
16 appropriation has been requested; and
17 (iii) The application is in the public interest and is not
18 detrimental to the public welfare. There shall be a rebuttable
19 presumption that wells which are the subject of an application pursuant
20 to subdivision (2)(a) of this section are in the public interest and are
21 not detrimental to the public welfare.

25 appropriators if the Chief Water Officer director, at the time of

27 construction, were not located, designed, or constructed so as to take
28 reasonable advantage of aquifer conditions in the area to minimize the
29 frequency and amount of the demand for flows for induced ground water
30 recharge. Thereafter a public water supplier holding an approved
31 application which has been denied the right to request regulation of
-102-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 junior appropriators may petition the Chief Water Officer director for a
2 hearing to present evidence showing the Chief Water Officer director that
3 the well or wells have been modified, relocated, or reconstructed to take
4 reasonable advantage of the aquifer conditions in the area. If the Chief
5 Water Officer director determines that the well or wells have been so
6 modified, relocated, or reconstructed, the Chief Water Officer director
7 shall cause to be modified the approval of the application to allow for
8 the regulation of junior appropriators, subject to the restrictions or
9 conditions applicable to public water suppliers.
10 (c) An application for an induced ground water recharge
11 appropriation for public water supplier wells constructed and placed in
12 service before September 9, 1993, shall not be subject to the
13 requirements of sections 46-288 and 46-289.
14 (3) An application for an induced ground water recharge
15 appropriation for public water supplier wells constructed or to be
16 constructed on or after September 9, 1993, shall be approved by the Chief
17 Water Officer director if he or she makes the findings required by
18 subdivision (2)(a) of this section and further finds that:
19 (a) There is unappropriated water available for the appropriation;
20 and
21 (b) The well or wells involved have been or will be located and
22 constructed to take reasonable advantage of aquifer conditions in the
23 area to minimize the frequency and amount of the demand for flows for
24 induced ground water recharge.

1 public interest. If the Chief Water Officer director approves the

5 section.
6 (b) In determining whether an application for an appropriation for

8 Officer's director's considerations shall include, but not be limited to,
9 the possible adverse effects on existing surface water or ground water
10 users and the economic, social, and environmental value of such uses,
11 including, but not limited to, irrigation, recreation, fish and wildlife,
12 public water supply, induced ground water recharge for public water
13 supply systems, and water quality maintenance.

17 Water Officer director in the order issued under this section.

16 shall work a forfeiture of the appropriation and all rights under the

18 considered a part of the cost of construction, and the progress of the
19 construction work shall be such that one-tenth of the total work shall be
20 completed within one year from the date of approval of the application.

22 project shall be prosecuted in the manner described in this section and

4 diversion or withdrawal of water from the reservoir for any purpose other
5 than for watering range livestock and (b) no release from the reservoir
6 to provide water for a downstream diversion or withdrawal for any purpose
7 other than for watering range livestock. This subsection does not exempt
8 any person from the requirements of the Safety of Dams and Reservoirs Act
9 or section 54-2425.
10 (3) Any person intending to construct a reservoir, holding pond, or
11 lagoon for the sole purpose of holding, managing, or disposing of animal
12 or human waste shall be exempt from subsection (1) of this section. This
13 subsection does not exempt any person from any requirements of the Safety
14 of Dams and Reservoirs Act or section 46-233 or 54-2425.
15 (4) Every person intending to modify or rehabilitate an existing
16 storage reservoir so that its impounding capacity is to be increased
17 shall comply with subsection (1) of this section.
18 (5) The owner of a storage reservoir or facility shall be liable for
19 all damages arising from leakage or overflow of the water therefrom or
20 from the breaking of the embankment of such reservoir. The owner or
21 possessor of a reservoir or intentional underground water storage
22 facility does not have the right to store water in such reservoir or
23 facility during the time that such water is required downstream in
24 ditches for direct irrigation or for any reservoir or facility holding a
25 senior right. Every person who owns, controls, or operates a reservoir or
26 intentional underground water storage facility, except political
27 subdivisions of this state, shall be required to pass through the outlets
28 of such reservoir or facility, whether presently existing or hereafter
29 constructed, a portion of the measured inflows to furnish water for
30 livestock in such amounts and at such times as directed by the Chief
31 Water Officer department to meet the requirements for such purposes as
-112-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 determined by the Chief Water Officer department, except that a reservoir
2 or facility owner shall not be required to release water for this purpose
3 which has been legally stored. Any dam shall be constructed in accordance
4 with the Safety of Dams and Reservoirs Act, and the outlet works shall be
5 installed so that water may be released in compliance with this section.
6 The requirement for outlet works may be waived by the Chief Water Officer
7 department upon a showing of good cause. Whenever any person diverts
8 water from a public stream and returns it into the same stream, he or she
9 may take out the same amount of water, less a reasonable deduction for
10 losses in transit, to be determined by the Chief Water Officer
11 department, if no prior appropriator for beneficial use is prejudiced by
12 such diversion.
13 (6) An application for storage and recovery of water intentionally
14 stored underground may be made only by an appropriator of record who
15 shows, by documentary evidence, sufficient interest in the underground
16 water storage facility to entitle the applicant to the water requested.
17 Sec. 98. Section 46-242, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
18 amended to read:

8 Sec. 101. Section 46-254, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is

6 Sec. 108. Section 46-288, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
7 amended to read:
8 46-288 For purposes of this section and section 46-289, unless the
9 context otherwise requires:
10 (1) Basin of origin shall mean the river basin in which the point or
11 proposed point of diversion of water is located;

13 and efficient use of water for domestic, municipal, agricultural,
14 industrial, commercial, power production, subirrigation, fish and
15 wildlife, ground water recharge, interstate compact, water quality
16 maintenance, or recreational purposes. Nothing in this subdivision shall
17 be construed to affect the preferences for use of surface water as

20 river basin and the transportation of such water to another river basin
21 for storage or utilization for a beneficial use; and

MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 Sec. 109. Section 46-289, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
2 amended to read:
3 46-289 The Legislature finds, recognizes, and declares that the
4 transfer of water to outside the boundaries of a river basin may have
5 impacts on the water and other resources in the basin and that such
6 impacts differ from those caused by uses of water within the same basin
7 in part because any unused water will not be returned to the stream from
8 which it is taken for further use in that river basin. The Legislature
9 therefor recognizes the need to delineate factors for consideration by
10 the Chief Water Officer of the Department of Water, Energy, and
11 Environment Director of Natural Resources when evaluating an application
12 made pursuant to section 46-233 which involves an interbasin transfer of
13 water in order to determine whether denial of such application is
14 demanded by the public interest. Those considerations shall include, but
15 not be limited to, the following factors:
16 (1) The economic, environmental, and other benefits of the proposed
17 interbasin transfer and use;
18 (2) Any adverse impacts of the proposed interbasin transfer and use;
19 (3) Any current beneficial uses being made of the unappropriated
20 water in the basin of origin;
21 (4) Any reasonably foreseeable future beneficial uses of the water
22 in the basin of origin;
23 (5) The economic, environmental, and other benefits of leaving the
24 water in the basin of origin for current or future beneficial uses;
25 (6) Alternative sources of water supply available to the applicant;
26 and
27 (7) Alternative sources of water available to the basin of origin
28 for future beneficial uses.
29 The application shall be deemed in the public interest if the
30 overall benefits to the state and the applicant's basin are greater than
31 or equal to the adverse impacts to the state and the basin of origin. The
-122-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 Chief Water Officer's director's order granting or denying an application
2 shall specify the reasons for such action, including a discussion of the
3 required factors for consideration, and shall document such decision by
4 reference to the hearing record, if any, and to any other sources used by
5 the Chief Water Officer director in making the decision.

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 changed to a natural-flow or storage-use appropriation for intentional
2 underground water storage at the same location if the historic
3 consumptive use of the direct-use portion of the appropriation is
4 transferred to another location or is terminated, but such a separation
5 and change may be approved only if, after the separation and change, (i)
6 the total permissible diversion under the appropriation will not
7 increase, (ii) the projected consequences of the separation and change
8 are consistent with the provisions of any integrated management plan
9 adopted in accordance with section 46-718 or 46-719 for the geographic
10 area involved, and (iii) if the location of the proposed intentional
11 underground water storage is in a river basin, subbasin, or reach
12 designated as overappropriated in accordance with section 46-713, the
13 integrated management plan for that river basin, subbasin, or reach has
14 gone into effect, and that plan requires that the amount of the
15 intentionally stored water that is consumed after the change will be no
16 greater than the amount of the incidentally stored water that was
17 consumed prior to the change. Approval of a separation and change
18 pursuant to this subdivision (f) shall not exempt any consumptive use
19 associated with the incidental recharge right from any reduction in water
20 use required by an integrated management plan for a river basin,
21 subbasin, or reach designated as overappropriated in accordance with
22 section 46-713.
23 Whenever any change in type of appropriation is approved pursuant to
24 this subsection and as long as that change remains in effect, the
25 appropriation shall be subject to the statutes, rules, and regulations
26 that apply to the type of appropriation to which the change has been
27 made.
28 (4) The Legislature finds that induced ground water recharge
29 appropriations issued pursuant to sections 46-233 and 46-235 and instream
30 appropriations issued pursuant to section 46-2,115 are specific to the
31 location identified in the appropriation. Neither type of appropriation
-126-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 shall be transferred to a different location, changed to a different type
2 of appropriation, or changed to permit a different purpose of use.
3 (5) In addition to any other purposes for which transfers and
4 changes may be approved, such transfers and changes may be approved if
5 the purpose is (a) to maintain or augment the flow in a specific stream
6 reach for any instream use that the Chief Water Officer department has
7 determined, through rules and regulations, to be a beneficial use or (b)
8 to increase the frequency that a diversion rate or rate of flow specified
9 in another valid appropriation is achieved.
10 For any transfer or change approved pursuant to subdivision (a) of
11 this subsection, the Chief Water Officer department shall be provided
12 with a report at least every five years while such transfer or change is
13 in effect. The purpose of such report shall be to indicate whether the
14 beneficial instream use for which the flow is maintained or augmented
15 continues to exist. If the report indicates that it does not or if no
16 report is filed within sixty days after the Chief Water Officer's
17 department's notice to the appropriator that the deadline for filing the
18 report has passed, the Chief Water Officer department may cancel the its
19 approval of the transfer or change and such appropriation shall revert to
20 the same location of use, type of appropriation, and purpose of use as
21 prior to such approval.
22 (6) A quantified or unquantified appropriation for incidental
23 underground water storage may be transferred to a new location along with
24 the direct-use appropriation with which it is recognized if the Chief
25 Water Officer director finds such transfer to be consistent with section
26 46-294 and determines that the geologic and other relevant conditions at
27 the new location are such that incidental underground water storage will
28 occur at the new location. The Chief Water Officer director may request
29 such information from the applicant as is needed to make such
30 determination and may modify any such quantified appropriation for
31 incidental underground water storage, if necessary, to reflect the
-127-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 geologic and other conditions at the new location.
2 (7) Unless an incidental underground water storage appropriation is
3 changed as authorized by subdivision (3)(f) of this section or is
4 transferred as authorized by subsection (6) of this section or subsection
5 (1) of section 46-291, such appropriation shall be canceled or modified,
6 as appropriate, by the Chief Water Officer director to reflect any
7 reduction in water that will be stored underground as the result of a
8 transfer or change of the direct-use appropriation with which the
9 incidental underground water storage was recognized prior to the transfer
10 or change.
11 (8) Any appropriation for manufacturing of hydropower changed under
12 subdivision (3)(e) of this section shall maintain the priority date and
13 preference category of the original manufacturing appropriation and shall
14 be subject to condemnation and subordination pursuant to sections 70-668
15 and 70-669. Any person holding a subordination agreement that was
16 established prior to such change of appropriation shall be entitled to
17 enter into a new subordination agreement for terms consistent with the
18 original subordination agreement at no additional cost. Any person having
19 obtained a condemnation award that was established prior to such change
20 of appropriation shall be entitled to the same benefits created by such
21 award, and any obligations created by such award shall become the
22 obligations of the new owner of the appropriation changed under this
23 section.

5 writing specifically stating the grounds for each objection and (b) that
6 any such objection and request shall be filed with in the Chief Water
7 Officer office of the department within two weeks after the date of final
8 publication of the notice.
9 (5) Within the time period allowed by this section for the filing of
10 objections and requests for hearings, the county board of any county
11 containing land to which the appropriation is appurtenant and, if
12 applicable, the county board of any county containing land to which the
13 appropriation is proposed to be transferred may provide the Chief Water
14 Officer department with comments about the potential economic impacts of
15 the proposed transfer or change in such county. The filing of any such
16 comments by a county board shall not make the county a party in the
17 application process, but such comments shall be considered by the Chief
18 Water Officer director in determining pursuant to section 46-294 whether
19 the proposed transfer or change is in the public interest.

1 interest shall include, but not be limited to, (i) the economic, social,

5 or change. The Chief Water Officer Department of Natural Resources shall

10 transfer or change will comply with subdivisions (1)(a) through (l) of
11 this section, except that (a) the burden is on a riparian user to
12 demonstrate his or her riparian status and to demonstrate a significant
13 adverse effect on his or her use in order to prevent approval of an

15 transfer are for irrigation, the number of acres to be irrigated will not
16 increase after the transfer, and the location of the diversion from the

22 subsection (1) of this section, or to provide the Chief Water Officer
23 department with information needed to properly and efficiently administer

1 change has been approved shall retain the same priority date as that of

14 is necessary, in the exercise of good husbandry, for the production of
15 crops on the land involved. The Chief Water Officer director may also

31 transfer or on an adjacent quarter section.

20 subdivision of the state or of the federal government;
21 (4) Underground water storage means the act of storing or recharging
22 water in underground strata. Such water shall be known as water stored
23 underground but does not include ground water as defined in section
24 46-706 which occurs naturally;
25 (5) Intentional underground water storage means underground water
26 storage which is an intended purpose or result of a water project or use.
27 Such storage may be accomplished by any lawful means such as injection
28 wells, infiltration basins, canals, reservoirs, and other reasonable
29 methods; and

1 years and ten months after the permit was granted or after the date of
2 the Chief Water Officer's director's action following the last such
3 review, whichever is later, and such notice shall be mailed to the
4 appropriator of record and posted on the department's website. The notice
5 shall state that any interested person may file comments relating to the
6 review of the instream appropriation or may request a hearing to present
7 evidence relevant to such review. Any such comments or request for
8 hearing shall be filed with in the Chief Water Officer headquarters
9 office of the department within six weeks after the date of final
10 publication of the notice. The appropriator of record shall, within the
11 six-week period, file written documentation of the continued use of the
12 appropriation. If no requests for hearing are received and if the Chief
13 Water Officer director is satisfied with the information provided by the
14 appropriator of record that the appropriation continues to be
15 beneficially used and is in the public interest, the Chief Water Officer
16 director shall issue an order stating such findings. If requested by any
17 interested person, or on his or her own motion based on the comments and
18 information filed, the Chief Water Officer director shall schedule a
19 hearing. If a hearing is held, the purpose of the hearing shall be to
20 receive evidence regarding whether the water appropriated under the
21 permit still provides the beneficial uses for which the permit was
22 granted and whether the permit is still in the public interest. The
23 hearing shall proceed under the rebuttable presumption that the
24 appropriation continues to provide the beneficial uses for which the
25 permit was granted and that the appropriation is in the public interest.
26 After the hearing, the Chief Water Officer director may by order modify
27 or cancel, in whole or in part, the instream appropriation.
28 Sec. 128. Section 46-2,113, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
29 amended to read:
30 46-2,113 It is in the state's and the public interest that the
31 filing of the following classes of applications before the Chief Water
-143-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 Officer department demand that the Chief Water Officer director shall

4 such appropriation:
5 (1) Applications for induced recharge to public water supply wells;

8 water exceeding two hundred acre-feet on an average annual basis;

MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025

6 46-2,139 The Storm Water Management Plan Program is created. The

9 such act existed on January 1, 2006, regarding storm water runoff under
10 the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System requirements. The
11 Storm Water Management Plan Program shall function as a grant program
12 administered by the Department of Water, Energy, and Environment
13 Environment and Energy, using funds appropriated for the program. The
14 department shall deduct from funds appropriated amounts sufficient to
15 reimburse itself for its costs of administration of the grant program.

18 requirements of the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System.

1 name of each director, it shall be stated to which of the three groups he
2 or she belongs; and
3 (6) A prayer for the organization of the district by the name
4 proposed.
5 No petition with the requisite signatures shall be declared null and
6 void on account of alleged defects, but the Chief Water Officer
7 department may at any time permit the petition to be amended to conform
8 to the facts, to correct any errors in the description of the territory,
9 or in any other particular. Similar petitions or duplicate copies of the
10 same petition for the organization of the same district may be filed and
11 shall together be regarded as one petition. All such petitions filed
12 prior to the hearing on the first petition filed shall be considered by
13 the Chief Water Officer department the same as though filed with the
14 first petition placed on file. In determining whether the requisite
15 number of landowners have signed the petition, the Chief Water Officer
16 department shall be governed by the names as they appear upon the tax
17 roll which shall be prima facie evidence of such ownership.
18 Sec. 154. Section 46-517, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
19 amended to read:
20 46-517 At the time of filing the petition or at any time subsequent
21 thereto, and prior to the time of hearing on the said petition, a bond
22 shall be filed in the amount of two thousand dollars, with security
23 approved by the Chief Water Officer department to pay all expenses
24 connected with the proceedings in case the organization of the district
25 be not effected. If at any time during the proceeding the Chief Water
26 Officer department shall be satisfied that the bond first executed is
27 insufficient in amount, the Chief Water Officer it may require the
28 execution of an additional bond within a time to be fixed at not less
29 than ten days distant. Upon a failure of the petitioner to execute the
30 same, the petition shall be dismissed.

18 Sec. 160. Section 46-525, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
19 amended to read:
20 46-525 Upon the said hearing, if it shall appear that a petition for
21 the organization of a reclamation district has been signed and presented,
22 as provided in section 46-516, in conformity with the Reclamation Act
23 sections 46-501 to 46-573, and that the allegations of the petition are
24 true, and that no protesting petition has been filed, or if filed has
25 been dismissed as provided in section 46-521, the Chief Water Officer
26 department shall, by order duly entered of record, adjudicate all
27 questions of jurisdiction, declare the district organized, and give it a
28 corporate name, by which it shall thereafter be known in all proceedings.
29 Thereupon the district shall be a political subdivision of the State of
30 Nebraska and a body corporate with all the powers of a public or
31 municipal corporation.

6 In the event of a failure to receive a majority affirmative vote of
7 the voters voting in such election, the district shall be dissolved and
8 the district shall submit to the Chief Water Officer department a full
9 and complete audit by a public accountant showing the assets possessed by
10 the district. Thereupon the Chief Water Officer department shall enter an
11 order providing that within sixty days the assets of such district shall
12 be liquidated, all rights granted by the Chief Water Officer department
13 shall be canceled, and any assets on hand shall be divided as follows:
14 (a) All bills payable and all expenses of dissolution shall be
15 deducted from the assets and paid; and
16 (b) The balance remaining shall be divided proportionately among the
17 operating public school districts of the district in the proportion that
18 the number of acres in each school district bears to the total number of
19 acres of all of the school districts within the boundaries of the
20 district. If the district is confined to one county, distribution shall
21 be made by the county treasurer of such county. If the district extends
22 into more than one county, the funds for disbursement to such school
23 districts shall be paid to the county within which the schoolhouses are
24 located for distribution to such school districts;
25 (2) To take by appropriation, grant, purchase, bequest, devise, or

29 sell, lease, encumber, alienate, or otherwise dispose of waterworks and
30 real and personal property; to enter into contracts for furnishing water
31 service for use within the district; to acquire, construct, operate,

LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 control, and use any and all works, facilities, and means necessary or

5 convenient to the full exercise of the powers granted in this
6 subdivision;

10 the manner provided for in sections 76-704 to 76-724, except that when

20 establish and maintain facilities across any stream of water or
21 watercourse. The district shall promptly restore any such street or
22 highway to its former state of usefulness as nearly as may be and shall
23 not use the same in such manner as to completely or unnecessarily impair
24 the usefulness thereof. In the use of streets, the district shall be
25 subject to the reasonable rules and regulations of the county, city, or
26 village where such streets lie concerning excavation and the refilling of
27 excavation, the relaying of pavements, and the protection of the public
28 during periods of construction. The district shall not be required to pay
29 any license or permit fees or file any bonds. The district may be
30 required to pay reasonable inspection fees;

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 agency thereof for the construction, preservation, operation, and

5 works, and to enter into contracts for the use of water from such works

12 foot of water service furnished to the lands within the district. The

14 acre-foot of water in the respective units and in such case shall assess
15 the lands within each unit upon the same basis of value per acre-foot of
16 water service furnished to lands within such unit;
17 (7) To fix rates at which water service, not otherwise provided for
18 in this section, may be furnished. Rates shall be equitable although not

20 district;

1 purposes, irrigation, power, milling, manufacturing, mining,

4 Sec. 169. Section 46-601.01, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska,

6 46-601.01 For purposes of Chapter 46, article 6:
7 (1) Chief Water Officer means the Chief Water Officer of the
8 Department of Water, Energy, and Environment;
9 (2) Common carrier means any carrier of water including a pipe,
10 canal, ditch, or other means of piping or adjoining water for irrigation
11 purposes;
12 (3) Department means the Department of Water, Energy, and
13 Environment;
14 (4) Director means the Director of Water, Energy, and Environment;

16 (5)(a) (1)(a) Water well means any excavation that is drilled,
17 cored, bored, washed, driven, dug, jetted, or otherwise constructed for
18 the purpose of exploring for ground water, monitoring ground water,
19 utilizing the geothermal properties of the ground, obtaining
20 hydrogeologic information, or extracting water from or injecting fluid as
21 defined in section 81-1502 into the underground water reservoir.
22 (b) Water well includes any excavation made for any purpose if
23 ground water flows into the excavation under natural pressure and a pump
24 or other device is placed in the excavation for the purpose of
25 withdrawing water from the excavation for irrigation. For such
26 excavations, construction means placing a pump or other device into the
27 excavation for the purpose of withdrawing water for irrigation.
28 (c) Water well does not include (i) any excavation made for
29 obtaining or prospecting for oil or natural gas or for inserting media to
30 repressure oil or natural gas bearing formations regulated by the
31 Nebraska Oil and Gas Conservation Commission or (ii) any structure

6 Sec. 170. Section 46-602, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
7 amended to read:
8 46-602 (1) Each water well completed in this state on or after July
9 1, 2001, excluding test holes and dewatering wells to be used for less
10 than ninety days, shall be registered with the department Department of
11 Natural Resources as provided in this section within sixty days after
12 completion of construction of the water well. The licensed water well
13 contractor as defined in section 46-1213 constructing the water well, or
14 the owner of the water well if the owner constructed the water well,
15 shall file the registration on a form made available by the department
16 and shall also file with the department the information from the well log
17 required pursuant to section 46-1241. The department shall, by January 1,
18 2002, provide licensed water well contractors with the option of filing
19 such registration forms electronically. No signature shall be required on
20 forms filed electronically. The fee required by subsection (3) of section
21 46-1224 shall be the source of funds for any required fee to a contractor
22 which provides the online services for such registration. Any discount in
23 the amount paid the state by a credit card, charge card, or debit card
24 company or a third-party merchant bank for such registration fees shall
25 be deducted from the portion of the registration fee collected pursuant

27 (2)(a) If the newly constructed water well is a replacement water
28 well, the registration form shall include (i) the registration number of
29 the water well being replaced, if applicable, and (ii) the date the
30 original water well was decommissioned or a certification that the water
31 well will be decommissioned within one hundred eighty days or a
-173-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 certification that the original water well will be modified and equipped
2 to pump fifty gallons per minute or less and will be used only for
3 livestock, monitoring, observation, or any other nonconsumptive use or de
4 minimis use approved by the applicable natural resources district.
5 (b) For purposes of this section, replacement water well means a
6 water well which is constructed to provide water for the same purpose as
7 the original water well and is operating in accordance with any
8 applicable permit from the department or the Chief Water Officer and any
9 applicable rules and regulations of the natural resources district and,
10 if the purpose is for irrigation, the replacement water well delivers
11 water to the same tract of land served by the original water well and (i)
12 replaces a decommissioned water well within one hundred eighty days after
13 the decommissioning of the original water well, (ii) replaces a water
14 well that has not been decommissioned but will not be used after
15 construction of the new water well and the original water well will be
16 decommissioned within one hundred eighty days after such construction,
17 except that in the case of a municipal water well, the original municipal
18 water well may be used after construction of the new water well but shall
19 be decommissioned within one year after completion of the replacement
20 water well, or (iii) the original water well will continue to be used but
21 will be modified and equipped within one hundred eighty days after such
22 construction of the replacement water well to pump fifty gallons per
23 minute or less and will be used only for livestock, monitoring,
24 observation, or any other nonconsumptive or de minimis use approved by
25 the applicable natural resources district.
26 (c) No water well shall be registered as a replacement water well
27 until the department Department of Natural Resources has received a
28 properly completed notice of decommissioning for the water well being
29 replaced on a form made available by the department, or properly
30 completed notice, prepared in accordance with subsection (7) of this
31 section, of the modification and equipping of the original water well to
-174-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 pump fifty gallons per minute or less for use only for livestock,
2 monitoring, observation, or any other nonconsumptive or de minimis use
3 approved by the applicable natural resources district. Such notices, as
4 required, shall be completed by (i) the licensed water well contractor as
5 defined in section 46-1213 who decommissions the water well or modifies
6 and equips the water well, (ii) the licensed pump installation contractor
7 as defined in section 46-1209 who decommissions the water well or
8 modifies and equips the water well, or (iii) the owner if the owner
9 decommissions a driven sandpoint well which is on land owned by him or
10 her for farming, ranching, or agricultural purposes or as his or her
11 place of abode. The department Department of Environment and Energy
12 shall, by rule and regulation, determine which contractor or owner shall
13 be responsible for such notice in situations in which more than one
14 contractor or owner may be required to provide notice under this
15 subsection.
16 (3) For a series of two or more water wells completed and pumped
17 into a common carrier as part of a single site plan for irrigation
18 purposes, a registration form and a detailed site plan shall be filed for
19 each water well. The registration form shall include the registration
20 numbers of other water wells included in the series if such water wells
21 are already registered.
22 (4) A series of water wells completed for purposes of installation
23 of a ground heat exchanger for a structure for utilizing the geothermal
24 properties of the ground shall be considered as one water well. One
25 registration form and a detailed site plan shall be filed for each such
26 series.
27 (5) One registration form shall be required along with a detailed
28 site plan which shows the location of each such water well in the site
29 and a log from each such water well for water wells constructed as part
30 of a single site plan for (a) monitoring ground water, obtaining
31 hydrogeologic information, or extracting contaminants from the ground,
-175-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (b) water wells constructed as part of remedial action approved by the
2 department Department of Environment and Energy pursuant to section
3 66-1525, 66-1529.02, or 81-15,124, and (c) water well owners who have a
4 permit issued pursuant to the Industrial Ground Water Regulatory Act and
5 also have an underground injection control permit issued by the
6 department Department of Environment and Energy.
7 (6) The department Department of Natural Resources shall be notified
8 by the owner of any change in the ownership of a water well required to
9 be registered under this section. Notification shall be in such form and
10 include such evidence of ownership as the department Director of Natural
11 Resources by rule and regulation directs. The department shall use such
12 notice to update the registration on file. The department shall not
13 collect a fee for the filing of the notice.
14 (7) The licensed water well contractor or licensed pump installation
15 contractor responsible therefor shall notify the department within sixty
16 days on a form provided by the department of any pump installation or any
17 modifications to the construction of the water well or pump, after the
18 initial registration of the well. For a change of use resulting in
19 modification and equipping of an original water well which is being
20 replaced in accordance with subsection (2) of this section, the licensed
21 water well contractor or licensed pump installation contractor shall
22 notify the department within sixty days on a form provided by the
23 department of the water well and pump modifications and equipping of the
24 original water well. A water well owner shall notify the department
25 within sixty days on a form provided by the department of any other
26 changes or any inaccuracies in recorded water well information,
27 including, but not limited to, changes in use. The department shall not
28 collect a fee for the filing of the notice.
29 (8) Whenever a water well becomes an illegal water well as defined
30 in section 46-706, the owner of the water well shall either correct the
31 deficiency that causes the well to be an illegal water well or shall
-176-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 cause the proper decommissioning of the water well in accordance with
2 rules and regulations adopted pursuant to the Water Well Standards and
3 Contractors' Practice Act. The licensed water well contractor who
4 decommissions the water well, the licensed pump installation contractor
5 who decommissions the water well, or the owner if the owner decommissions
6 a driven sandpoint well which is on land owned by him or her for farming,
7 ranching, or agricultural purposes or as his or her place of abode, shall
8 provide a properly completed notice of decommissioning to the department
9 Department of Natural Resources within sixty days. The department
10 Department of Environment and Energy shall, by rule and regulation,
11 determine which contractor or owner shall be responsible for such notice
12 in situations in which more than one contractor or owner may be required
13 to provide notice under this subsection. The department Department of
14 Natural Resources shall not collect a fee for the filing of the notice.
15 (9) Except for water wells which are used solely for domestic
16 purposes and were constructed before September 9, 1993, and for test
17 holes and dewatering wells used for less than ninety days, each water
18 well which was completed in this state before July 1, 2001, and which is
19 not registered on that date shall be an illegal water well until it is
20 registered with the department Department of Natural Resources. Such
21 registration shall be completed by a licensed water well contractor or by
22 the current owner of the water well, shall be on forms provided by the
23 department, and shall provide as much of the information required by
24 subsections (1) through (5) of this section for registration of a new
25 water well as is possible at the time of registration.
26 (10) Water wells which are or were used solely for injecting any
27 fluid other than water into the underground water reservoir, which were
28 constructed before July 16, 2004, and which have not been properly
29 decommissioned on or before July 16, 2004, shall be registered on or
30 before July 1, 2005.

3 Sec. 175. Section 46-613.01, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska,
4 is amended to read:
5 46-613.01 The Legislature recognizes and declares that the
6 maintenance of an adequate source of ground water within this state is
7 essential to the social stability of the state and the health, safety,
8 and welfare of its citizens and that reasonable restrictions on the
9 transportation of ground water from this state are a proper exercise of
10 the police powers of the state. The need for such restrictions, which
11 protect the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of this
12 state, is hereby declared a matter of legislative determination.
13 Any person, firm, city, village, municipal corporation, or other
14 entity intending to withdraw ground water from any water well located in
15 the State of Nebraska and transport it for use in another state shall
16 apply to the Chief Water Officer Department of Natural Resources for a
17 permit to do so. In determining whether to grant or deny such permit, the
18 Chief Water Officer Director of Natural Resources shall consider:
19 (1) The nature of the proposed use and whether it is a beneficial
20 use of ground water;
21 (2) The availability to the applicant of alternative sources of
22 surface or ground water;
23 (3) Any negative effect of the proposed withdrawal on ground water
24 supplies needed to meet present or reasonable future demands for water in
25 the area of the proposed withdrawal, to comply with any interstate
26 compact or decree, or to fulfill the provisions of any other formal state
27 contract or agreement;
28 (4) Any negative effect of the proposed withdrawal on surface water
29 supplies needed to meet present or reasonable future demands within the
30 state, to comply with any interstate compact or decree, or to fulfill the
31 provisions of any other formal state contract or agreement;
-182-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (5) Any adverse environmental effect of the proposed withdrawal or
2 transportation of ground water;
3 (6) The cumulative effect of the proposed withdrawal and transfer
4 relative to the matters listed in subdivisions (3) through (7) (6) of
5 this section when considered in conjunction with all other transfers
6 subject to this section; and
7 (7) Any other factors consistent with the purposes of this section
8 that the Chief Water Officer director deems relevant to protect the
9 health, safety, and welfare of the state and its citizens.
10 Issuance of a permit shall be conditioned on the applicant's
11 compliance with the rules and regulations of the natural resources
12 district from which the water is to be withdrawn. The applicant shall be
13 required to provide access to his or her property at reasonable times for
14 purposes of inspection by officials of the district or the Chief Water
15 Officer or the Chief Water Officer's representatives department.
16 The Chief Water Officer director may include such reasonable
17 conditions on the proposed use as he or she deems necessary to carry out
18 the purposes of this section.
19 Sec. 176. Section 46-613.02, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska,
20 is amended to read:
21 46-613.02 Any person violating any provision of sections 46-601 to
22 46-613.01 or furnishing false information under such sections shall be
23 guilty of a Class IV misdemeanor. Each day of a violation may be
24 considered a separate offense. The Attorney General and the county
25 attorneys may pursue appropriate proceedings pursuant to this section
26 when notified by the Chief Water Officer Director of Natural Resources
27 that such a violation has occurred.

12 (i) One thousand feet; or
13 (ii) The maximum number of feet specified in any applicable
14 regulations of a natural resources district that a well of a public water
15 supplier must be spaced from another well.
16 (b) Any person who, at least one hundred eighty days prior to filing
17 a notice of intent, obtained a valid permit from a natural resources
18 district to drill or construct a water well within the area subject to
19 the protection provided by this section is not prohibited from drilling
20 or constructing a water well.
21 (c) The public water supplier may waive the protection provided by
22 this section and allow a person to drill or construct a new or
23 replacement water well within the area subject to the protection provided
24 by this section.
25 (6) Within thirty days after the public water supplier reaches a
26 determination that the land described in a particular notice of intent is
27 not suitable for a public water supply wellfield, the public water
28 supplier shall notify the Chief Water Officer Department of Natural
29 Resources, all affected natural resources districts, the owner of the
30 land described in the notice of intent, and the owners of all land
31 falling within the spacing protection provided by subdivision (5)(a) of
-190-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 this section pursuant to the notice of intent of such determination. Upon
2 receipt by the Chief Water Officer department of the notice of such
3 determination, the notice of intent that contains the description of such
4 tract of land shall terminate immediately, notwithstanding any other
5 provision of this section.

25 Sec. 196. Section 46-683, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
26 amended to read:
27 46-683 (1) The Chief Water Officer director shall issue a written

31 water are in the public interest. In determining whether the withdrawal
-193-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 and transfer, if any, are in the public interest, the Chief Water
2 Officer's director's considerations shall include, but not be limited to:
3 (a) Possible adverse effects on existing surface or ground water
4 users;
5 (b) The effect of the withdrawal and any transfer of ground water on
6 surface or ground water supplies needed to meet reasonably anticipated
7 domestic and agricultural demands in the area of the proposed ground
8 water withdrawal;
9 (c) The availability of alternative sources of surface or ground
10 water reasonably accessible to the applicant in or near the region of the
11 proposed withdrawal or use;
12 (d) The economic benefit of the applicant's proposed use;
13 (e) The social and economic benefits of existing uses of surface or

17 Chief Water Officer director;

14 46-678.01. Any person using ground water at the time a notice to transfer
15 is filed under such section whose wells thereafter suffer an
16 unanticipated decline in ground water levels may petition the Chief Water
17 Officer director for a hearing. Such petition shall specifically set
18 forth the cause and extent of the ground water decline as well as the
19 nature and extent of any injury resulting from that decline. If at such
20 hearing the injured party presents evidence showing that the ground water
21 levels declined as a result of such transfer and shows the nature and
22 extent of any resulting injury, the Chief Water Officer director may
23 issue an order terminating or conditioning the transfer to eliminate any
24 further injury. If the injured party prevails and an order is issued

27 Sec. 204. Section 46-703, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
28 amended to read:
29 46-703 The Legislature further finds:
30 (1) The management, conservation, and beneficial use of
31 hydrologically connected ground water and surface water are essential to
-199-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 the continued economic prosperity and well-being of the state, including
2 the present and future development of agriculture in the state;
3 (2) Hydrologically connected ground water and surface water may need
4 to be managed differently from unconnected ground water and surface water
5 in order to permit equity among water users and to optimize the
6 beneficial use of interrelated ground water and surface water supplies;
7 (3) Natural resources districts already have significant legal
8 authority to regulate activities which contribute to declines in ground
9 water levels and to nonpoint source contamination of ground water and are
10 the preferred entities to regulate, through ground water management
11 areas, ground water related activities which are contributing to or are,
12 in the reasonably foreseeable future, likely to contribute to conflicts
13 between ground water users and surface water appropriators or to water
14 supply shortages in fully appropriated or overappropriated river basins,
15 subbasins, or reaches;
16 (4) The Legislature recognizes that ground water use or surface
17 water use in one natural resources district may have adverse affects on
18 water supplies in another district or in an adjoining state. The
19 Legislature intends and expects that each natural resources district
20 within which water use is causing external impacts will accept
21 responsibility for ground water management in accordance with the
22 Nebraska Ground Water Management and Protection Act in the same manner
23 and to the same extent as if the impacts were contained within that
24 district;
25 (5) The Chief Water Officer Department of Natural Resources is
26 responsible for regulation of surface water resources and local surface
27 water project sponsors are responsible for much of the structured
28 irrigation utilizing surface water supplies, and the Chief Water Officer
29 and the local surface water project sponsors these entities should be
30 responsible for regulation of surface water related activities which
31 contribute to conflicts between ground water users and surface water
-200-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 appropriators or to water supply shortages in fully appropriated or
2 overappropriated river basins, subbasins, or reaches;
3 (6) All involved natural resources districts, the Chief Water
4 Officer department, and surface water project sponsors should cooperate
5 and collaborate on the identification and implementation of management
6 solutions to conflicts between ground water users and surface water
7 appropriators or to water supply shortages in fully appropriated or
8 overappropriated river basins, subbasins, and reaches; and
9 (7) An Interrelated Water Review Board is needed to resolve any
10 conflicts between the Chief Water Officer department and the involved
11 natural resources districts concerning the content, implementation, or
12 enforcement of integrated management plans for fully appropriated and
13 overappropriated river basins, subbasins, and reaches.

17 (1) The levels of nitrate nitrogen and other contaminants in ground

19 (31) (29) Variance means (a) an approval to deviate from a
20 restriction imposed under subsection (1), (2), (8), or (9) of section
21 46-714 or (b) the approval to act in a manner contrary to existing rules
22 or regulations from a governing body whose rule or regulation is
23 otherwise applicable;
24 (32) (30) Certified irrigated acres means the number of acres or
25 portion of an acre that a natural resources district has approved for
26 irrigation from ground water in accordance with law and with rules
27 adopted by the district; and
28 (33) (31) Certified water uses means beneficial uses of ground water
29 for purposes other than irrigation identified by a district pursuant to
30 rules adopted by the district.

1 amended to read:

4 Sec. 209. Section 46-709, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
5 amended to read:
6 46-709 Each district shall maintain a ground water management plan
7 based upon the best available information and shall submit amendments to
8 such plan to the Chief Water Officer Director of Natural Resources for
9 review and approval.
10 The plan shall include, but not be limited to, the identification to
11 the extent possible of:
12 (1) Ground water supplies within the district including
13 transmissivity, saturated thickness maps, and other ground water
14 reservoir information, if available;
15 (2) Local recharge characteristics and rates from any sources, if
16 available;
17 (3) Average annual precipitation and the variations within the
18 district;
19 (4) Crop water needs within the district;
20 (5) Current ground water data-collection programs;
21 (6) Past, present, and potential ground water use within the
22 district;
23 (7) Ground water quality concerns within the district;
24 (8) Proposed water conservation and supply augmentation programs for
25 the district;
26 (9) The availability of supplemental water supplies, including the
27 opportunity for ground water recharge;
28 (10) The opportunity to integrate and coordinate the use of water
29 from different sources of supply;
30 (11) Ground water management objectives, including a proposed ground
31 water reservoir life goal for the district. For management plans adopted
-209-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 or revised after July 19, 1996, the ground water management objectives

4 management plan does not have to be revised prior to the adoption or
5 implementation of an integrated management plan pursuant to section
6 46-718 or 46-719;
7 (12) Existing subirrigation uses within the district;
8 (13) The relative economic value of different uses of ground water
9 proposed or existing within the district; and
10 (14) The geographic and stratigraphic boundaries of any proposed
11 management area.
12 If the expenses incurred by a district preparing or amending a
13 ground water management plan exceed twenty-five percent of the district's
14 current budget, the district may make application to the Nebraska
15 Resources Development Fund for assistance.

18 within the district, ground water quality goals, long-term solutions
19 necessary to prevent the levels of ground water contaminants from
20 becoming too high and to reduce high levels sufficiently to eliminate
21 health hazards, and practices recommended to stabilize, reduce, and
22 prevent the occurrence, increase, or spread of ground water
23 contamination.

31 46-718, the district's management plan shall have been approved by the

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 Chief Water Officer Director of Natural Resources or the district shall

5 develop computer models. In order to establish a management area, the

10 area. Notice of the hearing shall be published as provided in section
11 46-743, and the hearing shall be conducted in accordance with such
12 section.
13 (3)(a) Within ninety days after the hearing, the district shall
14 determine whether a management area shall be designated. If the district
15 determines that no management area shall be established, the district
16 shall issue an order to that effect.
17 (b) If the district determines that a management area shall be
18 established, the district shall by order designate the area as a
19 management area and shall adopt one or more controls authorized by
20 section 46-739 to be utilized within the area in order to achieve the
21 ground water management objectives specified in the plan. Such an order
22 shall include a geographic and stratigraphic definition of the area. The
23 boundaries and controls shall take into account any considerations
24 brought forth at the hearing and administrative factors directly
25 affecting the ability of the district to implement and carry out local
26 ground water management.
27 (c) The controls adopted shall not include controls substantially
28 different from those set forth in the notice of the hearing. The area
29 designated by the order shall not include any area not included in the
30 notice of the hearing.

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (c) In addition to the conclusion about whether a river basin,
2 subbasin, or reach is fully appropriated, the Chief Water Officer

LB317 LB317

1 any interested person. To be considered sufficient to justify a

20 Chief Water Officer department, then (i) the Chief Water Officer

31 and present written or oral testimony and evidence concerning the
-216-

LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 appropriation status of the river basin, subbasin, or reach.
2 (c) Within thirty days after the final hearing under subdivision (b)
3 of this subsection, the Chief Water Officer department shall notify the
4 appropriate natural resources districts of the Chief Water Officer's
5 department's final determination with respect to the appropriation status
6 of the river basin, subbasin, or reach.
7 (3) A river basin, subbasin, or reach shall be deemed fully
8 appropriated if the Chief Water Officer department determines based upon
9 the its evaluation conducted pursuant to subsection (1) of this section
10 and information presented at the hearing pursuant to subsection (4) of
11 section 46-714 that then-current uses of hydrologically connected surface
12 water and ground water in the river basin, subbasin, or reach cause or
13 will in the reasonably foreseeable future cause (a) the surface water
14 supply to be insufficient to sustain over the long term the beneficial or
15 useful purposes for which existing natural-flow or storage appropriations
16 were granted and the beneficial or useful purposes for which, at the time
17 of approval, any existing instream appropriation was granted, (b) the
18 streamflow to be insufficient to sustain over the long term the
19 beneficial uses from wells constructed in aquifers dependent on recharge
20 from the river or stream involved, or (c) reduction in the flow of a
21 river or stream sufficient to cause noncompliance by Nebraska with an
22 interstate compact or decree, other formal state contract or agreement,
23 or applicable state or federal laws.
24 (4)(a) A river basin, subbasin, or reach shall be deemed
25 overappropriated if, on July 16, 2004, the river basin, subbasin, or
26 reach is subject to an interstate cooperative agreement among three or
27 more states and if, prior to such date, the Chief Water Officer
28 department has declared a moratorium on the issuance of new surface water
29 appropriations in such river basin, subbasin, or reach and has requested
30 each natural resources district with jurisdiction in the affected area in
31 such river basin, subbasin, or reach either (i) to close or to continue
-217-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 in effect a previously adopted closure of all or part of such river
2 basin, subbasin, or reach to the issuance of additional water well
3 permits in accordance with subdivision (1)(k) of section 46-656.25 as
4 such section existed prior to July 16, 2004, or (ii) to temporarily
5 suspend or to continue in effect a temporary suspension, previously
6 adopted pursuant to section 46-656.28 as such section existed prior to
7 July 16, 2004, on the drilling of new water wells in all or part of such
8 river basin, subbasin, or reach.
