11 overappropriated. The designation shall include a description of the
12 geographic area within which the Chief Water Officer department has
13 determined that surface water and ground water are hydrologically
14 connected and the criteria used to make such determination.

12 that the river basin, subbasin, or reach is fully appropriated, the Chief
13 Water Officer department, at the same time, shall (a) decide whether to
14 continue or to terminate the stays on new surface water uses and on
15 increases in the number of surface water irrigated acres and (b)
16 designate the geographic area within which the Chief Water Officer
17 department considers surface water and ground water to be hydrologically
18 connected in the river basin, subbasin, or reach and describe the methods
19 and criteria used in making that determination. The Chief Water Officer
20 department shall provide notice of its decision to continue or terminate
21 the stays in the same manner as the notice required by subsection (1) of
22 this section.
23 (6) Within ninety days after a final determination by the Chief
24 Water Officer department that a river basin, subbasin, or reach is fully
25 appropriated, an affected natural resources district may hold one or more
26 public hearings on the question of whether the stays on the issuance of
27 new water well permits, on the construction of new water wells, or on
28 increases in ground water irrigated acres should be terminated. Notice of
29 the hearings shall be published as provided in section 46-743.
30 (7) Within forty-five days after a natural resources district's
31 final hearing pursuant to subsection (6) of this section, the natural
-222-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 resources district shall decide (a) whether to terminate the stay on new
2 water wells in all or part of the natural resources district subject to
3 the stay and (b) whether to terminate the stay on increases in ground
4 water irrigated acres. If the natural resources district decides not to
5 terminate the stay on new water wells in any geographic area, it shall
6 also decide whether to exempt from such stay the construction of water
7 wells for which permits were issued prior to the issuance of the stay but
8 for which construction had not begun prior to issuance of the stay. If
9 construction of water wells for which permits were issued prior to the
10 stay is allowed, all permits that were valid when the stay went into
11 effect shall be extended by a time period equal to the length of the
12 stay.
13 (8) Whenever the Chief Water Officer department designates a river
14 basin, subbasin, or reach as overappropriated, each previously declared
15 moratorium on the issuance of new surface water appropriations in the
16 river basin, subbasin, or reach shall continue in effect. The Chief Water
17 Officer department shall also provide prompt notice of such designation
18 to all licensed water well contractors in the state and to each natural
19 resources district that encompasses any of the geographic area involved.
20 Immediately upon receipt of such notice by a natural resources district,
21 there shall be a stay on the issuance of new water well construction
22 permits in any portion of such natural resources district that is within
23 the hydrologically connected area designated by the Chief Water Officer
24 department. The Chief Water Officer department shall also notify the
25 public of its designation of such river basin, subbasin, or reach as
26 overappropriated and of the geographic area involved in such designation.
27 Such notice shall be published once each week for three consecutive weeks
28 in at least one newspaper of statewide circulation and in such other
29 newspapers as are deemed appropriate by the Chief Water Officer
30 department to provide general notice in the river basin, subbasin, or
31 reach.
-223-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (9) Beginning ten days after the first publication of notice under
2 subsection (8) of this section in a newspaper of statewide circulation,
3 there shall also be stays (a) on the construction of any new water well
4 in the hydrologically connected area if such construction has not
5 commenced prior to such date and if no permit for construction of the
6 water well has been issued previously by either the Chief Water Officer
7 department or the natural resources district, (b) on the use of an
8 existing water well in the hydrologically connected area to increase the
9 number of acres historically irrigated, and (c) on the use of an existing
10 surface water appropriation to increase the number of acres historically
11 irrigated in the affected area.
12 (10) Within ninety days after a designation by the Chief Water
13 Officer department of a river basin, subbasin, or reach as
14 overappropriated, a natural resources district that encompasses any of
15 the hydrologically connected area designated by the Chief Water Officer
16 department may hold one or more public hearings on the question of
17 whether to terminate the stays on (a) the construction of new water wells
18 within all or part of its portion of the hydrologically connected area,
19 (b) the issuance of new water well construction permits in such area, or
20 (c) the increase in ground water irrigated acres in such area. Notice of
21 any hearing for such purpose shall be provided pursuant to section
22 46-743. Prior to the scheduling of a natural resources district hearing
23 on the question of whether to terminate any such stay, the Chief Water
24 Officer department and the affected natural resources district shall
25 consult with any irrigation district, reclamation district, public power
26 and irrigation district, mutual irrigation company, canal company, or
27 municipality that relies on water from the affected river basin,
28 subbasin, or reach and with other water users and stakeholders as deemed
29 appropriate by the Chief Water Officer department or the natural
30 resources district.
31 (11) Any stay issued pursuant to this section shall remain in effect
-224-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 until (a) the stay has been terminated pursuant to subsection (5), (7),
2 or (10) of this section, (b) an integrated management plan for the
3 affected river basin, subbasin, or reach has been adopted by the Chief
4 Water Officer department and the affected natural resources districts and
5 has taken effect, (c) an integrated management plan for the affected
6 river basin, subbasin, or reach has been adopted by the Interrelated
7 Water Review Board and has taken effect, (d) the Chief Water Officer
8 department has completed a reevaluation pursuant to subsection (2) of
9 section 46-713 and has determined that the affected river basin,
10 subbasin, or reach is not fully appropriated or overappropriated, or (e)
11 the stay expires pursuant to this subsection. Such stay may be imposed
12 initially for not more than three years following the Chief Water
13 Officer's department's designation of the river basin, subbasin, or reach
14 as overappropriated or the Chief Water Officer's department's final
15 determination that a river basin, subbasin, or reach is fully
16 appropriated and may be extended thereafter on an annual basis by
17 agreement of the Chief Water Officer department and the affected natural
18 resources district for not more than two additional years if necessary to
19 allow the development, adoption, and implementation of an integrated
20 management plan pursuant to sections 46-715 to 46-719.
21 (12)(a) For purposes of this subsection, (i) a status change occurs
22 when a preliminary or final determination that a river basin, subbasin,
23 or reach is fully appropriated is reversed by the Chief Water Officer
24 department or by judicial determination and such river basin, subbasin,
25 or reach is determined not to be fully appropriated and (ii) the
26 hydrologically connected area means the geographic area within which the
27 Chief Water Officer department considers surface water and ground water
28 in such river basin, subbasin, or reach to be hydrologically connected.
29 (b) If a status change occurs, any stays previously in force by the
30 Chief Water Officer department or affected natural resources districts
31 shall remain in force until the stays imposed under this subsection are
-225-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 in place and the Chief Water Officer department shall place an immediate
2 stay on the issuance of any new natural-flow, storage, or storage-use
3 appropriations in the river basin, subbasin, or reach. The Chief Water
4 Officer department shall also provide prompt notice of the status change
5 in accordance with subsection (1) of this section. Immediately upon
6 receipt of the notice by the affected natural resources district, there
7 shall be stays imposed as set forth in subsections (1) and (2) of this
8 section, subject to the exceptions set forth in subsection (3) of this
9 section. The stays imposed pursuant to this subsection shall remain in
10 effect within each affected natural resources district until such
11 district adopts rules and regulations in accordance with subdivision (c),
12 (d), or (e) of this subsection.
13 (c) Upon receipt of notice of a status change, each affected natural
14 resources district shall adopt rules and regulations within one hundred
15 twenty days after receipt of such notice for the prioritization and
16 granting of water well permits within the hydrologically connected area
17 for the four-year period following the status change. Nothing in this
18 subsection shall be construed to supersede the authority provided to
19 natural resources districts under subsection (2) of section 46-707 and
20 subdivisions (1)(f) and (1)(m) of section 46-739.
21 (d) The rules and regulations adopted by each affected natural
22 resources district in accordance with subdivision (c) of this subsection
23 shall (i) allow a limited number of total new ground water irrigated
24 acres annually, (ii) be created with the purpose of maintaining the
25 status of not fully appropriated based on the most recent basin
26 determination, (iii) be for a term of not less than four years, and (iv)
27 limit the number of new permits so that total new ground water irrigated
28 acres do not exceed the number set in the rules and regulations. The
29 Chief Water Officer department shall approve the proposed new number of
30 ground water irrigated acres within sixty days after approval by the
31 natural resources district if such district meets the conditions set
-226-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 forth in subdivision (d)(ii) of this subsection, based on the most recent
2 basin determination.
3 (e) If the proposed new number of acres is not approved by the Chief
4 Water Officer department within the applicable time period as provided in
5 subdivision (d) of this subsection, the affected natural resources
6 districts shall adopt rules and regulations that allow water well permits
7 to be issued that will result in no more than two thousand five hundred
8 irrigated acres or that will result in an increase of not more than
9 twenty percent of all historically irrigated acres within the
10 hydrologically connected area of each natural resources district within
11 the affected river basin, subbasin, or reach, whichever is less, for each
12 calendar year of the four-year period following the date of the
13 determination described in this subsection. Each affected natural
14 resources district may, after the initial four-year period has expired,
15 annually determine whether water well permit limitations should continue
16 and may enforce such limitations.
17 (f) During the four-year period following the status change, the
18 Chief Water Officer department shall ensure that any new appropriation
19 granted will not cause the basin, subbasin, or reach to be fully
20 appropriated based on the most recent basin determination. The Chief
21 Water Officer department, pursuant to its rules and regulations adopted
22 and promulgated under the Nebraska Ground Water Management and Protection
23 Act, shall not issue new natural flow surface water appropriations for
24 irrigation, within the river basin, subbasin, or reach affected by the
25 status change, that will result in a net increase of more than eight
26 hundred thirty-four irrigated acres in each natural resources district
27 during each calendar year of the four-year period following the date of
28 the determination described in this subsection.
29 Sec. 214. Section 46-715, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
30 amended to read:
31 46-715 (1)(a) Whenever the Chief Water Officer Department of Natural
-227-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 Resources has designated a river basin, subbasin, or reach as
2 overappropriated or has made a final determination that a river basin,
3 subbasin, or reach is fully appropriated, the natural resources districts
4 encompassing such river basin, subbasin, or reach and the Chief Water
5 Officer department shall jointly develop an integrated management plan
6 for such river basin, subbasin, or reach. The plan shall be completed,
7 adopted, and take effect within three years after such designation or
8 final determination unless the Chief Water Officer department and the
9 natural resources districts jointly agree to an extension of not more
10 than two additional years.
11 (b) A natural resources district encompassing a river basin,
12 subbasin, or reach that has not been designated as overappropriated or
13 has not been finally determined to be fully appropriated may, jointly
14 with the Chief Water Officer department, develop an integrated management
15 plan for such river basin, subbasin, or reach located within the
16 district. The district shall notify the Chief Water Officer department of
17 its intention to develop an integrated management plan which shall be
18 developed and adopted according to sections 46-715 to 46-717 and
19 subsections (1) and (2) of section 46-718. The objective of an integrated
20 management plan under this subdivision is to manage such river basin,
21 subbasin, or reach to achieve and sustain a balance between water uses
22 and water supplies for the long term. If a district develops an
23 integrated management plan under this subdivision and the Chief Water
24 Officer department subsequently determines the affected river basin,
25 subbasin, or reach to be fully appropriated, the Chief Water Officer
26 department and the affected natural resources district may amend the
27 integrated management plan.
28 (2) In developing an integrated management plan, the effects of
29 existing and potential new water uses on existing surface water
30 appropriators and ground water users shall be considered. An integrated
31 management plan shall include the following: (a) Clear goals and
-228-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 objectives with a purpose of sustaining a balance between water uses and
2 water supplies so that the economic viability, social and environmental
3 health, safety, and welfare of the river basin, subbasin, or reach can be
4 achieved and maintained for both the near term and the long term; (b) a
5 map clearly delineating the geographic area subject to the integrated
6 management plan; (c) one or more of the ground water controls authorized
7 for adoption by natural resources districts pursuant to section 46-739;
8 (d) one or more of the surface water controls authorized for adoption by
9 the Chief Water Officer department pursuant to section 46-716; and (e) a
10 plan to gather and evaluate data, information, and methodologies that
11 could be used to implement sections 46-715 to 46-717, increase
12 understanding of the surface water and hydrologically connected ground
13 water system, and test the validity of the conclusions and information
14 upon which the integrated management plan is based. The plan may also
15 provide for utilization of any applicable incentive programs authorized
16 by law. Nothing in the integrated management plan for a fully
17 appropriated river basin, subbasin, or reach shall require a natural
18 resources district to regulate ground water uses in place at the time of
19 the Chief Water Officer's department's preliminary determination that the
20 river basin, subbasin, or reach is fully appropriated, unless such
21 regulation is necessary to carry out the goals and objectives of a basin-
22 wide plan pursuant to section 46-755, but a natural resources district
23 may voluntarily adopt such regulations. The applicable natural resources
24 district may decide to include all water users within the district
25 boundary in an integrated management plan.
26 (3) In order to provide a process for economic development
27 opportunities and economic sustainability within a river basin, subbasin,
28 or reach, the integrated management plan shall include clear and
29 transparent procedures to track depletions and gains to streamflows
30 resulting from new, retired, or other changes to uses within the river
31 basin, subbasin, or reach. The procedures shall:
-229-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (a) Utilize generally accepted methodologies based on the best
2 available information, data, and science;
3 (b) Include a generally accepted methodology to be utilized to
4 estimate depletions and gains to streamflows, which methodology includes
5 location, amount, and time regarding gains to streamflows as offsets to
6 new uses;
7 (c) Identify means to be utilized so that new uses will not have
8 more than a de minimis effect upon existing surface water users or ground
9 water users;
10 (d) Identify procedures the natural resources district and the Chief
11 Water Officer department will use to report, consult, and otherwise share
12 information on new uses, changes in uses, or other activities affecting
13 water use in the river basin, subbasin, or reach;
14 (e) Identify, to the extent feasible, potential water available to
15 mitigate new uses, including, but not limited to, water rights leases,
16 interference agreements, augmentation projects, conjunctive use
17 management, and use retirement;
18 (f) Develop, to the extent feasible, an outline of plans after
19 consultation with and an opportunity to provide input from irrigation
20 districts, public power and irrigation districts, reclamation districts,
21 municipalities, other political subdivisions, and other water users to
22 make water available for offset to enhance and encourage economic
23 development opportunities and economic sustainability in the river basin,
24 subbasin, or reach; and
25 (g) Clearly identify procedures that applicants for new uses shall
26 take to apply for approval of a new water use and corresponding offset.
27 Nothing in this subsection shall require revision or amendment of an
28 integrated management plan approved on or before August 30, 2009.
29 (4) The ground water and surface water controls proposed for
30 adoption in the integrated management plan pursuant to subsection (1) of
31 this section shall, when considered together and with any applicable
-230-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 incentive programs, (a) be consistent with the goals and objectives of
2 the plan, (b) be sufficient to ensure that the state will remain in
3 compliance with applicable state and federal laws and with any applicable
4 interstate water compact or decree or other formal state contract or
5 agreement pertaining to surface water or ground water use or supplies,
6 and (c) protect the ground water users whose water wells are dependent on

9 surface water uses and ground water uses begun, in the case of a river
10 basin, subbasin, or reach designated as overappropriated or preliminarily
11 determined to be fully appropriated in accordance with section 46-713,
12 after the date of such designation or preliminary determination.
13 (5)(a) In any river basin, subbasin, or reach that is designated as
14 overappropriated, when the designated area lies within two or more
15 natural resources districts, the Chief Water Officer department and the
16 affected natural resources districts shall jointly develop a basin-wide
17 plan for the area designated as overappropriated. Such plan shall be

19 subdivision (b) of this subsection, shall be developed concurrently with
20 the development of the integrated management plan required pursuant to
21 subsections (1) through (4) of this section, and shall be designed to

27 overappropriated and subject to this subsection, the Chief Water Officer
28 department and each natural resources district encompassing such river
29 basin, subbasin, or reach shall jointly develop an integrated management
30 plan for such river basin, subbasin, or reach pursuant to subsections (1)
31 through (4) of this section. Each integrated management plan for a river
-231-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 basin, subbasin, or reach subject to this subsection shall be consistent
2 with any basin-wide plan developed pursuant to subdivision (a) of this
3 subsection. Such integrated management plan shall be developed after
4 consultation and collaboration with irrigation districts, reclamation
5 districts, public power and irrigation districts, mutual irrigation
6 companies, canal companies, and municipalities that rely on water from
7 within the affected area and that, after being notified of the
8 commencement of the plan development process, indicate in writing their
9 desire to participate in such process. In addition, the Chief Water
10 Officer department or the affected natural resources districts may
11 include designated representatives of other stakeholders. If agreement is
12 reached by all parties involved in such consultation and collaboration
13 process, the Chief Water Officer department and each natural resources
14 district shall adopt the agreed-upon integrated management plan. If
15 agreement cannot be reached by all parties involved, the integrated
16 management plan shall be developed and adopted by the Chief Water Officer
17 department and the affected natural resources district pursuant to
18 sections 46-715 to 46-718 or by the Interrelated Water Review Board
19 pursuant to section 46-719.
20 (c) Any integrated management plan developed under this subsection
21 shall identify the overall difference between the current and fully
22 appropriated levels of development. Such determination shall take into
23 account cyclical supply, including drought, identify the portion of the
24 overall difference between the current and fully appropriated levels of
25 development that is due to conservation measures, and identify the
26 portions of the overall difference between the current and fully
27 appropriated levels of development that are due to water use initiated
28 prior to July 1, 1997, and to water use initiated on or after such date.
29 (d) Any integrated management plan developed under this subsection
30 shall adopt an incremental approach to achieve the goals and objectives
31 identified under subdivision (2)(a) of this section using the following
-232-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 steps:
2 (i) The first incremental goals shall be to address the impact of
3 streamflow depletions to (A) surface water appropriations and (B) water
4 wells constructed in aquifers dependent upon recharge from streamflow, to
5 the extent those depletions are due to water use initiated after July 1,
6 1997, and, unless an interstate cooperative agreement for such river
7 basin, subbasin, or reach is no longer in effect, to prevent streamflow
8 depletions that would cause noncompliance by Nebraska with such
9 interstate cooperative agreement. During the first increment, the Chief
10 Water Officer department and the affected natural resources districts
11 shall also pursue voluntary efforts, subject to the availability of
12 funds, to offset any increase in streamflow depletive effects that occur
13 after July 1, 1997, but are caused by ground water uses initiated prior
14 to such date. The Chief Water Officer department and the affected natural
15 resources districts may also use other appropriate and authorized
16 measures for such purpose;
17 (ii) The Chief Water Officer department and the affected natural
18 resources districts may amend an integrated management plan subject to
19 this subsection (5) as necessary based on an annual review of the
20 progress being made toward achieving the goals for that increment;
21 (iii) During the ten years following adoption of an integrated
22 management plan developed under this subsection (5) or during the ten
23 years after the adoption of any subsequent increment of the integrated
24 management plan pursuant to subdivision (d)(iv) of this subsection, the
25 Chief Water Officer department and the affected natural resources
26 district shall conduct a technical analysis of the actions taken in such
27 increment to determine the progress towards meeting the goals and
28 objectives adopted pursuant to subsection (2) of this section. The
29 analysis shall include an examination of (A) available supplies and
30 changes in long-term availability, (B) the effects of conservation
31 practices and natural causes, including, but not limited to, drought, and
-233-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (C) the effects of the plan on reducing the overall difference between
2 the current and fully appropriated levels of development identified in
3 subdivision (5)(c) of this section. The analysis shall determine whether
4 a subsequent increment is necessary in the integrated management plan to
5 meet the goals and objectives adopted pursuant to subsection (2) of this
6 section and reduce the overall difference between the current and fully
7 appropriated levels of development identified in subdivision (5)(c) of
8 this section;
9 (iv) Based on the determination made in subdivision (d)(iii) of this
10 subsection, the Chief Water Officer department and the affected natural
11 resources districts, utilizing the consultative and collaborative process
12 described in subdivision (b) of this subsection, shall if necessary
13 identify goals for a subsequent increment of the integrated management
14 plan. Subsequent increments shall be completed, adopted, and take effect
15 not more than ten years after adoption of the previous increment; and
16 (v) If necessary, the steps described in subdivisions (d)(ii)
17 through (iv) of this subsection shall be repeated until the Chief Water
18 Officer department and the affected natural resources districts agree
19 that the goals and objectives identified pursuant to subsection (2) of
20 this section have been met and the overall difference between the current
21 and fully appropriated levels of development identified in subdivision
22 (5)(c) of this section has been addressed so that the river basin,
23 subbasin, or reach has returned to a fully appropriated condition.
24 (6) In any river basin, subbasin, or reach that is designated as
25 fully appropriated or overappropriated and whenever necessary to ensure
26 that the state is in compliance with an interstate compact or decree or a
27 formal state contract or agreement, the Chief Water Officer department,
28 in consultation with the affected districts, shall forecast on an annual

30 for beneficial use in the short term and long term in order to comply
31 with the requirement of subdivision (4)(b) of this section. This forecast
-234-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 shall be made by January 1, 2008, and each January 1 thereafter.
2 Sec. 215. Section 46-716, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
3 amended to read:
4 46-716 (1) The surface water controls that may be included in an
5 integrated management plan and may be adopted by the Chief Water Officer
6 Department of Natural Resources are: (a) Increased monitoring and
7 enforcement of surface water diversion rates and amounts diverted
8 annually; (b) the prohibition or limitation of additional surface water
9 appropriations; (c) requirements for surface water appropriators to apply
10 or utilize reasonable conservation measures consistent with good
11 husbandry and other requirements of section 46-231 and consistent with
12 reasonable reliance by other surface water or ground water users on
13 return flows or on seepage to the aquifer; and (d) other reasonable
14 restrictions on surface water use which are consistent with the intent of
15 section 46-715 and the requirements of section 46-231.
16 (2) If during the development of the integrated management plan the
17 Chief Water Officer department determines that surface water
18 appropriators should be required to apply or utilize conservation
19 measures or that other reasonable restrictions on surface water use need
20 to be imposed, the Chief Water Officer's department's portion of the
21 integrated management plan shall allow the affected surface water
22 appropriators and surface water project sponsors a reasonable amount of
23 time, not to exceed one hundred eighty days unless extended by the Chief
24 Water Officer department, to identify the conservation measures to be
25 applied or utilized, to develop a schedule for such application and
26 utilization, and to comment on any other proposed restrictions.

7 Sec. 217. Section 46-718, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
8 amended to read:
9 46-718 (1) If the Chief Water Officer Department of Natural
10 Resources and the affected natural resources districts preparing an
11 integrated management plan reach agreement on (a) the proposed goals and
12 objectives of the plan for the affected river basin, subbasin, or reach,
13 (b) the proposed geographic area to be subject to controls, and (c) the
14 surface water and ground water controls and any incentive programs that
15 are proposed for adoption and implementation in the river basin,
16 subbasin, or reach, they shall schedule one or more public hearings to
17 take testimony on the proposed integrated management plan and the
18 proposed controls. Such hearings shall be held within forty-five days
19 after reaching agreement and within or in reasonable proximity to the
20 area to be affected by implementation of the integrated management plan.
21 Notice of such hearings shall be published as provided in section 46-743.
22 The costs of publishing the notice shall be shared between the Chief
23 Water Officer department and the affected natural resources districts.
24 All interested persons may appear at the hearings and present testimony
25 or provide other evidence relevant to the issues being considered.
26 (2) Within sixty days after the final hearing under this section,
27 the Chief Water Officer department and the affected natural resources
28 districts shall jointly decide whether to implement the plan proposed,
29 with or without modifications, and whether to adopt and implement the
30 surface water and ground water controls and incentive programs proposed
31 in the plan. If the Chief Water Officer department and the natural
-237-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 resources districts agree to implement the plan and to adopt and
2 implement the proposed controls, the natural resources districts shall by
3 order designate a ground water management area for integrated management
4 or, if the geographic area subject to the integrated management plan is
5 already in a ground water management area, the order shall designate an
6 integrated management subarea for that area. The order shall include a
7 geographic and stratigraphic definition of the ground water management
8 area or integrated management subarea and shall adopt the controls in the
9 integrated management plan that are authorized for adoption by the
10 natural resources district pursuant to section 46-739. The Chief Water
11 Officer department shall by order adopt the controls in the integrated
12 management plan that are authorized for adoption by the Chief Water
13 Officer department pursuant to section 46-716. Neither the controls
14 adopted by the district nor those adopted by the Chief Water Officer
15 department shall include controls substantially different from those set
16 forth in the notice of hearing. The area designated as a ground water
17 management area or an integrated management subarea by the natural
18 resources district shall not include any area that was not identified in
19 the notice of the hearing as within the area proposed to be subject to
20 the controls in the plan. The Chief Water Officer department and the
21 natural resources district shall each cause a copy of their respective
22 orders its order to be published in the manner provided in section
23 46-744.
24 (3) If at any time during the development of a basin-wide plan or an
25 integrated management plan either the Chief Water Officer department or
26 the affected natural resources districts conclude that the parties will
27 be unable to reach a timely agreement on the basin-wide plan or on (a)
28 the goals and objectives of the integrated management plan for the
29 affected river basin, subbasin, or reach, (b) the geographic area to be
30 subject to controls, or (c) the surface water or ground water controls or
31 any incentive programs to be proposed for adoption and implementation in
-238-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 the affected river basin, subbasin, or reach, the Governor shall be
2 notified and the dispute shall be submitted to the Interrelated Water
3 Review Board as provided in subsection (2) of section 46-719.
4 Sec. 218. Section 46-719, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
5 amended to read:
6 46-719 (1)(a) The Interrelated Water Review Board is created for the
7 purposes stated in subsections (2) through (5) of this section. The board
8 shall consist of five members. The board, when appointed and convened,
9 shall continue in existence only until it has resolved a dispute referred
10 to it pursuant to such subsections. The Governor shall appoint and
11 convene the board within forty-five days of being notified of the need to
12 resolve a dispute. The board shall be chaired by the Governor or his or
13 her designee, which designee shall be knowledgeable concerning surface
14 water and ground water issues. The Governor shall appoint one additional
15 member of his or her choosing and shall appoint the other three members
16 of the board from a list of no fewer than six nominees provided by the
17 Nebraska Natural Resources Commission within twenty days after request by
18 the Governor for a list of nominees.
19 (b) Not more than two members of the board shall reside in the
20 geographic area involved in the dispute. A person is not eligible for
21 membership on the board if the decisions to be made by the board would or
22 could cause financial benefit or detriment to the person, a member of his
23 or her immediate family, or a business with which the person is
24 associated, unless such benefit or detriment is indistinguishable from
25 the effects of such action on the public generally or a broad segment of
26 the public. The board shall be subject to the Open Meetings Act.
27 (c) For purposes of subsections (2) and (3) of this section, action
28 may be taken by a vote of three of the board's five members. For purposes
29 of subsections (4) and (5) of this section, action may be taken only by a
30 vote of at least four of the board's five members.
31 (2)(a) If the Chief Water Officer Department of Natural Resources
-239-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 and the affected natural resources districts cannot resolve disputes over
2 the content of a basin-wide plan or an integrated management plan by
3 utilizing the process described in sections 46-715 to 46-718, the
4 Governor shall be notified and the dispute submitted to the Interrelated
5 Water Review Board. When the board has been appointed and convened to
6 resolve disputes over a basin-wide plan, the Chief Water Officer
7 department and each affected district shall present their proposed basin-
8 wide plans to the board. When the board has been convened to resolve
9 disputes over an integrated management plan, the Chief Water Officer
10 department and each affected natural resources district shall present
11 their (i) proposed goals and objectives for the integrated management
12 plan, (ii) proposed geographic area to be subject to controls, and (iii)
13 proposed surface water and ground water controls and any proposed
14 incentive program for adoption and implementation in the river basin,
15 subbasin, or reach involved. The Chief Water Officer department and each
16 affected natural resources district shall also be given adequate
17 opportunity to comment on the proposals made by the other parties to the
18 dispute.
19 (b) When the Interrelated Water Review Board concludes that the
20 issues in dispute have been fully presented and commented upon by the
21 parties to the dispute, which conclusion shall be made not more than
22 forty-five days after the board is convened, the board shall select the
23 proposals or portions of proposals that the board will consider for
24 adoption and shall schedule one or more public hearings to take testimony
25 on the selected proposals. The hearings shall be held within forty-five
26 days after the board's selection of proposals to consider for adoption
27 and shall be within or in reasonable proximity to the area that would be
28 affected by implementation of any of the proposals to be considered at
29 the hearings. Notice of the hearings shall be published as provided in
30 section 46-743. The cost of publishing the notice shall be shared by the
31 Chief Water Officer department and the affected natural resources
-240-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 districts. All interested persons may appear at the hearings and present
2 testimony or provide other evidence relevant to the issues being
3 considered.
4 (c) Within forty-five days after the final hearing pursuant to
5 subdivision (b) of this subsection, the Interrelated Water Review Board
6 shall by order, as applicable, adopt a basin-wide plan or an integrated
7 management plan for the affected river basin, subbasin, or reach and, in
8 the case of an integrated management plan, shall designate a ground water
9 management area for integrated management or an integrated management
10 subarea for such river basin, subbasin, or reach. An integrated
11 management plan shall be consistent with subsection (2) of section
12 46-715, and the surface water and ground water controls and any
13 applicable incentive programs adopted as part of that plan shall be
14 consistent with subsection (4) of section 46-715. The controls adopted by
15 the board shall not be substantially different from those described in
16 the notice of hearing. The area designated as a ground water management
17 area or an integrated management subarea shall not include any area that
18 was not identified in the notice of the hearing as within the area
19 proposed to be subject to the controls in the plan.
20 (d) The order adopted under this subsection shall be published in
21 the manner prescribed in section 46-744.
22 (e) Surface water controls adopted by the Interrelated Water Review
23 Board shall be implemented and enforced by the Chief Water Officer
24 department. Ground water controls adopted by the Interrelated Water
25 Review Board shall be implemented and enforced by the affected natural
26 resources districts.
27 (3) Whether an integrated management plan is adopted pursuant to
28 section 46-718 or by the Interrelated Water Review Board pursuant to
29 subsection (2) of this section, the Chief Water Officer department or a
30 natural resources district responsible in part for implementation and
31 enforcement of an integrated management plan may propose modification of
-241-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 the goals or objectives of that plan, of the area subject to the plan, or
2 of the surface water controls, ground water controls, or incentive
3 programs adopted to implement the plan. The Chief Water Officer
4 department and the affected natural resources districts shall utilize the
5 procedures in sections 46-715 to 46-718 in an attempt to reach agreement
6 on and to adopt and implement proposed modifications. If agreement on
7 such modifications cannot be achieved utilizing those procedures, either
8 the Chief Water Officer department or an affected natural resources
9 district may notify the Governor of the dispute. The Interrelated Water
10 Review Board shall be appointed and convened in accordance with
11 subsection (1) of this section to resolve the dispute and, if applicable,
12 to adopt any modifications utilizing the procedures in subsection (2) of
13 this section.
14 (4) The Chief Water Officer department and the affected natural
15 resources districts may also raise objections concerning the
16 implementation or enforcement of previously adopted surface water or
17 ground water controls. The Chief Water Officer department and the
18 affected natural resources districts shall utilize the procedures in
19 sections 46-715 to 46-718 in an attempt to reach agreement on such
20 implementation or enforcement issues. If agreement on such issues cannot
21 be achieved utilizing such procedures, either the Chief Water Officer
22 department or an affected natural resources district may notify the
23 Governor of the dispute. The Interrelated Water Review Board shall be
24 appointed and convened in accordance with subsection (1) of this section.
25 After permitting each party to fully express the its reasons for the its
26 position taken by each party on the disputed issues, the board may either
27 take no action or conclude (a) that one or more parties needs to modify
28 the party's its approach to implementation or enforcement and direct that
29 such modifications take place or (b) that one or more parties either has
30 not made a good faith effort to implement or enforce the portion of the
31 plan or controls for which the party it is responsible or is unable to
-242-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 fully implement and enforce such portion and that such party's
2 jurisdiction with respect to implementation and enforcement of the plan
3 and controls shall be terminated and reassigned to one or more of the
4 other parties responsible for implementation and enforcement. A decision
5 by the Interrelated Water Review Board to terminate and reassign
6 jurisdiction of any portion of the plan or controls shall take effect
7 immediately upon that decision. Notice of such reassignment shall be
8 published at least once in one or more newspapers as necessary to provide
9 general circulation in the area affected by such reassignment.
10 (5) The board may be reconvened in accordance with subsection (1) of
11 this section at a later date upon request to the Governor by the party
12 for which jurisdiction for implementation and enforcement was terminated
13 if such party desires to have the party's its jurisdiction reinstated,
14 but no such request shall be honored until at least one year after the
15 termination and not more than once per year thereafter. The board may
16 reinstate jurisdiction to that party only upon a clear showing by such
17 party that the party it is willing and able to fully implement and
18 enforce the plan and any applicable controls. Notice that a party's
19 jurisdiction has been reinstated shall be provided in the same manner
20 that notice of the earlier termination was given.

18 Sec. 224. Section 46-725, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
19 amended to read:
20 46-725 (1) When determining whether to designate or modify the
21 boundaries of a management area or to require a district which has
22 established a management area, a purpose of which is protection of water
23 quality, to adopt an action plan for the affected area, the director
24 Director of Environment and Energy shall consider:
25 (a) Whether contamination of ground water has occurred or is likely
26 to occur in the reasonably foreseeable future;
27 (b) Whether ground water users, including, but not limited to,
28 domestic, municipal, industrial, and agricultural users, are experiencing
29 or will experience within the foreseeable future substantial economic

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025

2 of contamination;

4 includes the affected area, the controls adopted by the district pursuant
5 to section 46-739 as administered and enforced by the district are
6 sufficient to address the ground water quality issues in the management
7 area; and

9 implement and carry out regulatory activities.

11 that no such area should be established, he or she shall issue an order
12 declaring that no management area shall be designated.

16 required to adopt an action plan, he or she shall consult with relevant
17 state agencies and with the district or districts affected and determine

19 subdivisions and the socioeconomic and administrative factors directly

21 section 46-725 shall, in cooperation with the department Department of
22 Environment and Energy, establish a program to monitor the quality of the
23 ground water in the area and shall if appropriate provide each landowner
24 or operator of an irrigation system with current information available
25 with respect to fertilizer and chemical usage for the specific soil types
26 present and cropping patterns used.

5 Sec. 232. Section 46-736, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
6 amended to read:
7 46-736 An application for a permit or late permit for a water well
8 in a management area shall be denied only if the district in which the
9 water well is to be located finds (1) that the location or operation of
10 the proposed water well or other work would conflict with any regulations
11 or controls adopted by the district, (2) that the proposed use would not
12 be a beneficial use of water, or (3) in the case of a late permit only,
13 that the applicant did not act in good faith in failing to obtain a
14 timely permit.
15 If the district finds that the application is incomplete or
16 defective, it shall return the application for correction. If the
17 correction is not made within sixty days, the application shall be
18 canceled. All permits shall be issued with or without conditions attached
19 or denied not later than thirty days after receipt by the district of a
20 complete and properly prepared application.
21 A permit issued shall specify all regulations and controls adopted
22 by a district relevant to the construction or utilization of the proposed
23 water well. No refund of any application fees shall be made regardless of
24 whether the permit is issued, canceled, or denied. The district shall
25 transmit one copy of each permit issued to the department Director of
26 Natural Resources.

6 amended to read:
7 46-739 (1) A district in which a management area has been designated
8 shall by order adopt one or more of the following controls for the
9 management area:
10 (a) It may allocate the amount of ground water that may be withdrawn
11 by ground water users;
12 (b) It may adopt a system of rotation for use of ground water;
13 (c) It may adopt well-spacing requirements more restrictive than
14 those found in sections 46-609 and 46-651;
15 (d) It may require the installation of devices for measuring ground
16 water withdrawals from water wells;
17 (e) It may adopt a system which requires reduction of irrigated
18 acres pursuant to subsection (2) of section 46-740;
19 (f) It may limit or prevent the expansion of irrigated acres or
20 otherwise limit or prevent increases in the consumptive use of ground
21 water withdrawals from water wells used for irrigation or other
22 beneficial purposes;
23 (g) It may require the use of best management practices;
24 (h) It may require the analysis of water or deep soils for
25 fertilizer and chemical content;
26 (i) It may impose mandatory educational requirements designed to
27 protect water quality or to stabilize or reduce the incidence of ground
28 water depletion, conflicts between ground water users and surface water
29 appropriators, disputes over interstate compacts or decrees, or

1 shall include, but not be limited to, those enumerated in subsection (2)

4 uses, different irrigation distribution systems, or varying climatic,
5 hydrologic, geologic, or soil conditions existing within a management
6 area the uniform application throughout such area of one or more controls
7 would fail to carry out the intent of the Nebraska Ground Water
8 Management and Protection Act in a reasonably effective and equitable
9 manner, the controls adopted by the district pursuant to this section may
10 contain different provisions for different categories of ground water use
11 or portions of the management area which differ from each other because
12 of varying climatic, hydrologic, geologic, or soil conditions. Any
13 differences in such provisions shall recognize and be directed toward

6 amended to read:
7 46-740 (1) If allocation is adopted for use of ground water for

11 allocation shall specify the total number of acre-inches that are

14 period of time. A ground water user may use his or her allocation on all

24 amended to read:
25 46-745 (1) Any person who violates a cease and desist order issued

LB317 LB317

6 violator resides or owns property. The court shall remit the civil

10 receipt, remit the civil penalty to the State Treasurer for credit to the
11 permanent school fund.
12 (2)(a) Prior to issuing a cease and desist order against a public

5 (3) of this section. Money in the fund shall be used to reimburse the
6 office of the Attorney General for the costs incurred in enforcing this

12 46-746 (1) Any person who violates any cease and desist order issued
13 by a district pursuant to section 46-707 or any controls, rules, or
14 regulations adopted by a natural resources district relating to a
15 management area shall be subject to the imposition of penalties imposed
16 through the controls adopted by the district, including, but not limited
17 to, having any allocation of water granted or irrigated acres certified
18 by the district reduced in whole or in part. Before a district takes any
19 action, notice and hearing shall be provided to such person.
20 (2) Any person who violates any of the provisions of sections 46-721
21 to 46-733 for which a penalty is not otherwise provided, other than the
22 requirements imposed on a district, the Chief Water Officer of the
23 Department of Water, Energy, and Environment, the director Director of
24 Natural Resources, or the department Department of Natural Resources,
25 shall be subject to a civil penalty of not more than five hundred
26 dollars. Each day of continued violation shall constitute a separate
27 offense.

10 Sec. 246. Section 46-754, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
11 amended to read:
12 46-754 The Interrelated Water Management Plan Program is created for

14 under the Nebraska Ground Water Management and Protection Act. The

16 Natural Resources Commission and the Chief Water Officer Department of
17 Natural Resources upon recommendations of the commission using funds
18 appropriated for the program. The commission shall develop guidelines and
19 limitations for grant requests for funding such district's duties,
20 including studies required to carry out those duties. Grant requests
21 shall be made to the commission for review in a manner and form
22 prescribed by the commission. The amounts requested and approved shall be
23 supported by a minimum local revenue match comprising twenty percent of
24 the total project cost. The Chief Water Officer Director of Natural
25 Resources shall expend funds to implement the commission's
26 recommendations for fiscal support under the program only upon the
27 commission's approval.

29 amended to read:
30 46-755 This section shall apply notwithstanding any other provision
31 of the Nebraska Ground Water Management and Protection Act.
-272-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (1) If a river basin as described in subdivision (2)(a) of section
2 2-1504 includes three or more natural resources districts that, pursuant
3 to subdivision (1)(a) of section 46-715, have been or are required to
4 develop an integrated management plan for all or substantially all
5 (eighty-five percent) of the district, such natural resources districts
6 shall, jointly with the Chief Water Officer department and the natural
7 resources districts within the same basin, develop and adopt a basin-wide
8 plan for the areas of a basin, subbasin, or reach determined by the
9 department to have hydrologically connected water supplies, except that
10 any natural resources district that has developed and implemented a
11 basin-wide plan pursuant to subsection (5) of section 46-715 shall not be
12 affected by this section. If deemed appropriate by the Chief Water
13 Officer department and the affected natural resources districts, the
14 basin-wide plan may combine two or more river basins.
15 (2) An integrated management plan developed under subdivision (1)(a)
16 or (b) of section 46-715 shall ensure such integrated management plan is
17 consistent with any basin-wide plan developed pursuant to this section.
18 However, an integrated management plan may implement additional incentive
19 programs or controls pursuant to section 46-739 if the programs and
20 controls are consistent with the basin-wide plan.
21 (3) A basin-wide plan shall be completed, adopted, and take effect
22 within three years after April 17, 2014, unless the Chief Water Officer
23 department and the natural resources districts jointly agree to an
24 extension of not more than an additional two years.
25 (4) A basin-wide plan shall (a) have clear goals and objectives with
26 a purpose of sustaining a balance between water uses and water supplies
27 so that the economic viability, social and environmental health, safety,
28 and welfare of the river basin, subbasin, or reach can be achieved and
29 maintained for both the near term and the long term, (b) ensure that
30 compliance with any interstate compact or decree or other formal state
31 contract or agreement or applicable state or federal law is maintained,
-273-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 and (c) set forth a timeline to meet the goals and objectives as required
2 under this subdivision, but in no case shall a timeline exceed thirty
3 years after April 17, 2014.
4 (5)(a) A basin-wide plan developed under this section shall utilize
5 the best generally-accepted methodologies and available information,
6 data, and science to evaluate the effect of existing uses of
7 hydrologically connected water on existing surface water and ground water
8 users. The plan shall include a process to gather and evaluate data,
9 information, and methodologies to increase understanding of the surface
10 water and hydrologically connected ground water system within the basin,
11 subbasin, or reach and test the validity of the conclusions, information,
12 and assumptions upon which the plan is based.
13 (b) A basin-wide plan developed under this section shall include a
14 schedule indicating the end date by which the stated goals and objectives
15 are to be achieved and the management actions to be taken to achieve the
16 goals and objectives. To ensure that reasonable progress is being made
17 toward achieving the final goals and objectives of the plan, the schedule
18 shall also include measurable hydrologic objectives and intermediate
19 dates by which the objectives are expected to be met and monitoring plans
20 to measure the extent to which the objectives are being achieved. Such
21 intermediate objectives shall be established in a manner that, if
22 achieved on schedule, will provide a reasonable expectation that the
23 goals of the plan will be achieved by the established end date.
24 (c) A basin-wide plan shall be developed using a consultation and
25 collaboration process involving representatives from irrigation
26 districts, reclamation districts, public power and irrigation districts,
27 mutual irrigation companies, canal companies, ground water users, range
28 livestock owners, the Game and Parks Commission, and municipalities that
29 rely on water from within the affected area and that, after being
30 notified of the commencement of the plan development process, indicate in
31 writing their desire to become an official participant in such process.
-274-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 The Chief Water Officer department and affected natural resources
2 districts shall involve official participants in formulating, evaluating,
3 and recommending plans and management actions and work to reach an
4 agreement among all official participants involved in a basin-wide plan.
5 In addition, the Chief Water Officer department or the affected natural
6 resources districts may include designated representatives of other
7 stakeholders. If agreement is reached by all parties involved in such
8 consultation and collaboration process, the Chief Water Officer
9 department and the affected natural resources districts shall adopt the
10 agreed-upon basin-wide plan. If agreement cannot be reached by all
11 parties involved, the basin-wide plan shall be developed and adopted by
12 the Chief Water Officer department and the affected natural resources
13 districts or by the Interrelated Water Review Board pursuant to section
14 46-719.
15 (d) Within five years after the adoption of the basin-wide plan, and
16 every five years thereafter, the Chief Water Officer department and
17 affected natural resources districts shall conduct a technical analysis
18 of the actions taken in a river basin to determine the progress towards
19 meeting the goals and objectives of the plan. The analysis shall include
20 an examination of (i) available supplies, current uses, and changes in
21 long-term water availability, (ii) the effects of conservation practices
22 and natural causes, including, but not limited to, drought, and (iii) the
23 effects of the plan in meeting the goal of sustaining a balance between
24 water uses and water supplies. The analysis shall determine if changes or
25 modifications to the basin-wide plan are needed to meet the goals and
26 objectives pursuant to subdivision (4)(a) of this section. The Chief
27 Water Officer department and affected natural resources districts shall
28 present the results of the analysis and any recommended modifications to
29 the plan at a public meeting and shall provide for at least a thirty-day
30 public comment period before holding a public hearing on the recommended
31 modifications. The Chief Water Officer department shall submit a report
-275-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 to the Legislature of the results of this analysis and the progress made
2 under the basin-wide plan. The report shall be submitted electronically.
3 Any official participant or stakeholder may submit comments to the Chief
4 Water Officer department and affected natural resources districts on the
5 final basin-wide plan adopted by the Chief Water Officer department and
6 affected natural resources districts, which shall be made a part of the
7 report to the Legislature.
8 (e) Before adoption of a basin-wide plan, the Chief Water Officer
9 department and affected natural resources districts shall schedule at
10 least one public hearing to take testimony on the proposed plan. Any such
11 hearings shall be held in reasonable proximity to the area affected by
12 the plan. Notice of hearings shall be published as provided in section
13 46-743. All interested persons may appear at any hearings and present
14 testimony or provide other evidence relevant to the issues under
15 consideration. Within sixty days after the final hearing, the Chief Water
16 Officer department and affected natural resources districts shall jointly
17 determine whether to adopt the plan.
18 (f) The Chief Water Officer department and the affected natural
19 resources districts may utilize, when necessary, the Interrelated Water
20 Review Board process provided in section 46-719 for disputes arising from
21 developing, implementing, and enforcing a basin-wide plan developed under
22 this section.

2 Sec. 257. Section 46-1102, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
3 amended to read:
4 46-1102 The Legislature finds that the use of chemigation throughout
5 the state is increasing and that, although chemigation provides a viable
6 alternative to other means of chemical application, if an irrigation
7 distribution system is not properly equipped or if a chemical is not used
8 with proper precautions, there exists a potential to contaminate the
9 water.
10 The Legislature also finds that complete information as to the
11 occurrences and use of chemigation in this state is essential to the
12 development of a sound state water management policy.
13 For these reasons, the Legislature deems it necessary to provide the
14 natural resources districts and the Department of Water, Energy, and
15 Environment Environment and Energy with the authority to document,
16 monitor, regulate, and enforce chemigation practices in Nebraska.

10 constitute a conflict of interest. As soon as a member is aware of a

12 conflict, whichever is sooner, the member shall submit a written
13 statement to the Director of Water, Energy, and Environment Environment

15 nature of the potential conflict. The member shall take such action as

17 influence over the action or decision on the matter. For purposes of this
18 section, conflict of interest includes financial, professional, or
19 personal obligations that may compromise or present the appearance of

13 (2) The board shall set fees for licensing individuals under the
14 Water Well Standards and Contractors' Practice Act for application for,
15 issuance of, and renewal of licenses. The fees shall be waived for
16 initial licenses for low-income individuals, military families, and young
17 workers as those terms are defined in the Uniform Credentialing Act.
18 (3) The board shall set a fee of not less than twenty-five dollars
19 and not more than forty dollars for each water well which is required to
20 be registered and which is designed and constructed to pump fifty gallons
21 per minute or less and each monitoring and observation well and a fee of
22 not less than forty dollars and not more than eighty dollars for each
23 water well which is required to be registered and which is designed and
24 constructed to pump more than fifty gallons per minute. For water wells
25 permitted pursuant to the Industrial Ground Water Regulatory Act, the fee
26 set pursuant to this subsection shall be collected for each of the first
27 ten such water wells registered, and for each group of ten or fewer such
28 water wells registered thereafter, the fee shall be collected as if only
29 one water well was being registered. For a series of two or more water
30 wells completed and pumped into a common carrier, as defined in section
31 46-601.01, as part of a single site plan for irrigation purposes, the fee
-285-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 set pursuant to this subsection shall be collected for each of the first
2 two such water wells registered. For a series of water wells completed
3 for purposes of installation of a ground heat exchanger for a structure
4 for utilizing the geothermal properties of the ground, the fee set
5 pursuant to this subsection shall be collected as if only one water well
6 was being registered. For water wells constructed as part of a single
7 site plan for monitoring ground water, obtaining hydrogeologic
8 information, or extracting contaminants from the ground and for water
9 wells constructed as part of remedial action approved by the department
10 Department of Environment and Energy pursuant to section 66-1525,
11 66-1529.02, or 81-15,124, the fee set pursuant to this subsection shall
12 be collected for each of the first five such water wells registered, and
13 for each group of five or fewer such water wells registered thereafter,
14 the fee shall be collected as if only one water well was being
15 registered. The fees shall be remitted to the Director of Water, Energy,
16 and Environment Natural Resources with the registration form required by
17 section 46-602 and shall be in addition to the fee in section 46-606. The
18 director shall remit the fee to the State Treasurer for credit to the
19 Water Well Standards and Contractors' Licensing Fund.
20 (4) The board shall set an application fee for a declaratory ruling
21 or variance of not less than fifty dollars and not more than one hundred
22 dollars. The fee shall be remitted to the State Treasurer for credit to
23 the Water Well Standards and Contractors' Licensing Fund.

28 generally accepted engineering practice, determines that construction of
29 such structures would require that such dam be reclassified as having a

20 Sec. 292. Section 46-1654, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is

22 46-1654 (1) Approval of applications for which approval under

24 days after receipt of the completed application plus any extensions of
25 time required to resolve matters diligently pursued by the applicant. At
26 the discretion of the Chief Water Officer department, one or more public
27 hearings may be held on an application.
28 (2) Approval of applications under the Safety of Dams and Reservoirs
29 Act, for which approval under sections 46-233 to 46-242 is required,
30 shall not be issued until all pending matters before the Chief Water
31 Officer department under the Safety of Dams and Reservoirs Act or such
-301-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 sections have been resolved and approved.
2 (3) Application approval shall be granted with terms, conditions,
3 and limitations necessary to safeguard life and property.
4 (4) If actual construction, reconstruction, enlargement, alteration,
5 breach, removal, or abandonment of the dam is not commenced within the
6 time established by the Chief Water Officer department, the application
7 approval becomes void, except that the Chief Water Officer department
8 may, upon written application and for good cause shown, extend the time
9 for commencing construction, reconstruction, enlargement, alteration,
10 breach, removal, or abandonment. If approval under sections 46-233 to
11 46-242 is also required, the Chief Water Officer department may not
12 extend the time for commencing construction without following the
13 procedures and granting a similar extension under subsection (2) of
14 section 46-238.
15 (5) Written notice shall be provided to the Chief Water Officer
16 department at least ten days before construction, reconstruction,
17 enlargement, alteration, breach, removal, or abandonment is to begin and
18 such other notices shall be given to the Chief Water Officer department
19 as the Chief Water Officer it may require.
20 Sec. 293. Section 46-1655, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
21 amended to read:
22 46-1655 (1) The application for approval of construction,
23 reconstruction, enlargement, alteration, breach, removal, or abandonment
24 of a dam shall be accompanied by a filing fee as established by rule and
25 regulation of the Chief Water Officer department but not to exceed (a)
26 two hundred dollars for a dam less than twenty-five feet in height, (b)
27 three hundred dollars for a dam twenty-five feet in height to not more
28 than fifty feet in height, and (c) four hundred dollars for a dam in
29 excess of fifty feet in height.
30 (2) Only one filing fee shall be collected for an enlargement by
31 flashboards, sandbags, earthen levees, gates, or other works, devices, or
-302-
ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 obstructions which are from time to time to be removed and replaced or
2 opened and shut and thereby operated so as to vary the surface elevation
3 of the reservoir.
4 (3) A dam subject to the Safety of Dams and Reservoirs Act and for
5 which plans and specifications have been approved prior to September 4,
6 2005, shall not be required to pay any additional fee or submit an
7 additional application for approval unless such dam requires
8 reconstruction, enlargement, alteration, breach, removal, or abandonment.
9 (4) An application shall not be considered by the Chief Water
10 Officer department until the filing fee is received.
11 (5) Fees collected by the department under this section shall be
12 remitted to the State Treasurer for credit to the Dam Safety Cash Fund.
13 Sec. 294. Section 46-1656, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
14 amended to read:
15 46-1656 The Dam Safety Cash Fund is created. The fund shall consist
16 of fees credited pursuant to section 46-1655 and any money specifically
17 appropriated to the fund by the Legislature. Money in the fund shall not
18 be subject to any fiscal-year limitation or provision for lapse of
19 unexpended balance at the end of any fiscal year or biennium. The fund
20 shall be administered by the department. Money in the fund may be
21 expended by the department for costs incurred by the department or the
22 Chief Water Officer in the administration of the Safety of Dams and
23 Reservoirs Act. Any money in the fund available for investment shall be
24 invested by the state investment officer pursuant to the Nebraska Capital
25 Expansion Act and the Nebraska State Funds Investment Act.

15 Sec. 298. Section 46-1660, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
16 amended to read:
17 46-1660 (1) Each approval to operate issued by the Chief Water
18 Officer department under the Safety of Dams and Reservoirs Act shall
19 contain such terms and conditions as the Chief Water Officer department
20 may prescribe.
21 (2) The Chief Water Officer department shall revoke, suspend, or
22 amend any approval to operate whenever it determines that the dam
23 constitutes a danger to life and property.
24 (3) Before any approval to operate is revoked by the Chief Water
25 Officer department, the Chief Water Officer department shall hold a

27 be mailed to the owner at least thirty days before the date set for the

1 46-1661 (1) Upon receipt of a written complaint alleging that the

4 of any dam, the Chief Water Officer department shall cause an inspection

6 reports on file are found adequate to make a determination whether the

9 (2) If it is found that an unsafe condition exists, the Chief Water

11 as is necessary to correct the condition, including breaching or removal
12 of any dam found to be beyond repair.
13 Sec. 300. Section 46-1662, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is

20 design engineer to provide adequate supervision during construction,

-306-
ER36 ER36

10 specifications are not being or have not been complied with, and shall
11 order immediate compliance with the approved plans and specifications.

15 of this section may cause revocation of application approval by the Chief
16 Water Officer department. If compliance with the notice has not occurred
17 within sixty days after the date of the notice, the Chief Water Officer
18 department shall order the incomplete structure removed sufficiently to
19 eliminate any safety hazard to life.
