10 Sec. 24. Section 2-2626, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
11 amended to read:
12 2-2626 The department shall have the following powers, functions,
13 and duties:
14 (1) To administer, implement, and enforce the Pesticide Act and
15 serve as the lead state agency for the regulation of pesticides. The
16 department shall involve the natural resources districts and other state
17 agencies, including the Department of Water, Energy, and Environment
18 Environment and Energy or the Department of Natural Resources, in matters
19 relating to water quality. Nothing in the act shall be interpreted in any
20 way to affect the powers of any other state agency or of any natural
21 resources district to regulate for ground water quality or surface water
22 quality as otherwise provided by law;
23 (2) To be responsible for the development and implementation of a
24 state management plan and pesticide management plans. The Department of
25 Water, Energy, and Environment Environment and Energy shall be
26 responsible for the adoption of standards for pesticides in surface
27 water, ground water, and drinking water. These standards shall be
28 established as action levels in the state management plan and pesticide
29 management plans at which prevention and mitigation measures are
30 implemented. Such action levels may be set at or below the maximum
31 contaminant level set for any product as set by the federal agency under
-26-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 the federal Safe Drinking Water Act, 42 U.S.C. 300f et seq., as the act
2 existed on January 1, 2021. The Department of Agriculture shall cooperate
3 with and use existing expertise in other state agencies when developing
4 the state management plan and pesticide management plans and shall not
5 hire a hydrologist within the department for such purpose;
6 (3) After notice and public hearing, to adopt and promulgate rules
7 and regulations providing lists of state-limited-use pesticides for the
8 entire state or for a designated area within the state, subject to the
9 following:
10 (a) A pesticide shall be included on a list of state-limited-use
11 pesticides if:
12 (i) The Department of Agriculture determines that the pesticide,
13 when used in accordance with its directions for use, warnings, and
14 cautions and for uses for which it is registered, may without additional
15 regulatory restrictions cause unreasonable adverse effects on humans or
16 the environment, including injury to the applicator or other persons
17 because of acute dermal or inhalation toxicity of the pesticides;
18 (ii) The water quality standards set by the Department of Water,
19 Energy, and Environment Environment and Energy pursuant to this section
20 are exceeded; or
21 (iii) The Department of Agriculture determines that the pesticide
22 requires additional restrictions to meet the requirements of the
23 Pesticide Act, the federal act, or any plan adopted under the Pesticide
24 Act or the federal act;
25 (b) The Department of Agriculture may regulate the specific time,
26 locations, and conditions restricting the use of a state-limited-use
27 pesticide, including allowable quantities or concentrations, and may
28 require that it be purchased or possessed only with permission or under
29 the direct supervision of the department or its designee;
30 (c) The Department of Agriculture may require a person authorized to
31 distribute or use a state-limited-use pesticide to maintain records of
-27-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 the person's distribution or use and may require that the records be kept
2 separate from other business records;
3 (d) The state management plan and pesticide management plans shall
4 be coordinated with the Department of Agriculture and other state agency
5 plans and with other state agencies and with natural resources districts;
6 (e) The state management plan and pesticide management plans may
7 impose progressively more rigorous pesticide management practices as
8 pesticides are detected in ground water or surface water at increasing
9 fractions of the standards adopted by the Department of Water, Energy,
10 and Environment Environment and Energy; and
11 (f) A pesticide management plan may impose progressively more
12 rigorous pesticide management practices to address any unreasonable
13 adverse effect of pesticides on humans or the environment. When
14 appropriate, a pesticide management plan may establish action levels for
15 imposition of such progressively more rigorous management practices based
16 upon measurable indicators of the adverse effect on humans or the
17 environment;
18 (4) To adopt and promulgate such rules and regulations as are
19 necessary for the enforcement and administration of the Pesticide Act.
20 The regulations may include, but not be limited to, regulations providing
21 for:
22 (a) The collection of samples, examination of records, and reporting
23 of information by persons subject to the act;
24 (b) The safe handling, transportation, storage, display,
25 distribution, use, and disposal of pesticides and their containers;
26 (c) Labeling requirements of all pesticides required to be
27 registered under provisions of the act, except that such regulations
28 shall not impose any requirements for federally registered labels
29 contrary to those required pursuant to the federal act;
30 (d) Classes of devices which shall be subject to the Pesticide Act;
31 (e) Reporting and record-keeping requirements for persons
-28-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 distributing or using pesticide products made available under 7 U.S.C.
2 136i-1 of the federal act and for persons required to keep records under
3 the Pesticide Act;
4 (f) Methods to be used in the application of pesticides when the
5 Department of Agriculture finds that such regulations are necessary to
6 carry out the purpose and intent of the Pesticide Act. Such regulations
7 may include methods to be used in the application of a restricted-use
8 pesticide or state-limited-use pesticide, may relate to the time, place,
9 manner, methods, materials, amounts, and concentrations in connection
10 with the use of the pesticide, may restrict or prohibit use of the
11 pesticides in designated areas during specified periods of time, and may
12 provide specific examples and technical interpretations of subdivision
13 (4) of section 2-2646. The regulations shall encompass all reasonable
14 factors which the department deems necessary to prevent damage or injury
15 by drift or misapplication to (i) plants, including forage plants, or
16 adjacent or nearby property, (ii) wildlife in the adjoining or nearby
17 areas, (iii) fish and other aquatic life in waters in reasonable
18 proximity to the area to be treated, (iv) surface water or ground water,
19 and (v) humans, animals, or beneficial insects. In adopting and
20 promulgating such regulations, the department shall give consideration to
21 pertinent research findings and recommendations of other agencies of the
22 state, the federal government, or other reliable sources. The department
23 may, by regulation, require that notice of a proposed use of a pesticide
24 be given to landowners whose property is adjacent to the property to be
25 treated or in the immediate vicinity thereof if the department finds that
26 such notice is necessary to carry out the purpose of the act;
27 (g) State-limited-use pesticides for the state or for designated
28 areas in the state;
29 (h) Establishment of the amount of any fee or fine as directed by
30 the act;
31 (i) Establishment of the components of any state management plan or
-29-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 pesticide management plan;
2 (j) Establishment of categories for licensed pesticide applicators
3 in addition to those established in 40 C.F.R. part 171, as such
4 regulations existed on January 1, 2019; and
5 (k) Establishment of a process for the issuance of permits for
6 emergency-use pesticides made available under 7 U.S.C. 136p of the
7 federal act;
8 (5) To enter any public or private premises at any reasonable time
9 to:
10 (a) Inspect and sample any equipment authorized or required to be
11 inspected under the Pesticide Act or to inspect the premises on which the
12 equipment is kept or stored;
13 (b) Inspect or sample any area exposed or reported to be exposed to
14 a pesticide or where a pesticide use has occurred;
15 (c) Inspect and sample any area where a pesticide is disposed of or
16 stored;
17 (d) Observe the use and application of and sample any pesticide;
18 (e) Inspect and copy any records relating to the distribution or use
19 of any pesticide or the issuance of any license, permit, or registration
20 under the act; or
21 (f) Inspect, examine, or take samples from any application
22 equipment, building, or place owned, controlled, or operated by any
23 person engaging in an activity regulated by the act if, from probable
24 cause, it appears that the application equipment, building, or place
25 contains a pesticide;
26 (6) To sample, inspect, make analysis of, and test any pesticide
27 found within this state;
28 (7) To issue and enforce a written or printed order to stop the
29 sale, removal, or use of a pesticide if the Department of Agriculture has
30 reason to believe that the pesticide or use of the pesticide is in
31 violation of any provision of the act. The department shall present the
-30-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 order to the owner or custodian of the pesticide. The person who receives
2 the order shall not distribute, remove, or use the pesticide until the
3 department determines that the pesticide or its use is in compliance with
4 the act. This subdivision shall not limit the right of the department to
5 proceed as authorized by any other provision of the act;
6 (8)(a) To sue in the name of the director to enjoin any violation of
7 the act. Venue for such action shall be in the county in which the
8 alleged violation occurred, is occurring, or is threatening to occur; and
9 (b) To request the county attorney or the Attorney General to bring
10 suit to enjoin a violation or threatened violation of the act;
11 (9) To impose or levy an administrative fine of not more than five
12 thousand dollars for each violation on any person who has violated any
13 provision, requirement, condition, limitation, or duty imposed by the act
14 or rules and regulations adopted and promulgated pursuant to the act. A
15 violation means each action which violates any separate or distinct
16 provision, requirement, condition, limitation, or duty imposed by the act
17 or rules and regulations adopted and promulgated pursuant to the act;
18 (10) To cause a violation warning letter to be served upon the
19 alleged violator or violators pursuant to the act;
20 (11) To take reasonable measures to assess and collect all fees and
21 fines prescribed by the act and the rules or regulations adopted under
22 the act;
23 (12) To access, inspect, and copy all books, papers, records, bills
24 of lading, invoices, and other information relating to the use,
25 manufacture, repackaging, and distribution of pesticides necessary for
26 the enforcement of the act;
27 (13) To seize, for use as evidence, without formal warrant if
28 probable cause exists, any pesticide which is in violation of the act or
29 is not approved by the Department of Agriculture or which is found to be
30 used or distributed in the violation of the act or the rules and
31 regulations adopted and promulgated under it;
-31-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (14) To adopt classifications of restricted-use pesticides as
2 determined by the federal agency under the federal act. In addition to
3 the restricted-use pesticides classified by the administrator, the
4 Department of Agriculture may also determine state-limited-use pesticides
5 for the state or for designated areas within the state as provided in
6 subdivision (3) of this section;
7 (15) To receive grants-in-aid from any federal entity, and to enter
8 into cooperative agreements with any federal entity, any agency of this
9 state, any subdivision of this state, any agency of another state, any
10 Indian tribe, or any private person for the purpose of obtaining
11 consistency with or assistance in the implementation of the Pesticide
12 Act. The Department of Agriculture may reimburse any such entity from the
13 Pesticide Administrative Cash Fund for the work performed under the

12 contained in this section shall prevent the district from establishing

4 Sec. 31. Section 2-4602, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
5 amended to read:
6 2-4602 The Legislature recognizes that erosion and sedimentation are
7 serious problems throughout the state. Changes in farm and ranch
8 enterprises, operations, and ownership, demands made upon farm and ranch
9 enterprises which do not encourage sound resource utilization, rapid
10 shifts in land use from agricultural and rural to nonagricultural and
11 urban uses, construction of streets, highways, pipelines, recreation
12 areas, schools and universities, public utilities and facilities,
13 conversion of grasslands to croplands, and other land-disturbing
14 activities have caused excessive wind erosion and water runoff and
15 accelerated the process of soil erosion and sediment deposition. This has
16 resulted in the pollution of the waters of the state and damage to
17 domestic, agricultural, industrial, recreational, fish and wildlife, and
18 other resources. It is declared to be the policy of the state to
19 strengthen and extend the present erosion and sediment control activities
20 and programs of the state for both rural and urban lands, to improve
21 water quality, and to establish and implement, through the Director of
22 Water, Energy, and Environment Natural Resources and the Nebraska Natural
23 Resources Commission, a statewide, comprehensive, and coordinated erosion
24 and sediment control program to reduce damage from wind erosion and storm
25 water runoff, to retard nonpoint pollution from sediment and related
26 pollutants, and to conserve and protect land, air, and other resources of
27 the state. This program shall be carried out by the natural resources
28 districts in cooperation with the counties, municipalities, and other
29 local governments and political subdivisions of the state and other
30 public and private entities.
31 Sec. 32. Section 2-4603, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
-41-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 amended to read:
2 2-4603 For purposes of the Erosion and Sediment Control Act, unless
3 the context otherwise requires:
4 (1) Commission means the Nebraska Natural Resources Commission;
5 (2) Conservation agreement means an agreement between the owner or
6 operator of a farm unit and the district in which the owner or operator
7 agrees to implement a farm unit conservation plan or, with the approval
8 of the district within which the farm unit is located, a portion of a
9 farm unit conservation plan. The agreement shall include a schedule for
10 implementation and may be conditioned on the district or other public
11 entity furnishing technical, planning, or financial assistance in the
12 establishment of the soil and water conservation practices necessary to
13 implement the plan or a portion of the plan;
14 (3) Director means the Director of Water, Energy, and Environment
15 Natural Resources;
16 (4) District means a natural resources district;
17 (5) Erosion or sediment control practice means:
18 (a) The construction or installation and maintenance of permanent
19 structures or devices necessary to carry, to a suitable outlet away from
20 any building site, any commercial or industrial development, or any
21 publicly or privately owned recreational or service facility not served
22 by a central storm sewer system, any water which would otherwise cause
23 erosion in excess of the applicable soil-loss tolerance level and which
24 does not carry or constitute sewage or industrial or other waste;
25 (b) The employment of temporary devices or structures, temporary
26 seeding, fiber mats, plastic, straw, diversions, silt fences, sediment
27 traps, or other measures adequate either to prevent erosion in excess of
28 the applicable soil-loss tolerance level or to prevent excessive
29 downstream sedimentation from land which is the site of or is directly
30 affected by any nonagricultural land-disturbing activity; or
31 (c) The establishment and maintenance of vegetation upon the right-
-42-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 of-way of any completed portion of any public street, road, or highway or
2 the construction or installation thereon of permanent structures or
3 devices or other measures adequate to prevent erosion of the right-of-way
4 in excess of the applicable soil-loss tolerance level;
5 (6) Excess erosion means the occurrence of erosion in excess of the
6 applicable soil-loss tolerance level which causes or contributes to an
7 accumulation of sediment upon the lands of any other person to the
8 detriment or damage of such other person;
9 (7) Farm unit conservation plan means a plan jointly developed by
10 the owner and, if appropriate, the operator of a farm unit and the
11 district within which the farm unit is located based upon the determined
12 conservation needs for the farm unit and identifying the soil and water
13 conservation practices which may be expected to prevent soil loss by
14 erosion from that farm unit in excess of the applicable soil-loss
15 tolerance level. The plan may also, if practicable, identify alternative
16 practices by which such objective may be attained;
17 (8) Nonagricultural land-disturbing activity means a land change,
18 including, but not limited to, tilling, clearing, grading, excavating,
19 transporting, or filling land, which may result in soil erosion from wind
20 or water and the movement of sediment and sediment-related pollutants
21 into the waters of the state or onto lands in the state but does not
22 include the following:
23 (a) Activities related directly to the production of agricultural,
24 horticultural, or silvicultural crops, including, but not limited to,
25 tilling, planting, or harvesting of such crops;
26 (b) Installation of aboveground public utility lines and
27 connections, fenceposts, sign posts, telephone poles, electric poles, and
28 other kinds of posts or poles;
29 (c) Emergency work to protect life or property;
30 (d) Activities related to the construction of housing, industrial,
31 and commercial developments on sites under two acres in size; and
-43-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (e) Activities related to the operation, construction, or
2 maintenance of industrial or commercial public power district or public
3 power and irrigation district facilities or sites when such activity is
4 conducted pursuant to state or federal law or is part of the operational
5 plan for such facility or site;
6 (9) Person means any individual, partnership, limited liability
7 company, firm, association, joint venture, public or private corporation,
8 trust, estate, commission, board, institution, utility, cooperative,
9 municipality or other political subdivision of this state, interstate
10 body, or other legal entity;
11 (10) Soil and water conservation practice means a practice which
12 serves to prevent erosion of soil by wind or water in excess of the
13 applicable soil-loss tolerance level from land used only for
14 agricultural, horticultural, or silvicultural purposes. Soil and water
15 conservation practice includes, but is not limited to:
16 (a) Permanent soil and water conservation practice, including the
17 planting of perennial grasses, legumes, shrubs, or trees, the
18 establishment of grassed waterways, the construction of terraces, and
19 other permanent soil and water practices approved by the district; and
20 (b) Temporary soil and water conservation practice, including the
21 planting of annual or biennial crops, use of strip-cropping, contour
22 planting, minimum or mulch tillage, and other cultural practices approved
23 by the district; and
24 (11) Soil-loss tolerance level means the maximum amount of soil loss
25 due to erosion by wind or water, expressed in terms of tons per acre per
26 year, which is determined to be acceptable in accordance with the Erosion
27 and Sediment Control Act. Soil loss may be impacted by water erosion
28 which may include (a) sheet and rill erosion which includes relatively
29 uniform soil loss across the entire field slope which may leave small
30 channels located at regular intervals across the slope and (b) ephemeral
31 gully erosion which occurs in well-defined depressions or natural
-44-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 drainageways where concentrated overland flow results in the convergence

3 Sec. 33. Section 2-4604, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
4 amended to read:
5 2-4604 (1) The director shall, in cooperation with the commission,
6 the Department of Environment and Energy, the Natural Resources
7 Conservation Service of the United States Department of Agriculture, and
8 other appropriate state and federal agencies, develop and coordinate a
9 comprehensive state erosion and sediment control program designed to
10 reduce soil erosion in this state to tolerable levels. The program, which
11 shall be reasonable and attainable, shall include:
12 (a) The soil-loss tolerance level for the various types of soils in
13 the state;
14 (b) State goals and a state strategy for reducing soil losses on all
15 lands in the state to an amount no more than the applicable soil-loss
16 tolerance level;
17 (c) Guidelines for establishing priorities for implementation of the
18 program at the state and local levels;
19 (d) Types of assistance to be provided by the state to districts,
20 cities, and counties in the implementation of the state and local erosion
21 and sediment control programs; and
22 (e) Such other elements as the director deems appropriate in
23 accordance with the objectives of the Erosion and Sediment Control Act,
24 including any recommendations for further legislative or administrative
25 action.
26 (2) The state erosion and sediment control program may be revised by
27 the director and the commission at any time. Before approving any such
28 changes, the director and the commission shall conduct at least four
29 public hearings or meetings to receive information from interested
30 persons in different parts of the state.

7 Nebraska Emergency Management Agency, and the Conservation and Survey
8 Division and Cooperative Extension Service of the University of Nebraska.

24 expenses as provided in sections 81-1174 to 81-1177.
25 (2) The committee shall meet at least twice each year and shall meet
26 more frequently (a) at the call of the chairperson, (b) upon request of a
27 majority of the committee members, and (c) during periods of drought or
28 other severe climate situations.

1 is amended to read:
2 13-2042.01 (1) The department Department of Environment and Energy
3 shall rebate to the municipality or county of origin ten cents of the
4 disposal fee required by section 13-2042 for solid waste disposed of at
5 landfills regulated by the department or transported for disposal out of
6 state from a solid waste processing facility holding a permit under the
7 Integrated Solid Waste Management Act and when such solid waste
8 originated in a municipality or county with a purchasing policy approved
9 by the department. The fee shall be rebated on a schedule agreed upon
10 between the municipality or county and the department. The schedule shall
11 be no more often than quarterly and no less often than annually.
12 (2) Any municipality or county may apply to the department for the
13 rebate authorized in subsection (1) of this section if the municipality
14 or county has a written purchasing policy in effect requiring a
15 preference for purchasing products, materials, or supplies which are
16 manufactured or produced from recycled material. The policy shall provide
17 that the preference shall not operate when it would result in the
18 purchase of products, materials, or supplies which are of inadequate
19 quality as determined by the municipality or county. Upon receipt of an
20 application, the department Department of Environment and Energy shall
21 submit the application to the materiel division of the Department of
22 Administrative Services for review. The materiel division shall review
23 the application for compliance with this section and any rules and
24 regulations adopted pursuant to this section and to determine the
25 probable effectiveness in assuring that a preference is given to
26 products, materials, or supplies which are manufactured or produced from
27 recycled material. The materiel division shall provide a report of its
28 findings to the Department of Water, Energy, and Environment Department
29 of Environment and Energy within thirty days after receiving the review
30 request. The department Department of Environment and Energy shall
31 approve the application or suggest modifications to the application
-48-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 within sixty days after receiving the application based on the materiel
2 division's report, any analysis by the department Department of
3 Environment and Energy, and any factors affecting compliance with this
4 section or the rules and regulations adopted pursuant to this section.
5 (3) A municipality or county shall file a report complying with the
6 rules and regulations adopted pursuant to this section with the
7 Department of Water, Energy, and Environment Department of Environment
8 and Energy before April 1 of each year documenting purchasing practices
9 for the past calendar year in order to continue receiving the rebate. The
10 report shall include, but not be limited to, quantities of products,
11 materials, or supplies purchased which were manufactured or produced from
12 recycled material. The department shall provide copies of each report to
13 the materiel division in a timely manner. If the department determines
14 that a municipality or county is not following the purchasing policy
15 presented in the approved application or that the purchasing policy
16 presented in the approved application is not effective in assuring that a
17 preference is given to products, materials, or supplies which are
18 manufactured or produced from recycled material, the department shall
19 suspend the rebate until it determines that the municipality or county is
20 giving a preference to products, materials, or supplies which are
21 manufactured or produced from recycled material pursuant to a written
22 purchasing policy approved by the department subsequent to the
23 suspension. The materiel division may make recommendations to the
24 department regarding suspensions and reinstatements of rebates. The
25 Department of Administrative Services may adopt and promulgate rules and
26 regulations establishing procedures for reviewing applications and for
27 annual reports.
28 (4) Any suspension of the rebate or denial of an application made
29 under this section may be appealed. The appeal shall be in accordance
30 with the Administrative Procedure Act.

7 Sec. 40. Section 19-1201, Revised Statutes Cumulative Supplement,
8 2024, is amended to read:
9 19-1201 (1) There is hereby established the Revitalize Rural
10 Nebraska Grant Program. The governing body of a city of the first class,
11 a city of the second class, or a village may apply, on behalf of the city
12 or village, to the Department of Water, Energy, and Environment
13 Environment and Energy for approval of a dilapidated commercial property
14 demolition grant. The Director of Water, Energy, and Environment
15 Environment and Energy shall prescribe the form and manner of
16 application.
17 (2) The department shall award the grants annually on a competitive
18 basis beginning in fiscal year 2023-24 subject to available funds. The
19 department shall give priority to applications from cities of the second
20 class and villages. If there are funds remaining at the end of each grant
21 period, the department shall consider applications from cities of the
22 first class. A city or village may apply for more than one grant. The
23 department shall give preference to new applicants.
24 (3) There shall be no limit on the amount that can be awarded to
25 each applicant within the available funding. It is the intent of the
26 Legislature that if the department does not award all of the available
27 appropriation for grants under the program, the unobligated amount of the
28 appropriation shall be reappropriated for the next fiscal year to be
29 awarded during the next grant period.

30 amended to read:
31 25-1064 (1) The injunction may be granted at the time of commencing
-53-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 the action or at any time afterward before judgment by the Court of
2 Appeals or the Supreme Court or any judge thereof. No restraining order
3 or temporary injunction should be granted at the time of the commencement
4 of the action if the relief demanded involves the delivery of irrigation
5 water and the Chief Water Officer Director of Natural Resources, as
6 defined in section 25-1062.01, is a party except in accordance with the
7 procedure prescribed in subsection (5) of this section.
8 (2) No temporary injunction may be granted without notice to the
9 adverse party.
10 (3) Any judge of the district court, except when the relief demanded
11 involves the delivery of irrigation water and the Chief Water Officer
12 director is a party, may grant a temporary restraining order without
13 notice to the adverse party or his or her attorney only if (a) it clearly
14 appears from specific facts shown by affidavit that immediate and
15 irreparable injury, loss, or damage will result to the applicant before
16 the adverse party or his or her attorney can be heard in opposition and
17 (b) the applicant or his or her attorney certifies to the court in
18 writing the efforts, if any, which have been made to give such notice and
19 the reasons supporting the applicant's claim that such notice shall not
20 be required.
21 Every temporary restraining order granted without notice shall: (i)
22 Be endorsed with the date and hour of issuance; (ii) be filed immediately
23 in the office of the clerk of the district court and entered of record;
24 (iii) define the injury and state why the injury is irreparable and why
25 the order was granted without notice; and (iv) expire by its terms within
26 such time after entry, not to exceed ten days, as the court fixes unless
27 within such fixed time period the order, for good cause shown, is
28 extended for a like period or unless the party against whom the order is
29 directed consents to an extension for a longer period. The reasons for
30 the extension shall be entered of record. If a temporary restraining
31 order is granted without notice, the motion for a temporary injunction
-54-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 shall be heard at the earliest possible time in the district court and
2 shall take precedence over all matters except older matters of the same
3 character. When the motion for a temporary injunction comes up for
4 hearing, the party who obtained the temporary restraining order shall
5 proceed with the application for a temporary injunction, and if he or she
6 does not do so, the district court shall dissolve the temporary
7 restraining order. On two days' notice to the party who obtained the
8 temporary restraining order without notice or on such shorter notice to
9 such party as the district court may prescribe, the adverse party may
10 appear and move for the dissolution or modification of the order, and in
11 that event, the court shall proceed to hear and determine such motion as
12 expeditiously as the ends of justice require.
13 (4) In the absence from the county of the district judges, any judge
14 of the county court, except when the relief demanded involves the
15 delivery of irrigation water and the Chief Water Officer director is a
16 party, may grant a temporary restraining order without notice to the
17 adverse party or his or her attorney only if (a) it clearly appears from
18 specific facts shown by affidavit that immediate and irreparable injury,
19 loss, or damage will result to the applicant before the adverse party or
20 his or her attorney can be heard in opposition and (b) the applicant or
21 his or her attorney certifies to the court in writing the efforts, if
22 any, which have been made to give such notice and the reasons supporting
23 the applicant's claim that such notice shall not be required. The judge
24 of the county court shall direct that reasonable notice be given to the
25 party against whom the temporary restraining order is issued to attend at
26 a specified time or place before the district court or any judge thereof
27 to show cause why a temporary injunction should not be issued.
28 Every temporary restraining order granted without notice shall: (i)
29 Be endorsed with the date and hour of issuance; (ii) be filed immediately
30 in the office of the clerk of the district court and entered of record;
31 (iii) define the injury and state why the injury is irreparable and why
-55-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 the order was granted without notice; and (iv) expire by its terms within
2 such time after entry, not to exceed ten days, as the judge of the county
3 court fixes unless within such fixed time period the order, for good
4 cause shown, is extended by the district court for a like period or
5 unless the party against whom the order is directed consents to an
6 extension for a longer period. The reasons for the extension shall be
7 entered of record.
8 (5) The Supreme Court or any judge thereof, the Court of Appeals or
9 any judge thereof, the district court or any judge thereof, or a judge of
10 the county court, if and when he or she has jurisdiction, shall have no
11 power, when the relief demanded involves the delivery of irrigation water
12 and the Chief Water Officer director is a party, to grant a restraining
13 order or temporary injunction at the time of the commencement of the
14 action, except when notice by either registered or certified letter has
15 been mailed seventy-two hours prior to the time of hearing to the Chief
16 Water Officer director and the division supervisor in the water division
17 created by section 61-212 in which the action is brought and, in the
18 manner provided in section 25-1062.01, to all appropriators whose rights
19 to the delivery of irrigation water might in any manner be affected, of
20 the time and place of the hearing. At the hearing on the restraining
21 order or temporary injunction, the Chief Water Officer director,
22 appropriators, or riparian owners shall be entitled to be heard, in
23 person or by their attorney or attorneys, on the question of whether the
24 restraining order should be granted and, if so, in what amount the bond
25 or undertaking is to be fixed.
26 (6) Any person, natural or artificial, injured or likely to be
27 injured by the granting of a restraining order may intervene in the
28 action at any stage of the proceedings and become a party to the
29 litigation if it involves the delivery of irrigation water and the Chief
30 Water Officer director is a party.

27 improved above such district pursuant to sections 31-508 and 31-509, the
28 board of trustees shall advertise for bids for the construction of such
29 improvements as are recommended by the department and in accordance with
30 plans recommended by the department.

7 Sec. 59. Section 37-806, Revised Statutes Cumulative Supplement,
8 2024, is amended to read:

12 Conservation Act, and any species of wildlife or wild plants determined
13 to be a threatened species pursuant to the Endangered Species Act shall
14 be a threatened species under the Nongame and Endangered Species
15 Conservation Act.
16 (b) Within a reasonable time after any federal listing, downlisting,
17 removal, or uplisting, the commission may determine that any species of
18 wildlife or wild plant should receive a different state-listed status
19 throughout all or any portion of the range of such species within this
20 state by completing the formal listing process as prescribed in this
21 section or by retaining its previous state-listed status.
22 (2) In addition to the species determined to be endangered or
23 threatened pursuant to the Endangered Species Act, the commission shall,
24 by adopting and promulgating rules and regulations, determine whether any
25 species of wildlife or wild plants normally occurring within this state
26 is an endangered or threatened species as a result of any of the
27 following factors:
28 (a) The present or threatened destruction, modification, or
29 curtailment of its habitat or range;
30 (b) Overutilization for commercial, recreational, scientific,
31 educational, or other purposes;
-64-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (c) Disease or predation;
2 (d) The inadequacy of existing regulatory mechanisms; or
3 (e) Other natural or manmade factors affecting its continued
4 existence within this state.
5 (3)(a) The commission shall make determinations required by
6 subsection (2) of this section on the basis of the best scientific,
7 commercial, and other data available to the commission.
8 (b) Except with respect to species of wildlife or wild plants
9 determined to be endangered or threatened species under subsection (1) of
10 this section, the commission shall not add a species to nor remove a
11 species from any list published pursuant to subsection (5) of this
12 section unless the commission has first:
13 (i) Provided public notice of such proposed action by publication in
14 a newspaper of general circulation in each county in that portion of the
15 subject species' range in which it is endangered or threatened or, if the
16 subject species' range extends over more than five counties, in a
17 newspaper of statewide circulation distributed in the county;
18 (ii) Provided notice of such proposed action to and allowed comment
19 from the Department of Agriculture, the Department of Water, Energy, and
20 Environment Environment and Energy, the Department of Natural Resources,
21 and any other state agency that the commission determines might be
22 impacted by the proposed action;
23 (iii) Provided notice of such proposed action to and allowed comment
24 from each natural resources district and public power district located in
25 that portion of the subject species' range in which it is endangered or
26 threatened;
27 (iv) Notified the Governor of any state sharing a common border with
28 this state, in which the subject species is known to occur, that such
29 action is being proposed;
30 (v) Allowed at least sixty days following publication for comment
31 from the public and other interested parties;
-65-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (vi) Held at least one public hearing on such proposed action in
2 each game and parks commissioner district of the subject species' range
3 in which it is endangered or threatened;
4 (vii) Submitted the scientific, commercial, and other data that is
5 the basis of the proposed action to scientists or experts outside and
6 independent of the commission for peer review of the data and
7 conclusions. If the commission submits the data to a state or federal
8 fish and wildlife agency for peer review, the commission shall also
9 submit the data to scientists or experts not affiliated with such an
10 agency for review. For purposes of this section, state fish and wildlife
11 agency does not include a postsecondary educational institution; and

16 who hold state-recognized property rights on behalf of themselves or
17 others, as a result of the listing of the species or the development of a
18 proposed program for the conservation of the species as required in
19 subsection (1) of section 37-807.
20 (c) The inadvertent failure to provide notice as required by
21 subdivision (3)(b) of this section shall not prohibit the listing of a
22 species and shall not be deemed to be a violation of the Administrative
23 Procedure Act or the Nongame and Endangered Species Conservation Act.

-66-

1 peer review, including an explanation of any changes or modifications the

4 applicable, for public examination.
5 (e) In cases when the commission determines that an emergency
6 situation exists involving the continued existence of such species as a

8 may add species to such lists after first publishing public notice that

10 support such determination.
11 (4) In determining whether any species of wildlife or wild plants is
12 an endangered or threatened species, the commission shall take into
13 consideration those actions being carried out by the federal government,
14 by other states, by other agencies of this state or its political
15 subdivisions, or by any other person which may affect the species under
16 consideration.

30 of this section, but only if the commission publishes a public notice
31 that such person has presented substantial evidence that warrants such a
-67-

LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 review.
2 (7) Whenever any species of wildlife or wild plants is listed as a
3 threatened species pursuant to subsection (5) of this section, the
4 commission shall issue such rules and regulations as are necessary to
5 provide for the conservation of such species. The commission may
6 prohibit, with respect to any threatened species of wildlife or wild
7 plants, any act prohibited under subsection (8) or (9) of this section.
8 (8) With respect to any endangered species of wildlife, it shall be
9 unlawful, except as provided in subsection (7) of this section or section
10 37-807, for any person subject to the jurisdiction of this state to:
11 (a) Export any such species from this state;
12 (b) Take any such species within this state;
13 (c) Possess, process, sell or offer for sale, deliver, carry,
14 transport, or ship, by any means whatsoever except as a common or
15 contract motor carrier under the jurisdiction of the Public Service
16 Commission or the federal Surface Transportation Board, any such species;
17 or

21 the Nongame and Endangered Species Conservation Act.
22 (9) With respect to any endangered species of wild plants, it shall
23 be unlawful, except as provided in subsection (7) of this section, for
24 any person subject to the jurisdiction of this state to:
25 (a) Export any such species from this state;
26 (b) Possess, process, sell or offer for sale, deliver, carry,
27 transport, or ship, by any means whatsoever, any such species; or
28 (c) Violate any rule or regulation pertaining to such species or to
29 any threatened species of wild plants listed pursuant to this section and
30 adopted and promulgated by the commission pursuant to the act.
31 (10) Any endangered species of wildlife or wild plants that enters
-68-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 this state from another state or from a point outside the territorial
2 limits of the United States and that is being transported to a point
3 within or beyond this state may be so entered and transported without
4 restriction in accordance with the terms of any federal permit or permit
5 issued under the laws or regulations of another state.
6 (11) The commission may permit any act otherwise prohibited by
7 subsection (8) of this section for scientific purposes or to enhance the
8 propagation or survival of the affected species.
9 (12) Any law, rule, regulation, or ordinance of any political
10 subdivision of this state that applies with respect to the taking,
11 importation, exportation, possession, sale or offer for sale, processing,
12 delivery, carrying, transportation other than under the jurisdiction of

15 Species Conservation Act shall be void to the extent that it may
16 effectively (a) permit that which is prohibited by the act or by any rule
17 or regulation that implements the act or (b) prohibit that which is
18 authorized pursuant to an exemption or permit provided for in the act or
19 in any rule or regulation that implements the act. The Nongame and
20 Endangered Species Conservation Act shall not otherwise be construed to
21 void any law, rule, regulation, or ordinance of any political subdivision
22 of this state which is intended to conserve wildlife or wild plants.

-73-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 46-122 (1) It is hereby expressly provided that all water
2 distributed for irrigation purposes shall attach to and follow the tract
3 of land to which it is applied unless a change of location has been
4 approved by the board of directors pursuant to sections 46-2,127 to
5 46-2,129 or by the Chief Water Officer Department of Natural Resources
6 pursuant to section 46-294 or sections 46-2,122 to 46-2,126.
7 (2) The board of directors may by the adoption of appropriate bylaws
8 provide for the suspension of water delivery to any land in such district
9 upon which the irrigation taxes levied and assessed thereon shall remain
10 due and unpaid for two years. It shall be the duty of the directors to
11 make all necessary arrangements for right-of-way for laterals from the
12 main canal to each tract of land subject to assessment, and when
13 necessary the board shall exercise its right of eminent domain to procure
14 right-of-way for the laterals and shall make such rules in regard to the
15 payment for such right-of-way as may be just and equitable.
16 (3) In times of reduced water supply, when the volume of water is
17 not adequate to be beneficially used when equitably apportioned to all
18 landowners in the district, the board may, after providing notice to
19 landowners in a portion of the district and upon receiving no objections
20 from the majority of such landowners, elect not to deliver water to that
21 portion of the district. Such election shall not subject the district to
22 liability under section 46-160 and shall not affect the rights of
23 landowners in that portion of the district to water deliveries in the
24 future. Any election to not deliver water to a portion of the district
25 shall be made on a year-to-year basis, not to exceed ten years, and such
26 election shall not subject any landowner to adjudication of his or her
27 water right under section 46-229. The board may adjust the tolls or
28 charges made to landowners within the district to reflect the decrease in
29 supply to those landowners in the portion of the district not receiving
30 water pursuant to such election by the board.

2 46-190 After a sale of the property and franchises of the district,

2 Sec. 64. Section 46-192, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
3 amended to read:
4 46-192 After all the property of the district is disposed of as
5 provided in sections 46-186 to 46-188, except for any balance of funds
6 remaining after all of the obligations of such district have been paid,
7 the directors of such district shall file in the office of the county
8 clerk of each county in which such district is located, and with in the
9 Chief Water Officer office of the Department of Water, Energy, and
10 Environment Natural Resources, a report attested by the secretary of the
11 board, stating that the district has disposed of its property and
12 franchises, except for any balance of funds remaining, and has
13 discontinued operation, which report shall be recorded in the
14 miscellaneous record of such counties. Each easement and right-of-way,
15 whether owned by the district in fee or otherwise, shall automatically be
16 terminated and extinguished and such interest together with any canal or
17 other structure shall become the property of the owner of the land upon
18 which such easement, right-of-way, canal, or other structure is located
19 or, if owned in fee by the district, shall become the property of the
20 owner of the land adjacent thereto, upon the filing of the report with
21 the Chief Water Officer department. If any person has any claim against
22 such district which is not settled or disposed of at the time of the
23 filing of such report and such person fails or neglects to bring suit
24 upon such claim within one year after the time of the filing of such
25 report, such claim or claims shall be forever barred as against such
26 district as well as against all persons and property therein.

23 Sec. 80. Section 46-229.04, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
24 amended to read:
25 46-229.04 (1) At a hearing held pursuant to section 46-229.03, the
26 verified field investigation report of an employee of the department, or
27 such other report or information that is relied upon by the Chief Water
28 Officer department to reach the preliminary determination of nonuse,
29 shall be prima facie evidence for the forfeiture and annulment of such
30 water appropriation. If no person appears at the hearing, such water
31 appropriation or unused part thereof shall be declared forfeited and
-87-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 annulled. If an interested person appears and contests the same, the
2 Chief Water Officer department shall hear evidence, and if it appears
3 that such water has not been put to a beneficial use or has ceased to be
4 used for such purpose for more than five consecutive years, the same
5 shall be declared canceled and annulled unless the Chief Water Officer
6 department finds that (a) there has been sufficient cause for such nonuse
7 as provided for in subsection (2), (3), or (4) of this section or (b)
8 subsection (5) or (6) of this section applies.
9 (2) Sufficient cause for nonuse shall be deemed to exist for up to
10 thirty consecutive years if:
11 (a) Such nonuse was caused by the unavailability of water for that
12 use. For a river basin, subbasin, or reach that has been designated as
13 overappropriated pursuant to section 46-713 or determined by the Chief
14 Water Officer department to be fully appropriated pursuant to section
15 46-714, the period of time within which sufficient cause for nonuse
16 because of the unavailability of water may be deemed to exist may be
17 extended beyond thirty years by the Chief Water Officer department upon
18 petition therefor by the owner of the appropriation if the Chief Water
19 Officer department determines that an integrated management plan being
20 implemented in the river basin, subbasin, or reach involved is likely to
21 result in restoration of a usable water supply for the appropriation; or
22 (b) The land subject to the appropriation is under an acreage
23 reserve program or production quota or is otherwise withdrawn from use as
24 required for participation in any federal, state, or natural resources
25 district program, or such land was previously under such a program but
26 currently is not under such a program and there have been not more than
27 five consecutive years of nonuse on such land subsequent to when that
28 land was last under such program.
29 (3) Sufficient cause for nonuse shall be deemed to exist
30 indefinitely if such nonuse was the result of one or more of the
31 following:
-88-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (a) For any tract of land under separate ownership, the available
2 supply was used but on only part of the land under the appropriation
3 because of an inadequate water supply;
4 (b) The appropriation is a storage appropriation and there was an
5 inadequate water supply to provide the water for the storage
6 appropriation or less than the full amount of the storage appropriation
7 was needed to keep the reservoir full; or
8 (c) The appropriation is a storage-use appropriation and there was
9 an inadequate water supply to provide the water for the appropriation or
10 use of the storage water was unnecessary because of climatic conditions.
11 (4) Sufficient cause for nonuse shall be deemed to exist for up to
12 fifteen consecutive years if such nonuse was a result of one or more of
13 the following:
14 (a) Federal, state, or local laws, rules, or regulations temporarily
15 prevented or restricted such use;
16 (b) Use of the water was unnecessary because of climatic conditions;
17 (c) Circumstances were such that a prudent person, following the
18 principles of good husbandry, would not have been expected to use the
19 water;
20 (d) The works, diversions, or other facilities essential to use the
21 water were destroyed by a cause not within the control of the owner of
22 the appropriation and good faith efforts to repair or replace the works,
23 diversions, or facilities have been and are being made;
24 (e) The owner of the appropriation was in active involuntary service
25 in the armed forces of the United States or was in active voluntary
26 service during a time of crisis; or
27 (f) Legal proceedings prevented or restricted use of the water.
28 The Chief Water Officer department may specify by rule and
29 regulation other circumstances that shall be deemed to constitute
30 sufficient cause for nonuse for up to fifteen years.
31 (5) When an appropriation is held in the name of an irrigation
-89-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 district, a reclamation district, a public power and irrigation district,
2 a mutual irrigation company or canal company, or the United States Bureau
3 of Reclamation and the Chief Water Officer director determines that water
4 under that appropriation has not been used on a specific parcel of land
5 for more than five years and that no sufficient cause for such nonuse
6 exists, the right to use water under that appropriation on that parcel
7 shall be terminated and notice of the termination shall be posted on the
8 department's website and shall be given in the manner provided in
9 subsection (2), (3), or (4) of section 46-229.03. The district or company
10 holding such right shall have five years after the determination, or five
11 years after an order of cancellation issued by the Chief Water Officer
12 department following the filing of a voluntary relinquishment of the
13 water appropriation that has been signed by the landowner and the
14 appropriator of record, to assign the right to use that portion of the
15 appropriation to other land within the district or the area served by the
16 company, to file an application for a transfer in accordance with section
17 46-290, or to transfer the right in accordance with sections 46-2,127 to
18 46-2,129. The Chief Water Officer department shall issue the its order of
19 cancellation within sixty days after receipt of the voluntary
20 relinquishment unless the relinquishment is conditioned by the landowner
21 upon an action of a governmental agency. If the relinquishment contains
22 such a provision, the Chief Water Officer department shall issue the its
23 order of cancellation within sixty days after receipt of notification
24 that such action has been completed. The Chief Water Officer department
25 shall be notified of any such assignment within thirty days after such
26 assignment. If the district or company does not assign the right to use
27 that portion of the appropriation to other land, does not file an
28 application for a transfer within the five-year period, or does not
29 notify the Chief Water Officer department within thirty days after any
30 such assignment, that portion of the appropriation shall be canceled
31 without further proceedings by the Chief Water Officer department and the
-90-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 district or company involved shall be so notified by the Chief Water
2 Officer department. During the time within which assignment of a portion
3 of an appropriation is pending, the allowable diversion rate for the
4 appropriation involved shall be reduced, as necessary, to avoid
5 inconsistency with the rate allowed by section 46-231 or with any greater
6 rate previously approved for such appropriation by the Chief Water
7 Officer director in accordance with section 46-229.06.
8 (6) When it is determined by the Chief Water Officer director that
9 an appropriation, for which the location of use has been temporarily
10 transferred in accordance with sections 46-290 to 46-294, has not been
11 used at the new location for more than five years and that no sufficient
12 cause for such nonuse exists, the right to use that appropriation at the
13 temporary location of use shall be terminated. Notice of that termination
14 shall be posted on the department's website and shall be given in the
15 manner provided in subsection (2), (3), or (4) of section 46-229.03. The
16 right to reinitiate use of that appropriation at the location of use
17 prior to the temporary transfer shall continue to exist for five years
18 after the Chief Water Officer's director's determination, but if such use
19 is not reinitiated at that location within such five-year period, the
20 appropriation shall be subject to cancellation in accordance with
21 sections 46-229 to 46-229.04.
22 (7) If at the time of a hearing conducted in accordance with
23 subsection (1) of this section there is an application for incidental or
24 intentional underground water storage pending before the Chief Water
25 Officer department and filed by the owner of the appropriation, the
26 proceedings shall be consolidated.
27 Sec. 81. Section 46-229.05, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is

29 46-229.05 An appeal may be taken from the decision of the Chief

31 Sec. 82. Section 46-229.06, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
-91-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 amended to read:
2 46-229.06 When a departmental proceeding that is conducted pursuant
3 to sections 46-229 to 46-229.04 concerns the partial cancellation of an
4 appropriation, the Chief Water Officer department may receive evidence on
5 the question of whether, following such partial cancellation, a reduction
6 in the rate of diversion to the maximum rate prescribed in section 46-231
7 would result in an authorized diversion rate less than the rate
8 necessary, in the interests of good husbandry, for the production of
9 crops on the lands that remain subject to the appropriation. If the Chief
10 Water Officer director determines, based on a preponderance of the
11 evidence, that such rate would be less than the rate necessary, in the
12 interests of good husbandry, for the production of crops, he or she may
13 approve a diversion rate for the remaining portion of the appropriation
14 greater than the maximum rate authorized by section 46-231. Such
15 increased rate can be no greater than the rate authorized for the
16 appropriation prior to the partial cancellation and no greater than the
17 rate determined by the Chief Water Officer director to be necessary, in
18 the interests of good husbandry, for the production of crops on the lands
19 that remain subject to the appropriation.

21 Sec. 84. Section 46-231, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
22 amended to read:
23 46-231 Each appropriation shall be determined in its priority and
24 amount by the time at which it is made and the amount of water which the
25 works are constructed to carry. An appropriator shall at no time be
26 entitled to the use of more than he or she can beneficially use for the

28 appropriation made by means of enlargement of the distributing works

31 not exceed one cubic foot per second of time for each seventy acres of
-93-

LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025

5 for the production of crops. Such limitations do not apply to storage

18 so long as (1) the volume of water used in a twenty-four-hour period does
19 not exceed the amount of water that would otherwise have been allowed at

21 the volume of water used in a seven-day, Monday-through-Sunday period
22 does not exceed the amount of water that would otherwise have been
23 allowed at the approved fixed continuous rate for a seven-day period. The
24 Chief Water Officer department shall determine schedules among
25 appropriators to assure that other rights are not violated.

16 (5) Prior to taking action on an application for induced ground

18 such application at the applicant's expense at least once each week for

5 amended to include appropriation for intentional underground water
6 storage and recovery of such water.
7 (8) Application may be made to the Chief Water Officer department
8 for a temporary permit to appropriate water. The same standards for
9 granting a permanent appropriation shall apply for granting such
10 temporary permit except when the temporary permit is for road
11 construction or other public use construction and the amount of water
12 requested is less than ten acre-feet in total volume. For temporary
13 permits for public-use construction, the applicant shall include on the
14 application the location of the diversion, the location of use, a
15 description of the project, the amount of water requested, and the person
16 to contact. Temporary permits for public-use construction and for less
17 than ten acre-feet in total volume may be granted without any
18 determination of unappropriated water and shall be considered to be in
19 the public interest. The requirement of filing a map or plans with the
20 application for a temporary permit may be waived at the discretion of the
21 Chief Water Officer director. In granting a temporary permit, the Chief
22 Water Officer director shall specify a date on which the right to
23 appropriate water under the permit shall expire. Under no circumstances
24 shall such date be longer than one calendar year after the date the
25 temporary permit was granted. Temporary permits shall be administered
26 during times of shortage based on priority. The right to appropriate
27 water shall automatically terminate on the date specified by the Chief
28 Water Officer director on the temporary permit without further action by
29 the Chief Water Officer department.

8 Sec. 86. Section 46-233.01, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
9 amended to read:
10 46-233.01 (1) Application may be made to the Chief Water Officer
11 department for a permit to appropriate any of the public surface waters
12 of the State of Nebraska to be diverted or stored in Nebraska for use in
13 any other state.
14 (2) In determining whether to grant such application, the Chief
15 Water Officer director shall consider the following factors:
16 (a) Whether unappropriated water exists in the source of supply
17 named in the application;
18 (b) Whether such application and appropriation when perfected are
19 not otherwise detrimental to the public welfare;
20 (c) Whether denial of the application is demanded by the public
21 interest; and
22 (d) Whether the proposed use is a beneficial use of water.
23 (3) When determining whether denial of such application is demanded
24 by the public interest, the Chief Water Officer director shall consider
25 the following factors:
26 (a) The economic, environmental, and other benefits of the proposed
27 use;
28 (b) Any adverse economic, environmental, and other impacts of the
29 proposed use;
30 (c) Any current beneficial uses being made of the unappropriated
31 water;
-99-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (d) The economic, environmental, and other benefits of not allowing
2 the appropriation and preserving the water supply for beneficial uses
3 within the state;
4 (e) Alternative sources of water supply available to the applicant;
5 and
6 (f) Any other factors consistent with the purposes of this section
7 that the Chief Water Officer director deems relevant to protecting the
8 interests of the state and its citizens.
9 The application shall be deemed in the public interest if the
10 overall benefits to Nebraska are greater than the adverse impacts to
11 Nebraska. The Chief Water Officer's director's order granting or denying
12 an application shall specify the reasons for such action, including a
13 discussion of the required factors for consideration, and shall document
14 such decision by reference to the hearing record, if any, and to any
15 other sources used by the Chief Water Officer director in making the
16 decision.

11 Officer director if he or she finds that:
12 (i) The appropriation is necessary to maintain the well or wells for

14 (ii) The rate and timing of the flow is the amount reasonably
15 necessary to maintain the well or wells for the uses for which the
16 appropriation has been requested; and
17 (iii) The application is in the public interest and is not
18 detrimental to the public welfare. There shall be a rebuttable

-102-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 junior appropriators may petition the Chief Water Officer director for a

4 reasonable advantage of the aquifer conditions in the area. If the Chief
5 Water Officer director determines that the well or wells have been so
6 modified, relocated, or reconstructed, the Chief Water Officer director
7 shall cause to be modified the approval of the application to allow for
8 the regulation of junior appropriators, subject to the restrictions or
9 conditions applicable to public water suppliers.
10 (c) An application for an induced ground water recharge
11 appropriation for public water supplier wells constructed and placed in
12 service before September 9, 1993, shall not be subject to the

17 Water Officer director if he or she makes the findings required by

19 (a) There is unappropriated water available for the appropriation;
20 and
21 (b) The well or wells involved have been or will be located and
22 constructed to take reasonable advantage of aquifer conditions in the
23 area to minimize the frequency and amount of the demand for flows for
24 induced ground water recharge.

8 Officer's director's considerations shall include, but not be limited to,

2 46-237 (1) Within six months after approval and allowance of an

6 to the rules and regulations of the department as to material, size,
7 coloring, and scale. Such map or plat shall show the source from which
8 the proposed appropriation is to be taken and all proposed dams, dikes,
9 reservoirs, canals, powerhouses, and other structures for the purpose of
10 storing, conveying, or using water for any purpose whatsoever and their
11 true courses or positions in connection with the boundary lines and
12 corners of lands which they occupy. The lands to be irrigated shall be
13 identified in the manner prescribed by the department. No rights shall be
14 deemed to have been acquired until the provisions of this section have
15 been complied with. Except as provided in subsection (2) of this section,
16 failure to so comply shall work a forfeiture of the appropriation and all
17 rights thereunder.
18 (2) For any appropriation with a priority date earlier than 1958 but
19 for which either the appropriator has failed to comply with the
20 requirements of subsection (1) of this section or a map or plat required
21 by such subsection has been lost or destroyed through no fault of the
22 appropriator, the lack of such compliance or of such map or plat shall
23 not be the basis for an a departmental adjudication or cancellation of
24 the appropriation by the Chief Water Officer and the appropriation shall
25 not be subject to legal challenge by any party on that basis.
26 (3) The Chief Water Officer department may notify any appropriator
27 subject to subsection (2) of this section of the need to file a map or
28 plat of lands under such appropriation. Unless the Chief Water Officer
29 department grants an extension for good cause shown, the appropriator
30 shall file the required map within three years after that notification
31 and such map shall conform to the rules and regulations of the Chief
-108-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 Water Officer department as to material, size, coloring, and scale. If
2 the appropriator fails to comply, the Chief Water Officer department may
3 deny the appropriator the right to divert or withdraw water subject to
4 the appropriation until compliance has been achieved.
5 Sec. 95. Section 46-238, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
6 amended to read:
7 46-238 (1) Within twelve months after the approval of any
8 application for water for irrigation, power, or other useful purpose by
9 the Chief Water Officer department, the person making such application
10 shall commence the excavation or construction of the works in which it is
11 intended to divert the water and the actual construction of any water
12 power plant and reservoir or reservoirs for storage in connection
13 therewith and shall vigorously, diligently, and uninterruptedly prosecute
14 such work to completion unless temporarily interrupted by some
15 unavoidable and natural cause. A failure to comply with this section
16 shall work a forfeiture of the appropriation and all rights under the
17 appropriation. The cost of promotion and engineering work shall not be
18 considered a part of the cost of construction, and the progress of the
19 construction work shall be such that one-tenth of the total work shall be
20 completed within one year from the date of approval of the application.
21 The construction of all work required in connection with the proposed
22 project shall be prosecuted in the manner described in this section and
23 with such a force as shall assure the average rate of constructional
24 progress necessary to complete such work or works within the time
25 stipulated in the approval of such application, notwithstanding the
26 ordinary delays and casualties that must be expected and provided
27 against. A failure to carry on the construction of either an irrigation
28 project or a water power project as outlined in this section shall work a
29 forfeiture of the appropriation and all rights under the appropriation,
30 and the Chief Water Officer department shall cancel such appropriation.

ER36 ER36

MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 books, and papers of any irrigation or water power company, shall have

15 of each petition received to be published at the petitioner's expense in

17 of the appropriation once a week for three consecutive weeks. The Chief
18 Water Officer department shall hold a hearing on the issue of extension
19 on the Chief Water Officer's its own motion or if requested by any
20 interested person. If a hearing is held, notice shall be given by
21 certified mail to the applicant, to any person who requested a hearing,
22 and to any person who requests notification of the hearing. The Chief
23 Water Officer department may grant the extension in the absence of a
24 hearing if no requests for a hearing are received. Any interested person
25 may be made a party to such action. Any party affected by the decision on
26 the petition may appeal directly to the Court of Appeals. Subsequent
27 extensions may be made in the same manner.

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 determined by the Chief Water Officer department, except that a reservoir

3 which has been legally stored. Any dam shall be constructed in accordance
4 with the Safety of Dams and Reservoirs Act, and the outlet works shall be
5 installed so that water may be released in compliance with this section.
6 The requirement for outlet works may be waived by the Chief Water Officer
7 department upon a showing of good cause. Whenever any person diverts
8 water from a public stream and returns it into the same stream, he or she
9 may take out the same amount of water, less a reasonable deduction for
10 losses in transit, to be determined by the Chief Water Officer
11 department, if no prior appropriator for beneficial use is prejudiced by
12 such diversion.
13 (6) An application for storage and recovery of water intentionally
14 stored underground may be made only by an appropriator of record who
15 shows, by documentary evidence, sufficient interest in the underground
16 water storage facility to entitle the applicant to the water requested.
