6 Sec. 108. Section 46-288, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
7 amended to read:
8 46-288 For purposes of this section and section 46-289, unless the
9 context otherwise requires:
10 (1) Basin of origin shall mean the river basin in which the point or
11 proposed point of diversion of water is located;
12 (2) Beneficial use shall include, but not be limited to, reasonable
13 and efficient use of water for domestic, municipal, agricultural,
14 industrial, commercial, power production, subirrigation, fish and
15 wildlife, ground water recharge, interstate compact, water quality
16 maintenance, or recreational purposes. Nothing in this subdivision shall
17 be construed to affect the preferences for use of surface water as
18 provided in section 46-204;
19 (3) Interbasin transfer shall mean the diversion of water in one
20 river basin and the transportation of such water to another river basin
21 for storage or utilization for a beneficial use; and
22 (4) River basin shall mean any of the following natural hydrologic
23 basins of the state as shown on maps located in the Department of Water,
24 Energy, and Environment Natural Resources: (a) The White River and Hat
25 Creek basin; (b) the Niobrara River basin; (c) the Platte River basin,
26 including the North Platte and South Platte River basins, except that for
27 purposes of transfer between the North and South Platte River basins each
28 shall be considered a separate river basin; (d) the Loup River basin; (e)
29 the Elkhorn River basin; (f) the Republican River basin; (g) the Little
30 Blue River basin; (h) the Big Blue River basin; (i) the Nemaha River
31 basin; and (j) the Missouri tributaries basin.
-121-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 Sec. 109. Section 46-289, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
2 amended to read:
3 46-289 The Legislature finds, recognizes, and declares that the
4 transfer of water to outside the boundaries of a river basin may have
5 impacts on the water and other resources in the basin and that such
6 impacts differ from those caused by uses of water within the same basin
7 in part because any unused water will not be returned to the stream from
8 which it is taken for further use in that river basin. The Legislature
9 therefor recognizes the need to delineate factors for consideration by
10 the Chief Water Officer of the Department of Water, Energy, and
11 Environment Director of Natural Resources when evaluating an application
12 made pursuant to section 46-233 which involves an interbasin transfer of
13 water in order to determine whether denial of such application is
14 demanded by the public interest. Those considerations shall include, but
15 not be limited to, the following factors:
16 (1) The economic, environmental, and other benefits of the proposed
17 interbasin transfer and use;
18 (2) Any adverse impacts of the proposed interbasin transfer and use;
19 (3) Any current beneficial uses being made of the unappropriated
20 water in the basin of origin;
21 (4) Any reasonably foreseeable future beneficial uses of the water
22 in the basin of origin;
23 (5) The economic, environmental, and other benefits of leaving the
24 water in the basin of origin for current or future beneficial uses;
25 (6) Alternative sources of water supply available to the applicant;
26 and
27 (7) Alternative sources of water available to the basin of origin
28 for future beneficial uses.
29 The application shall be deemed in the public interest if the
30 overall benefits to the state and the applicant's basin are greater than
31 or equal to the adverse impacts to the state and the basin of origin. The
-122-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 Chief Water Officer's director's order granting or denying an application
2 shall specify the reasons for such action, including a discussion of the
3 required factors for consideration, and shall document such decision by
4 reference to the hearing record, if any, and to any other sources used by
5 the Chief Water Officer director in making the decision.
6 Sec. 110. Section 46-290, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
7 amended to read:
8 46-290 (1)(a) Except as provided in this section and sections
9 46-2,120 to 46-2,130, any person having a permit to appropriate water for
10 beneficial purposes issued pursuant to sections 46-233 to 46-235,
11 46-240.01, 46-241, 46-242, or 46-637 and who desires (i) to transfer the
12 use of such appropriation to a location other than the location specified
13 in the permit, (ii) to change that appropriation to a different type of
14 appropriation as provided in subsection (3) of this section, or (iii) to
15 change the purpose for which the water is to be used under a natural-
16 flow, storage, or storage-use appropriation to a purpose not at that time
17 permitted under the appropriation shall apply for approval of such
18 transfer or change to the Chief Water Officer Department of Natural
19 Resources.
20 (b) The application for such approval shall contain (i) the number
21 assigned to such appropriation by the Chief Water Officer department,
22 (ii) the name and address of the present holder of the appropriation,
23 (iii) if applicable, the name and address of the person or entity to whom
24 the appropriation would be transferred or who will be the user of record
25 after a change in the location of use, type of appropriation, or purpose
26 of use under the appropriation, (iv) the legal description of the land to
27 which the appropriation is now appurtenant, (v) the name and address of
28 each holder of a mortgage, trust deed, or other equivalent consensual
29 security interest against the tract or tracts of land to which the
30 appropriation is now appurtenant, (vi) if applicable, the legal
31 description of the land to which the appropriation is proposed to be
-123-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 transferred, (vii) if a transfer is proposed, whether other sources of
2 water are available at the original location of use and whether any
3 provisions have been made to prevent either use of a new source of water
4 at the original location or increased use of water from any existing
5 source at that location, (viii) if applicable, the legal descriptions of
6 the beginning and end of the stream reach to which the appropriation is
7 proposed to be transferred for the purpose of augmenting the flows in
8 that stream reach, (ix) if a proposed transfer is for the purpose of
9 increasing the quantity of water available for use pursuant to another
10 appropriation, the number assigned to such other appropriation by the
11 Chief Water Officer department, (x) the purpose of the current use, (xi)
12 if a change in purpose of use is proposed, the proposed purpose of use,
13 (xii) if a change in the type of appropriation is proposed, the type of
14 appropriation to which a change is desired, (xiii) if a proposed transfer
15 or change is to be temporary in nature, the duration of the proposed
16 transfer or change, and (xiv) such other information as the Chief Water
17 Officer department by rule and regulation requires.
18 (2) If a proposed transfer or change is to be temporary in nature, a
19 copy of the proposed agreement between the current appropriator and the
20 person who is to be responsible for use of water under the appropriation
21 while the transfer or change is in effect shall be submitted at the same
22 time as the application.
23 (3) Regardless of whether a transfer or a change in the purpose of
24 use is involved, the following changes in type of appropriation, if found
25 by the Chief Water Officer of the Department of Water, Energy, and
26 Environment Director of Natural Resources to be consistent with section
27 46-294, may be approved subject to the following:
28 (a) A natural-flow appropriation for direct out-of-stream use may be
29 changed to a natural-flow appropriation for aboveground reservoir storage
30 or for intentional underground water storage;
31 (b) A natural-flow appropriation for intentional underground water
-124-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 storage may be changed to a natural-flow appropriation for direct out-of-
2 stream use or for aboveground reservoir storage;
3 (c) A natural-flow appropriation for direct out-of-stream use, for
4 aboveground reservoir storage, or for intentional underground water
5 storage may be changed to an instream appropriation subject to sections
6 46-2,107 to 46-2,119 if the Chief Water Officer director determines that
7 the resulting instream appropriation would be consistent with
8 subdivisions (2), (3), and (4) of section 46-2,115;
9 (d) A natural-flow appropriation for direct out-of-stream use, for
10 aboveground reservoir storage, or for intentional underground water
11 storage may be changed to an appropriation for induced ground water
12 recharge if the Chief Water Officer director determines that the
13 resulting appropriation for induced ground water recharge would be
14 consistent with subdivisions (2)(a)(i) and (ii) of section 46-235;
15 (e) An appropriation for the manufacturing of hydropower at a
16 facility located on a natural stream channel may be permanently changed
17 in full to an instream basin-management appropriation to be held jointly
18 by the Game and Parks Commission and any natural resources district or
19 combination of natural resources districts. The beneficial use of such
20 change is to maintain the streamflow for fish, wildlife, and recreation
21 that was available from the manufacturing of hydropower prior to the
22 change. Such changed appropriation may also be utilized by the owners of
23 the appropriation to assist in the implementation of an approved
24 integrated management plan or plans developed pursuant to sections 46-714
25 to 46-718 for each natural resources district within the river basin. Any
26 such change under this section shall be subject to review under sections
27 46-229 to 46-229.06 to ensure that the beneficial uses of the change of
28 use are still being achieved; and
29 (f) The incidental underground water storage portion, whether or not
30 previously quantified, of a natural-flow or storage-use appropriation may
31 be separated from the direct-use portion of the appropriation and may be
-125-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 changed to a natural-flow or storage-use appropriation for intentional
2 underground water storage at the same location if the historic
3 consumptive use of the direct-use portion of the appropriation is
4 transferred to another location or is terminated, but such a separation
5 and change may be approved only if, after the separation and change, (i)
6 the total permissible diversion under the appropriation will not
7 increase, (ii) the projected consequences of the separation and change
8 are consistent with the provisions of any integrated management plan
9 adopted in accordance with section 46-718 or 46-719 for the geographic
10 area involved, and (iii) if the location of the proposed intentional
11 underground water storage is in a river basin, subbasin, or reach
12 designated as overappropriated in accordance with section 46-713, the
13 integrated management plan for that river basin, subbasin, or reach has
14 gone into effect, and that plan requires that the amount of the
15 intentionally stored water that is consumed after the change will be no
16 greater than the amount of the incidentally stored water that was
17 consumed prior to the change. Approval of a separation and change
18 pursuant to this subdivision (f) shall not exempt any consumptive use
19 associated with the incidental recharge right from any reduction in water
20 use required by an integrated management plan for a river basin,
21 subbasin, or reach designated as overappropriated in accordance with
22 section 46-713.
23 Whenever any change in type of appropriation is approved pursuant to
24 this subsection and as long as that change remains in effect, the
25 appropriation shall be subject to the statutes, rules, and regulations
26 that apply to the type of appropriation to which the change has been
27 made.
28 (4) The Legislature finds that induced ground water recharge
29 appropriations issued pursuant to sections 46-233 and 46-235 and instream
30 appropriations issued pursuant to section 46-2,115 are specific to the
31 location identified in the appropriation. Neither type of appropriation
-126-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 shall be transferred to a different location, changed to a different type
2 of appropriation, or changed to permit a different purpose of use.
3 (5) In addition to any other purposes for which transfers and
4 changes may be approved, such transfers and changes may be approved if
5 the purpose is (a) to maintain or augment the flow in a specific stream
6 reach for any instream use that the Chief Water Officer department has
7 determined, through rules and regulations, to be a beneficial use or (b)
8 to increase the frequency that a diversion rate or rate of flow specified
9 in another valid appropriation is achieved.
10 For any transfer or change approved pursuant to subdivision (a) of
11 this subsection, the Chief Water Officer department shall be provided
12 with a report at least every five years while such transfer or change is
13 in effect. The purpose of such report shall be to indicate whether the
14 beneficial instream use for which the flow is maintained or augmented
15 continues to exist. If the report indicates that it does not or if no
16 report is filed within sixty days after the Chief Water Officer's
17 department's notice to the appropriator that the deadline for filing the
18 report has passed, the Chief Water Officer department may cancel the its
19 approval of the transfer or change and such appropriation shall revert to
20 the same location of use, type of appropriation, and purpose of use as
21 prior to such approval.
22 (6) A quantified or unquantified appropriation for incidental
23 underground water storage may be transferred to a new location along with
24 the direct-use appropriation with which it is recognized if the Chief
25 Water Officer director finds such transfer to be consistent with section
26 46-294 and determines that the geologic and other relevant conditions at
27 the new location are such that incidental underground water storage will
28 occur at the new location. The Chief Water Officer director may request
29 such information from the applicant as is needed to make such
30 determination and may modify any such quantified appropriation for
31 incidental underground water storage, if necessary, to reflect the
-127-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 geologic and other conditions at the new location.
2 (7) Unless an incidental underground water storage appropriation is
3 changed as authorized by subdivision (3)(f) of this section or is
4 transferred as authorized by subsection (6) of this section or subsection
5 (1) of section 46-291, such appropriation shall be canceled or modified,
6 as appropriate, by the Chief Water Officer director to reflect any
7 reduction in water that will be stored underground as the result of a
8 transfer or change of the direct-use appropriation with which the
9 incidental underground water storage was recognized prior to the transfer
10 or change.
11 (8) Any appropriation for manufacturing of hydropower changed under
12 subdivision (3)(e) of this section shall maintain the priority date and
13 preference category of the original manufacturing appropriation and shall
14 be subject to condemnation and subordination pursuant to sections 70-668
15 and 70-669. Any person holding a subordination agreement that was
16 established prior to such change of appropriation shall be entitled to
17 enter into a new subordination agreement for terms consistent with the
18 original subordination agreement at no additional cost. Any person having
19 obtained a condemnation award that was established prior to such change
20 of appropriation shall be entitled to the same benefits created by such
21 award, and any obligations created by such award shall become the
22 obligations of the new owner of the appropriation changed under this
23 section.

4 to and request a hearing on the application by filing such objections in
5 writing specifically stating the grounds for each objection and (b) that
6 any such objection and request shall be filed with in the Chief Water
7 Officer office of the department within two weeks after the date of final
8 publication of the notice.
9 (5) Within the time period allowed by this section for the filing of
10 objections and requests for hearings, the county board of any county
11 containing land to which the appropriation is appurtenant and, if
12 applicable, the county board of any county containing land to which the
13 appropriation is proposed to be transferred may provide the Chief Water
14 Officer department with comments about the potential economic impacts of
15 the proposed transfer or change in such county. The filing of any such
16 comments by a county board shall not make the county a party in the
17 application process, but such comments shall be considered by the Chief
18 Water Officer director in determining pursuant to section 46-294 whether
19 the proposed transfer or change is in the public interest.

24 section 46-294.02, no more than thirty years;

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 interest shall include, but not be limited to, (i) the economic, social,
2 and environmental impacts of the proposed transfer or change and (ii)
3 whether and under what conditions other sources of water are available
4 for the uses to be made of the appropriation after the proposed transfer
5 or change. The Chief Water Officer Department of Natural Resources shall
6 adopt and promulgate rules and regulations to govern the Chief Water
7 Officer's director's determination of whether a proposed transfer or
8 change is in the public interest.
9 (2) The applicant has the burden of proving that the proposed
10 transfer or change will comply with subdivisions (1)(a) through (l) of
11 this section, except that (a) the burden is on a riparian user to
12 demonstrate his or her riparian status and to demonstrate a significant
13 adverse effect on his or her use in order to prevent approval of an
14 application and (b) if both the current use and the proposed use after a
15 transfer are for irrigation, the number of acres to be irrigated will not
16 increase after the transfer, and the location of the diversion from the
17 stream will not change, there is a rebuttable presumption that the
18 transfer will be consistent with subdivision (1)(d) of this section.
19 (3) In approving an application, the Chief Water Officer director
20 may impose any reasonable conditions deemed necessary to protect the
21 public interest, to ensure consistency with any of the other criteria in
22 subsection (1) of this section, or to provide the Chief Water Officer
23 department with information needed to properly and efficiently administer
24 the appropriation while the transfer or change remains in effect. If
25 necessary to prevent diminution of supply for any other appropriator, the
26 conditions imposed by the Chief Water Officer director shall require that
27 historic return flows be maintained or replaced in quantity, timing, and
28 location. After approval of any such transfer or change, the
29 appropriation shall be subject to all water use restrictions and
30 requirements in effect at any new location of use and, if applicable, at
31 any new diversion location. An appropriation for which a transfer or
-135-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 change has been approved shall retain the same priority date as that of
2 the original appropriation. If an approved transfer or change is
3 temporary, the location of use, purpose of use, or type of appropriation
4 shall revert to the location of use, purpose of use, or type of
5 appropriation prior to the transfer or change.
6 (4) In approving an application for a transfer, the Chief Water
7 Officer director may also authorize the overlying of water appropriations
8 on the same lands, except that if any such overlying of appropriations
9 would result in either the authorized diversion rate or the authorized
10 aggregate annual quantity that could be diverted to be greater than is
11 otherwise permitted by section 46-231, the Chief Water Officer director
12 shall limit the total diversion rate or aggregate annual quantity for the
13 appropriations overlain to the rate or quantity that he or she determines
14 is necessary, in the exercise of good husbandry, for the production of
15 crops on the land involved. The Chief Water Officer director may also
16 authorize a greater number of acres to be irrigated if the amount and
17 rate of water approved under the original appropriation is not increased
18 by the change of location. An increase in the number of acres to be
19 irrigated shall be approved only if (a) such an increase will not
20 diminish the supply of water available to or otherwise adversely affect
21 another water appropriator or (b) the transfer would not adversely affect
22 the water supply for any river basin, subbasin, or reach that has been
23 designated as overappropriated pursuant to section 46-713 or determined
24 to be fully appropriated pursuant to section 46-714 and (i) the number of
25 acres authorized under the appropriation when originally approved has not
26 been increased previously, (ii) the increase in the number of acres
27 irrigated will not exceed five percent of the number of acres being
28 irrigated under the permit before the proposed transfer or a total of ten
29 acres, whichever acreage is less, and (iii) all the use will be either on
30 the quarter section to which the appropriation was appurtenant before the
31 transfer or on an adjacent quarter section.

9 Sec. 118. Section 46-296, Revised Statutes Cumulative Supplement,
10 2024, is amended to read:
11 46-296 For purposes of sections 46-202 and 46-295 to 46-2,106,
12 unless the context otherwise requires:
13 (1) Chief Water Officer means the Chief Water Officer of the
14 Department of Water, Energy, and Environment;
15 (2) (1) Department means the Department of Water, Energy, and
16 Environment Natural Resources;
17 (2) Director means the Director of Natural Resources;
18 (3) Person means a natural person, partnership, limited liability
19 company, association, corporation, municipality, or agency or political
20 subdivision of the state or of the federal government;
21 (4) Underground water storage means the act of storing or recharging
22 water in underground strata. Such water shall be known as water stored
23 underground but does not include ground water as defined in section
24 46-706 which occurs naturally;
25 (5) Intentional underground water storage means underground water
26 storage which is an intended purpose or result of a water project or use.
27 Such storage may be accomplished by any lawful means such as injection
28 wells, infiltration basins, canals, reservoirs, and other reasonable
29 methods; and
30 (6) Incidental underground water storage means underground water
31 storage which occurs as an indirect result, rather than an intended or
-138-

10 46-2,111 (1) The Legislature finds that instream appropriations for

25 Sec. 127. Section 46-2,112, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
26 amended to read:
27 46-2,112 A permit to appropriate water for instream flows shall be
28 subject to review every fifteen years after it is granted. Notice of a
29 pending review shall be published in a newspaper published or of general
30 circulation in the area involved at least once each week for three
31 consecutive weeks, the last publication to be not later than fourteen
-142-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 years and ten months after the permit was granted or after the date of
2 the Chief Water Officer's director's action following the last such
3 review, whichever is later, and such notice shall be mailed to the
4 appropriator of record and posted on the department's website. The notice
5 shall state that any interested person may file comments relating to the
6 review of the instream appropriation or may request a hearing to present
7 evidence relevant to such review. Any such comments or request for
8 hearing shall be filed with in the Chief Water Officer headquarters
9 office of the department within six weeks after the date of final
10 publication of the notice. The appropriator of record shall, within the
11 six-week period, file written documentation of the continued use of the
12 appropriation. If no requests for hearing are received and if the Chief
13 Water Officer director is satisfied with the information provided by the
14 appropriator of record that the appropriation continues to be
15 beneficially used and is in the public interest, the Chief Water Officer
16 director shall issue an order stating such findings. If requested by any
17 interested person, or on his or her own motion based on the comments and
18 information filed, the Chief Water Officer director shall schedule a
19 hearing. If a hearing is held, the purpose of the hearing shall be to
20 receive evidence regarding whether the water appropriated under the
21 permit still provides the beneficial uses for which the permit was
22 granted and whether the permit is still in the public interest. The
23 hearing shall proceed under the rebuttable presumption that the
24 appropriation continues to provide the beneficial uses for which the
25 permit was granted and that the appropriation is in the public interest.
26 After the hearing, the Chief Water Officer director may by order modify
27 or cancel, in whole or in part, the instream appropriation.

4 Sec. 144. Section 46-2,139, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
5 amended to read:
6 46-2,139 The Storm Water Management Plan Program is created. The
7 purpose of the program is to facilitate and fund the duties of cities and
8 counties under the federal Clean Water Act, 33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq., as
9 such act existed on January 1, 2006, regarding storm water runoff under
10 the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System requirements. The
11 Storm Water Management Plan Program shall function as a grant program
12 administered by the Department of Water, Energy, and Environment
13 Environment and Energy, using funds appropriated for the program. The
14 department shall deduct from funds appropriated amounts sufficient to
15 reimburse itself for its costs of administration of the grant program.
16 Any city or county when applying for a grant under the program shall have
17 a storm water management plan approved by the department which meets the
18 requirements of the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System.
19 Grant applications shall be made to the department on forms prescribed by
20 the department. Grant funds shall be distributed by the department as
21 follows:
22 (1) Not less than eighty percent of the funds available for grants
23 under this section shall be provided to cities and counties in urbanized
24 areas, as identified in 77 Federal Register 18652-18669, that apply for
25 grants and meet the requirements of this section. Grants made pursuant to
26 this subdivision shall be distributed proportionately based on the
27 population of applicants within such category, as determined by the most
28 recent federal census update or recount certified by the United States
29 Department of Commerce, Bureau of the Census. For the purpose of
30 distributing grant funds to a county pursuant to this subdivision, the
31 proportion shall be based on the county population, less the population
-151-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 of city applicants within that county. Any funds available for grants
2 under this subdivision and not awarded by the end of a calendar year
3 shall be available for grants in the following year; and
4 (2) Not more than twenty percent of the funds available for grants
5 under this section shall be provided to cities and counties outside of
6 urbanized areas, as identified in 77 Federal Register 18652-18669, with
7 populations greater than ten thousand inhabitants as determined by the
8 most recent federal census update or recount certified by the United
9 States Department of Commerce, Bureau of the Census, that apply for
10 grants and meet the requirements of this section. Grants under this
11 subdivision shall be distributed proportionately based on the population
12 of applicants within this category as determined by the most recent
13 federal census update or recount certified by the United States
14 Department of Commerce, Bureau of the Census. For the purpose of
15 distributing grant funds to a county pursuant to this subdivision, the
16 proportion shall be based on the county population, less the population
17 of city applicants within that county. Any funds available for grants
18 pursuant to this subdivision which have not been awarded at the end of
19 each calendar year shall be available for awarding grants pursuant to
20 subdivision (1) of this section.
21 Any city or county receiving a grant under subdivision (1) or (2) of
22 this section shall contribute matching funds equal to twenty percent of
23 the grant amount.

MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 the submission of proposition and all matters pertaining to such election
2 to conform, including notice of election, as nearly as may be, and except
3 as otherwise expressly provided in sections 46-301 to 46-315, to the
4 provisions of law governing elections upon propositions for the issuance
5 of bonds of the district. The report of the Chief Water Officer
6 Department of Natural Resources and all other data and information on
7 file with the board of directors or the officers of the district shall be
8 subject to inspection at all reasonable business hours by any elector of
9 the district, or other interested persons, for the entire period during
10 which notice of the election shall be published. Such question and
11 proposition shall be thus submitted by ballots upon which shall appear,
12 in a clear, fair, and concise manner, a statement of the nature and
13 description of the proposed project, and, if such proposition includes
14 the issuance of bonds of the district, there shall also appear upon the
15 ballots a general description of such bonds, including principal amount,
16 rate of interest and when payable, date of issuance, and date of
17 maturity. At the bottom of the ballots substantially the following form
18 shall appear:
19 FOR the adoption of the foregoing plan and project (and issuance of
20 bonds of the district).
21 AGAINST the adoption of the foregoing plan and project (and the
22 issuance of bonds of the district).
23 If a majority of the ballots cast on such proposition are in favor
24 thereof, the board of directors shall declare the same adopted, and the
25 board of directors of the district shall proceed forthwith to put such
26 plan and project into effect, including the issuance of bonds of the
27 district if included in the proposition submitted at the election, the
28 levy and collection of taxes and assessments to pay such bonds and
29 interest thereon, and the execution of all contracts proper or incident
30 to the consummation of such plan and project.

1 formed under the act unless the taxable valuation of land, together with
2 improvements thereon, within the proposed district, exclusive of land and
3 improvements thereon in cities and villages, is five million seven
4 hundred twenty thousand dollars or more. The petition shall set forth:
5 (1) The proposed name of the district;
6 (2) That property within the proposed district will be benefited by
7 the accomplishment of the purposes enumerated in section 46-515;
8 (3) A general description of the purpose of the contemplated
9 improvement and of the territory to be included in the proposed district.
10 The description need not be given by metes and bounds or by legal
11 subdivision, but it shall be sufficient to enable a property owner to
12 ascertain whether the property is within the territory proposed to be
13 organized as a district. The territory need not be contiguous if it is so
14 situated that the organization of a single district of the territory
15 described is calculated to promote one or more of the purposes enumerated
16 in section 46-515;
17 (4) The taxable value of all irrigable land within the boundaries of
18 the proposed district;
19 (5) A general description of the divisions of the district, the
20 number of directors of the district proposed for each subdivision, and

24 elected and qualified. In the petition the directors named shall be
25 divided as nearly as possible into three equal groups, the members of the
26 first group to hold office until their successors have been elected at
27 the first general state election thereafter and have qualified, the
28 members of the second group to hold office until their successors have
29 been elected at the second general state election thereafter and have
30 qualified, and the members of the third group until the members elected
31 at the third general state election thereafter have qualified. After the
-158-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 name of each director, it shall be stated to which of the three groups he
2 or she belongs; and
3 (6) A prayer for the organization of the district by the name
4 proposed.
5 No petition with the requisite signatures shall be declared null and
6 void on account of alleged defects, but the Chief Water Officer
7 department may at any time permit the petition to be amended to conform
8 to the facts, to correct any errors in the description of the territory,
9 or in any other particular. Similar petitions or duplicate copies of the
10 same petition for the organization of the same district may be filed and
11 shall together be regarded as one petition. All such petitions filed
12 prior to the hearing on the first petition filed shall be considered by
13 the Chief Water Officer department the same as though filed with the
14 first petition placed on file. In determining whether the requisite
15 number of landowners have signed the petition, the Chief Water Officer
16 department shall be governed by the names as they appear upon the tax
17 roll which shall be prima facie evidence of such ownership.

20 46-525 Upon the said hearing, if it shall appear that a petition for
21 the organization of a reclamation district has been signed and presented,

26 department shall, by order duly entered of record, adjudicate all
27 questions of jurisdiction, declare the district organized, and give it a
28 corporate name, by which it shall thereafter be known in all proceedings.
29 Thereupon the district shall be a political subdivision of the State of
30 Nebraska and a body corporate with all the powers of a public or
31 municipal corporation.

MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 appropriation for the actual construction of its works, no physical
2 construction of any of its works has been started, then the same question
3 shall again be submitted to the qualified electors. In the event a
4 majority of the qualified voters voting in such election vote yes, then
5 such district shall be continued for an additional fifteen years.
6 In the event of a failure to receive a majority affirmative vote of
7 the voters voting in such election, the district shall be dissolved and
8 the district shall submit to the Chief Water Officer department a full
9 and complete audit by a public accountant showing the assets possessed by
10 the district. Thereupon the Chief Water Officer department shall enter an
11 order providing that within sixty days the assets of such district shall
12 be liquidated, all rights granted by the Chief Water Officer department
13 shall be canceled, and any assets on hand shall be divided as follows:
14 (a) All bills payable and all expenses of dissolution shall be
15 deducted from the assets and paid; and
16 (b) The balance remaining shall be divided proportionately among the
17 operating public school districts of the district in the proportion that
18 the number of acres in each school district bears to the total number of
19 acres of all of the school districts within the boundaries of the
20 district. If the district is confined to one county, distribution shall
21 be made by the county treasurer of such county. If the district extends
22 into more than one county, the funds for disbursement to such school
23 districts shall be paid to the county within which the schoolhouses are
24 located for distribution to such school districts;
25 (2) To take by appropriation, grant, purchase, bequest, devise, or
26 lease, and to hold and enjoy water rights and waterworks, and any and all
27 real and personal property of any kind within or without the district
28 necessary or convenient to the full exercise of its powers; to purchase,
29 sell, lease, encumber, alienate, or otherwise dispose of waterworks and
30 real and personal property; to enter into contracts for furnishing water
31 service for use within the district; to acquire, construct, operate,
-166-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 control, and use any and all works, facilities, and means necessary or
2 convenient to the exercise of its power, both within and without the
3 district, for the purpose of providing for the use of such water within
4 the district; and to do and perform any and all things necessary or
5 convenient to the full exercise of the powers granted in this
6 subdivision;
7 (3) To have and to exercise the power of eminent domain in addition
8 to any other rights and powers conferred in this section upon any
9 district organized under the Reclamation Act, for the purposes and after
10 the manner provided for in sections 76-704 to 76-724, except that when
11 any reclamation district exercises the power of eminent domain as to
12 water being used for power purposes, it shall not include any other
13 properties of any irrigation district, public power district, or public
14 power and irrigation district organized and existing under the laws of
15 the State of Nebraska;
16 (4) To construct and maintain works and establish and maintain
17 facilities across or along any public street or highway and in, upon, or
18 over any vacant public lands, which public lands are now or may hereafter
19 become the property of the State of Nebraska, and to construct works and
20 establish and maintain facilities across any stream of water or
21 watercourse. The district shall promptly restore any such street or
22 highway to its former state of usefulness as nearly as may be and shall
23 not use the same in such manner as to completely or unnecessarily impair
24 the usefulness thereof. In the use of streets, the district shall be
25 subject to the reasonable rules and regulations of the county, city, or
26 village where such streets lie concerning excavation and the refilling of
27 excavation, the relaying of pavements, and the protection of the public
28 during periods of construction. The district shall not be required to pay
29 any license or permit fees or file any bonds. The district may be
30 required to pay reasonable inspection fees;
31 (5) To contract with the government of the United States or any
-167-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 agency thereof for the construction, preservation, operation, and
2 maintenance of tunnels, reservoirs, regulating or reregulating basins,
3 diversion works and canals, dams, power plants, drains, and all necessary
4 works incident thereto, to acquire rights to the use of water from such
5 works, and to enter into contracts for the use of water from such works
6 by persons and corporations, public and private;
7 (6) To list in separate ownership the lands within the district
8 which are susceptible of irrigation from the district sources, to enter
9 into contracts to furnish water service to all such lands, and to levy
10 assessments as hereinafter provided against the lands within the district
11 to which water service is furnished on the basis of the value per acre-
12 foot of water service furnished to the lands within the district. The
13 board may divide the district into units and fix a different value per
14 acre-foot of water in the respective units and in such case shall assess
15 the lands within each unit upon the same basis of value per acre-foot of
16 water service furnished to lands within such unit;
17 (7) To fix rates at which water service, not otherwise provided for
18 in this section, may be furnished. Rates shall be equitable although not
19 necessarily equal or uniform for like classes of service throughout the
20 district;
21 (8) To adopt plans and specifications for the works for which the
22 district was organized, which plans and specifications may at any time be
23 changed or modified by the board. The plans shall include maps, profiles,
24 and such other data and descriptions as may be necessary to set forth the
25 location and character of the works, and a copy thereof shall be kept in
26 the office of the district and open to public inspection. The plans and
27 specifications and any changes shall be approved by the Chief Water
28 Officer department in accordance with the statutes;
29 (9) To appropriate and otherwise acquire water rights within or
30 without the state; to develop, store, and transport water; to provide,
31 contract for, and furnish water service for municipal and domestic
-168-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 purposes, irrigation, power, milling, manufacturing, mining,
2 metallurgical use, and any and all other beneficial uses and to derive
3 revenue and benefits therefrom; to fix the terms and rates therefor; to
4 make and adopt plans for and to acquire, construct, operate, and maintain
5 dams, reservoirs, canals, conduits, pipelines, tunnels, power plants,
6 transmission lines, and any and all works, facilities, improvements, and
7 property necessary or convenient therefor; and in the doing of all of
8 such things to obligate itself and execute and perform such obligations
9 according to the tenor thereof. The contracts for furnishing of water
10 service for irrigation and domestic purposes shall only be made for use
11 within the district. The board may transfer water appropriations within
12 the district pursuant to sections 46-2,127 to 46-2,129;
13 (10) To invest any surplus money in the district treasury, including
14 such money as may be in any sinking fund established for the purpose of
15 providing for the payment of the principal or interest of any contract,
16 bond, or other indebtedness or for any other purpose, not required for
17 the immediate necessities of the district, in its own bonds or in
18 treasury notes or bonds of the United States. The investment may be made
19 by direct purchase of any issue of such bonds or treasury notes, or part
20 thereof, at the original sale of the same or by the subsequent purchase
21 of such bonds or treasury notes. Any bonds or treasury notes thus
22 purchased and held may, from time to time, be sold and the proceeds
23 reinvested in bonds or treasury notes as provided in this subdivision.
24 Sales of any bonds or treasury notes thus purchased and held shall, from
25 time to time, be made in season so that the proceeds may be applied to
26 the purposes for which the money with which the bonds or treasury notes
27 were originally purchased was placed in the treasury of the district. The
28 functions and duties authorized by this subdivision shall be performed
29 under such rules and regulations as shall be prescribed by the board;
30 (11) To refund bonded indebtedness incurred by the district under
31 and pursuant to such rules and regulations as shall be prescribed by the
-169-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 board;
2 (12) To borrow money, incur indebtedness, and issue bonds or other
3 evidence of such indebtedness;
4 (13) To adopt bylaws not in conflict with the Constitution of
5 Nebraska and laws of the state for carrying on the business, objects, and
6 affairs of the board and of the district; and
7 (14) To enter into agreements for water service with agencies of the
8 federal government or the Game and Parks Commission through which water
9 will be made available, at rates determined as provided in subdivision
10 (7) of this section, for hunting, fishing, and recreational development.
11 The water service shall not exceed the amount of water which may be
12 appropriated for such purposes by order of the Chief Water Officer
13 department, and such amounts shall be included in the total appropriative
14 right of the district or districts involved.
15 Sec. 168. Section 46-583, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
16 amended to read:
17 46-583 At the hearing, if the board of directors of such district
18 deems it not for the best interest of such district that a change of its
19 boundaries be so made as to include therein the lands mentioned in the
20 petition, the board of directors of such district shall order that the
21 petition be rejected. But if the board of directors of such district
22 deems it for the best interest of such district that the boundaries of
23 such district be changed and if it appears that the petition for the
24 annexation and incorporation of the tract or tracts of land has been
25 signed and presented as provided in section 46-574, that the allegations
26 of the petition are true, and that no protesting petition has been filed,
27 or if filed has been dismissed as provided by sections 46-574 to 46-584,
28 the board of directors of such district may enter a tentative order
29 annexing and including all lands described in the petition, or some part
30 thereof. The order shall not become final until the proposition of
31 levying taxes as provided for in section 46-543 has been complied with
-170-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 and until the proposition of levying taxes has been submitted by a
2 resolution of the board of directors of such district to the qualified
3 electors residing within the tract or tracts of land described in the
4 tentative order at an election held for that purpose in the same manner
5 as provided for submission of incurring bonded indebtedness in sections
6 46-564 to 46-566, and when the proposition has been approved by a
7 majority of the qualified electors residing within the tract or tracts of
8 land voting on the proposition at such election, then the board of
9 directors shall enter a final order annexing and including all lands
10 described in the tentative order. If at such election a majority of the
11 qualified electors vote against the proposition, then the board of
12 directors of such district shall set aside the tentative order, shall
13 order that the petition be denied, and shall proceed no further in that
14 matter. If the proposition is approved by a majority of the qualified
15 electors of the tract or tracts voting on the proposition at such
16 election in the manner provided for in section 46-543, the board of
17 directors of such district shall certify to the county board of the
18 county in which the tract or tracts of land are situated the rate of tax
19 to be levied. The final order entered by the board of directors of such
20 district shall describe the entire boundaries of the district, and for
21 that purpose the board of directors may cause a survey of such portions
22 thereof to be made as the board of directors deems necessary. A copy of
23 the final order of the board of directors ordering such annexation,
24 certified by the president and secretary of the board of directors of
25 such district, shall be filed with the Chief Water Officer Department of
26 Natural Resources, and thereupon the district shall be and remain a
27 reclamation district as fully and to every intent and purpose as if the
28 lands which are included in the district by the annexation thereof and
29 the change of boundaries had been included therein at the original
30 organization of the district. Such tract or tracts of land so annexed to
31 such district shall enjoy all the rights and privileges, of whatever kind
-171-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 and nature, and be subject to all the contract, obligation, lien, or
2 charge for or upon which the original district was or might become liable
3 or chargeable.
4 Sec. 169. Section 46-601.01, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska,
5 is amended to read:
6 46-601.01 For purposes of Chapter 46, article 6:
7 (1) Chief Water Officer means the Chief Water Officer of the
8 Department of Water, Energy, and Environment;
9 (2) Common carrier means any carrier of water including a pipe,
10 canal, ditch, or other means of piping or adjoining water for irrigation
11 purposes;
12 (3) Department means the Department of Water, Energy, and
13 Environment;
14 (4) Director means the Director of Water, Energy, and Environment;
15 and
16 (5)(a) (1)(a) Water well means any excavation that is drilled,
17 cored, bored, washed, driven, dug, jetted, or otherwise constructed for
18 the purpose of exploring for ground water, monitoring ground water,
19 utilizing the geothermal properties of the ground, obtaining
20 hydrogeologic information, or extracting water from or injecting fluid as
21 defined in section 81-1502 into the underground water reservoir.
22 (b) Water well includes any excavation made for any purpose if
23 ground water flows into the excavation under natural pressure and a pump
24 or other device is placed in the excavation for the purpose of
25 withdrawing water from the excavation for irrigation. For such
26 excavations, construction means placing a pump or other device into the
27 excavation for the purpose of withdrawing water for irrigation.
28 (c) Water well does not include (i) any excavation made for
29 obtaining or prospecting for oil or natural gas or for inserting media to
30 repressure oil or natural gas bearing formations regulated by the

3 Sec. 175. Section 46-613.01, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska,
4 is amended to read:
5 46-613.01 The Legislature recognizes and declares that the
6 maintenance of an adequate source of ground water within this state is
7 essential to the social stability of the state and the health, safety,
8 and welfare of its citizens and that reasonable restrictions on the
9 transportation of ground water from this state are a proper exercise of
10 the police powers of the state. The need for such restrictions, which
11 protect the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of this
12 state, is hereby declared a matter of legislative determination.
13 Any person, firm, city, village, municipal corporation, or other
14 entity intending to withdraw ground water from any water well located in
15 the State of Nebraska and transport it for use in another state shall
16 apply to the Chief Water Officer Department of Natural Resources for a
17 permit to do so. In determining whether to grant or deny such permit, the
18 Chief Water Officer Director of Natural Resources shall consider:
19 (1) The nature of the proposed use and whether it is a beneficial
20 use of ground water;
21 (2) The availability to the applicant of alternative sources of
22 surface or ground water;
23 (3) Any negative effect of the proposed withdrawal on ground water
24 supplies needed to meet present or reasonable future demands for water in
25 the area of the proposed withdrawal, to comply with any interstate
26 compact or decree, or to fulfill the provisions of any other formal state
27 contract or agreement;
28 (4) Any negative effect of the proposed withdrawal on surface water
29 supplies needed to meet present or reasonable future demands within the
30 state, to comply with any interstate compact or decree, or to fulfill the
31 provisions of any other formal state contract or agreement;
-182-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 (5) Any adverse environmental effect of the proposed withdrawal or
2 transportation of ground water;
3 (6) The cumulative effect of the proposed withdrawal and transfer
4 relative to the matters listed in subdivisions (3) through (7) (6) of
5 this section when considered in conjunction with all other transfers
6 subject to this section; and
7 (7) Any other factors consistent with the purposes of this section
8 that the Chief Water Officer director deems relevant to protect the
9 health, safety, and welfare of the state and its citizens.
10 Issuance of a permit shall be conditioned on the applicant's
11 compliance with the rules and regulations of the natural resources
12 district from which the water is to be withdrawn. The applicant shall be
13 required to provide access to his or her property at reasonable times for
14 purposes of inspection by officials of the district or the Chief Water
15 Officer or the Chief Water Officer's representatives department.
16 The Chief Water Officer director may include such reasonable
17 conditions on the proposed use as he or she deems necessary to carry out
18 the purposes of this section.
19 Sec. 176. Section 46-613.02, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska,
20 is amended to read:
21 46-613.02 Any person violating any provision of sections 46-601 to
22 46-613.01 or furnishing false information under such sections shall be

25 attorneys may pursue appropriate proceedings pursuant to this section

2 Sec. 182. Section 46-642, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
3 amended to read:
4 46-642 (1) If the Chief Water Officer Director of Natural Resources

12 (2) In determining whether to grant or deny a permit under
13 subsection (1) of this section, the Chief Water Officer director shall
14 consider the factors set forth in subdivisions (1) through (7) of section
15 46-613.01.
16 Sec. 183. Section 46-644, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is

31 water are in the public interest. In determining whether the withdrawal
-193-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 and transfer, if any, are in the public interest, the Chief Water
2 Officer's director's considerations shall include, but not be limited to:
3 (a) Possible adverse effects on existing surface or ground water
4 users;

8 water withdrawal;

11 proposed withdrawal or use;

12 46-686.01 The Chief Water Officer director shall have jurisdiction
13 over any ground water withdrawal and transfer made under section
14 46-678.01. Any person using ground water at the time a notice to transfer
15 is filed under such section whose wells thereafter suffer an
16 unanticipated decline in ground water levels may petition the Chief Water
17 Officer director for a hearing. Such petition shall specifically set
18 forth the cause and extent of the ground water decline as well as the
19 nature and extent of any injury resulting from that decline. If at such
20 hearing the injured party presents evidence showing that the ground water
21 levels declined as a result of such transfer and shows the nature and
22 extent of any resulting injury, the Chief Water Officer director may

1 objection, in the office of the natural resources district containing the

7 if the district has reason to believe that the withdrawal, transfer, or

10 Protection Act to prohibit such withdrawal, transfer, or use. If the

12 consistent with all rules and regulations of the district but may not

14 section, the district shall request that the Chief Water Officer

20 of the hearing. After the hearing, if the Chief Water Officer Director of

23 he or she shall issue a cease and desist order prohibiting the withdrawal

27 Sec. 204. Section 46-703, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
28 amended to read:
29 46-703 The Legislature further finds:
30 (1) The management, conservation, and beneficial use of
31 hydrologically connected ground water and surface water are essential to
-199-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 the continued economic prosperity and well-being of the state, including
2 the present and future development of agriculture in the state;
3 (2) Hydrologically connected ground water and surface water may need
4 to be managed differently from unconnected ground water and surface water
5 in order to permit equity among water users and to optimize the
6 beneficial use of interrelated ground water and surface water supplies;
7 (3) Natural resources districts already have significant legal
8 authority to regulate activities which contribute to declines in ground
9 water levels and to nonpoint source contamination of ground water and are
10 the preferred entities to regulate, through ground water management
11 areas, ground water related activities which are contributing to or are,
12 in the reasonably foreseeable future, likely to contribute to conflicts
13 between ground water users and surface water appropriators or to water
14 supply shortages in fully appropriated or overappropriated river basins,
15 subbasins, or reaches;
16 (4) The Legislature recognizes that ground water use or surface
17 water use in one natural resources district may have adverse affects on
18 water supplies in another district or in an adjoining state. The
19 Legislature intends and expects that each natural resources district
20 within which water use is causing external impacts will accept
21 responsibility for ground water management in accordance with the
22 Nebraska Ground Water Management and Protection Act in the same manner
23 and to the same extent as if the impacts were contained within that
24 district;
25 (5) The Chief Water Officer Department of Natural Resources is
26 responsible for regulation of surface water resources and local surface
27 water project sponsors are responsible for much of the structured
28 irrigation utilizing surface water supplies, and the Chief Water Officer
29 and the local surface water project sponsors these entities should be
30 responsible for regulation of surface water related activities which
31 contribute to conflicts between ground water users and surface water
-200-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 appropriators or to water supply shortages in fully appropriated or
2 overappropriated river basins, subbasins, or reaches;
3 (6) All involved natural resources districts, the Chief Water
4 Officer department, and surface water project sponsors should cooperate
5 and collaborate on the identification and implementation of management
6 solutions to conflicts between ground water users and surface water
7 appropriators or to water supply shortages in fully appropriated or
8 overappropriated river basins, subbasins, and reaches; and
9 (7) An Interrelated Water Review Board is needed to resolve any
10 conflicts between the Chief Water Officer department and the involved
11 natural resources districts concerning the content, implementation, or
12 enforcement of integrated management plans for fully appropriated and
13 overappropriated river basins, subbasins, and reaches.
14 Sec. 205. Section 46-704, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
15 amended to read:
16 46-704 The Legislature also finds that:
17 (1) The levels of nitrate nitrogen and other contaminants in ground
18 water in certain areas of the state are increasing;
19 (2) Long-term solutions should be implemented and efforts should be
20 made to prevent the levels of ground water contaminants from becoming too
21 high and to reduce high levels sufficiently to eliminate health hazards;
22 (3) Agriculture has been very productive and should continue to be
23 an important industry to the State of Nebraska;
24 (4) Natural resources districts have the legal authority to regulate
25 certain activities and, as local entities, are the preferred regulators
26 of activities which may contribute to ground water contamination in both
27 urban and rural areas;
28 (5) The department is authorized Department of Environment and
29 Energy should be given authority to regulate sources of contamination
30 when necessary to prevent serious deterioration of ground water quality;
31 (6) The powers given to districts and the department Department of

18 amended to read:
19 46-706 For purposes of the Municipal and Rural Domestic Ground Water
20 Transfers Permit Act, the Nebraska Ground Water Management and Protection
21 Act, and sections 46-601 to 46-613.02, 46-636, 46-637, and 46-651 to
22 46-655, unless the context otherwise requires:
23 (1) Person means a natural person, a partnership, a limited
24 liability company, an association, a corporation, a municipality, an
25 irrigation district, an agency or a political subdivision of the state,
26 or a department, an agency, or a bureau of the United States;
27 (2) Ground water means that water which occurs in or moves, seeps,
28 filters, or percolates through ground under the surface of the land;
29 (3) Contamination or contamination of ground water means nitrate
30 nitrogen or other material which enters the ground water due to action of
31 any person and causes degradation of the quality of ground water
-202-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 sufficient to make such ground water unsuitable for present or reasonably
2 foreseeable beneficial uses;
3 (4) Department means the Department of Water, Energy, and
4 Environment;
5 (5) Chief Water Officer means the Chief Water Officer of the
6 Department of Water, Energy, and Environment;
7 (6) (4) District means a natural resources district operating
8 pursuant to Chapter 2, article 32;
9 (7) (5) Illegal water well means (a) any water well operated or
10 constructed without or in violation of a permit required by the Nebraska
11 Ground Water Management and Protection Act, (b) any water well not in
12 compliance with rules and regulations adopted and promulgated pursuant to
13 the act, (c) any water well not properly registered in accordance with
14 sections 46-602 to 46-604, or (d) any water well not in compliance with
15 any other applicable laws of the State of Nebraska or with rules and
16 regulations adopted and promulgated pursuant to such laws;
17 (8) (6) To commence construction of a water well means the beginning
18 of the boring, drilling, jetting, digging, or excavating of the actual
19 water well from which ground water is to be withdrawn;
20 (9) (7) Management area means any area so designated by a district
21 pursuant to section 46-712 or 46-718, by the Director of Water, Energy,
22 and Environment Director of Environment and Energy pursuant to section
23 46-725, or by the Interrelated Water Review Board pursuant to section
24 46-719. Management area includes a control area or a special ground water
25 quality protection area designated prior to July 19, 1996;
26 (10) (8) Management plan means a ground water management plan
27 developed by a district and submitted to the Chief Water Officer Director
28 of Natural Resources for review pursuant to section 46-711;
29 (11) (9) Ground water reservoir life goal means the finite or
30 infinite period of time which a district establishes as its goal for
31 maintenance of the supply and quality of water in a ground water
-203-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 reservoir at the time a ground water management plan is adopted;
2 (12) (10) Board means the board of directors of a district;
3 (13) (11) Acre-inch means the amount of water necessary to cover an
4 acre of land one inch deep;
5 (14) (12) Subirrigation or subirrigated land means the natural
6 occurrence of a ground water table within the root zone of agricultural
7 vegetation, not exceeding ten feet below the surface of the ground;
8 (15) (13) Best management practices means schedules of activities,
9 maintenance procedures, and other management practices utilized for
10 purposes of irrigation efficiency, to conserve or effect a savings of
11 ground water, or to prevent or reduce present and future contamination of
12 ground water. Best management practices relating to contamination of
13 ground water may include, but not be limited to, irrigation scheduling,
14 proper rate and timing of fertilizer application, and other fertilizer
15 and pesticide management programs. In determining the rate of fertilizer
16 application, the district shall consult with the University of Nebraska
17 or a certified crop advisor certified by the American Society of
18 Agronomy;
19 (16) (14) Point source means any discernible, confined, and discrete
20 conveyance, including, but not limited to, any pipe, channel, tunnel,
21 conduit, well, discrete fissure, container, rolling stock, vessel, other
22 floating craft, or other conveyance, over which the department Department
23 of Environment and Energy has regulatory authority and from which a
24 substance which can cause or contribute to contamination of ground water
25 is or may be discharged;
26 (17) (15) Allocation, as it relates to water use for irrigation
27 purposes, means the allotment of a specified total number of acre-inches
28 of irrigation water per irrigated acre per year or an average number of
29 acre-inches of irrigation water per irrigated acre over any reasonable
30 period of time;
31 (18) (16) Rotation means a recurring series of use and nonuse of
-204-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 irrigation wells on an hourly, daily, weekly, monthly, or yearly basis;
2 (19) (17) Water well has the same meaning as in section 46-601.01;
3 (20) (18) Surface water project sponsor means an irrigation district
4 created pursuant to Chapter 46, article 1, a reclamation district created
5 pursuant to Chapter 46, article 5, or a public power and irrigation
6 district created pursuant to Chapter 70, article 6;
7 (21) (19) Beneficial use means that use by which water may be put to
8 use to the benefit of humans or other species;
9 (22) (20) Consumptive use means the amount of water that is consumed
10 under appropriate and reasonably efficient practices to accomplish
11 without waste the purposes for which the appropriation or other legally
12 permitted use is lawfully made;
13 (23) (21) Dewatering well means a well constructed and used solely
14 for the purpose of lowering the ground water table elevation;
15 (24) (22) Emergency situation means any set of circumstances that
16 requires the use of water from any source that might otherwise be
17 regulated or prohibited and the agency, district, or organization
18 responsible for regulating water use from such source reasonably and in
19 good faith believes that such use is necessary to protect the public
20 health, safety, and welfare, including, if applicable, compliance with
21 federal or state water quality standards;
22 (25) (23) Good cause shown means a reasonable justification for
23 granting a variance for a consumptive use of water that would otherwise
24 be prohibited by rule or regulation and which the granting agency,
25 district, or organization reasonably and in good faith believes will
26 provide an economic, environmental, social, or public health and safety
27 benefit that is equal to or greater than the benefit resulting from the
28 rule or regulation from which a variance is sought;
29 (26) (24) Historic consumptive use means the amount of water that
30 has previously been consumed under appropriate and reasonably efficient
31 practices to accomplish without waste the purposes for which the
-205-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 appropriation or other legally permitted use was lawfully made;
2 (27) (25) Monitoring well means a water well that is designed and
3 constructed to provide ongoing hydrologic or water quality information
4 and is not intended for consumptive use;
5 (28) (26) Order, except as otherwise specifically provided, includes
6 any order required by the Nebraska Ground Water Management and Protection
7 Act, by rule or regulation, or by a decision adopted by a district by
8 vote of the board of directors of the district taken at any regularly
9 scheduled or specially scheduled meeting of the board;
10 (29) (27) Overall difference between the current and fully
11 appropriated levels of development means the extent to which existing
12 uses of hydrologically connected surface water and ground water and
13 conservation activities result in the water supply available for purposes
14 identified in subsection (3) of section 46-713 to be less than the water
15 supply available if the river basin, subbasin, or reach had been
16 determined to be fully appropriated in accordance with section 46-714;
17 (30) (28) Test hole means a hole designed solely for the purposes of
18 obtaining information on hydrologic or geologic conditions;
19 (31) (29) Variance means (a) an approval to deviate from a
20 restriction imposed under subsection (1), (2), (8), or (9) of section
21 46-714 or (b) the approval to act in a manner contrary to existing rules
22 or regulations from a governing body whose rule or regulation is
23 otherwise applicable;
24 (32) (30) Certified irrigated acres means the number of acres or
25 portion of an acre that a natural resources district has approved for
26 irrigation from ground water in accordance with law and with rules
27 adopted by the district; and
28 (33) (31) Certified water uses means beneficial uses of ground water
29 for purposes other than irrigation identified by a district pursuant to
30 rules adopted by the district.

6 (2) In addition to the powers enumerated in subsection (1) of this

8 of one hundred eighty days on the construction of any new water well and
9 on any increase in the number of acres historically irrigated, without
10 prior notice or hearing, upon adoption of a resolution by the board
11 finding that such temporary immediate stay is necessary. The district
12 shall hold at least one public hearing on the matter within the district
13 during such one hundred eighty days, with the notice of the hearing given
14 as provided in section 46-743, prior to making a determination as to
15 imposing a permanent stay or conditions in accordance with subsections
16 (1) and (6) of section 46-739. Within forty-five days after a hearing
17 pursuant to this subsection, the district shall decide whether to exempt
18 from the immediate temporary stay the construction of water wells for
19 which permits were issued prior to the date of the resolution commencing
20 the stay but for which construction had not begun prior to such date. If
21 construction of such water wells is allowed, all permits that were valid
22 when the stay went into effect shall be extended by a time period equal
23 to the length of the stay and such water wells shall otherwise be
24 completed in accordance with section 46-738. Water wells listed in
25 subsection (3) of section 46-714 and water wells of public water
26 suppliers are exempt from this subsection.

4 Sec. 209. Section 46-709, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, is
5 amended to read:
6 46-709 Each district shall maintain a ground water management plan
7 based upon the best available information and shall submit amendments to

11 the extent possible of:
12 (1) Ground water supplies within the district including
13 transmissivity, saturated thickness maps, and other ground water
14 reservoir information, if available;

22 district;

25 the district;
26 (9) The availability of supplemental water supplies, including the
27 opportunity for ground water recharge;

31 46-718, the district's management plan shall have been approved by the
-211-

ER36 ER36
LB317 LB317
MJP - 04/10/2025 MJP - 04/10/2025
1 Chief Water Officer Director of Natural Resources or the district shall
2 have completed the requirements of subsection (2) of section 46-711. If
3 necessary to determine whether a management area should be designated,
4 the district may initiate new studies and data-collection efforts and
5 develop computer models. In order to establish a management area, the
6 district shall fix a time and place for a public hearing to consider the
7 management plan information supplied by the Chief Water Officer director
8 and to hear any other evidence. The hearing shall be located within or in
9 reasonable proximity to the area proposed for designation as a management
10 area. Notice of the hearing shall be published as provided in section
11 46-743, and the hearing shall be conducted in accordance with such
12 section.
13 (3)(a) Within ninety days after the hearing, the district shall
14 determine whether a management area shall be designated. If the district
15 determines that no management area shall be established, the district
16 shall issue an order to that effect.
17 (b) If the district determines that a management area shall be
18 established, the district shall by order designate the area as a
19 management area and shall adopt one or more controls authorized by
20 section 46-739 to be utilized within the area in order to achieve the
21 ground water management objectives specified in the plan. Such an order
22 shall include a geographic and stratigraphic definition of the area. The
23 boundaries and controls shall take into account any considerations
24 brought forth at the hearing and administrative factors directly
25 affecting the ability of the district to implement and carry out local
26 ground water management.
27 (c) The controls adopted shall not include controls substantially
28 different from those set forth in the notice of the hearing. The area
29 designated by the order shall not include any area not included in the
30 notice of the hearing.
